item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
I don't know if this happens to other people, but every so often I undergo this delusion where I forget that life isn't fair and I start to think 'It'll all be alright...' in some mad attack of optimism. Of course, there is no rational reason to believe everything will be alright and it is very disappointing when life turns out not to be fair or alright just from hoping it will be so. That leaves life turning on the factors of chance and personal effort and imagination.

Actually (and I apologise for being so morbid),but it'd be fair to say it's not going to be alright as we're all going to die one way or the other and the longer one does survive the more grieving one has to do. Which reminds me of a bad joke - An old married couple in their nineties contact a divorce lawyer, who pleads with them to stay together after 75 years of marriage, "Why now? Why not last it out?"
The little old lady pipes up, "We wanted to wait until our children were dead."

It's the end of term and I hate my course and I've been living the last nine weeks on a 'it'll be alright..' basis. Like the couple in the joke, I'm never quite sure how long one is supposed to keep going and at what point it's reasonable to make a change. I don't think I'm at that point yet.

My time has been spent learning and relearning a lot of Maths and Physics which is good when it is well taught, but often it is not. The best teacher is our fluid dynamics lecturer. It's a difficult subject as so little of it is intuitive, but he's really good at connecting all the pieces of the puzzle together from definitions through first principles and onto complexity.
I've been learning about materials and their properties, such as concrete and steel which also has the potential to be interesting but often there is little depth beyond how these materials can be best used to ensure making a profit.
And I've been learning a bit more computer programming and using drawing software.

Of the five Ws - What?Where?When?Who?Why? - the last one rarely gets a look in, though as you can probably guess it's the one I find most interesting. To me it's the one that gives sense to the others.
Civil Engineering covers a large range of things from understanding transport networks down to specifying the nuts and bolts for a bus shelter, so we've been introduced to a little of a lot of things. It has the potential to be really interesting and world changing, but at the moment it is not. Last year my lecturers conveyed a love of their subject's that enthused us (well, me anyway). This lot act like they can't really be bothered most of the time. And when they can, it's all about getting a job at the end, which while important, seems like missing the point of learning.
So maybe I'll end up quitting and returning to part time study and full time work or change courses or Universities. There is rarely only one way to go about things.

In the meantime, I've been taking comfort in reading a bit of philosophy (Descartes and English Mathematician G.H. Hardy) and having not been to a gallery in the best part of a year, I've been twice in the past month. It's interesting to spend time considering things which are essentially qualitative as opposed to the largely quantitative realms of science and engineering. Maybe it's just a reflection of my frame of mind at the moment, but I came away from looking at Art with the feeling that over the last couple of hundred years a quite pessimistic view of humanity has evolved through Art which is in contrast to the general optimism of the Science Project. That said, a lot of what I looked at was excellent and the Art did make me realise that I want to be doing something that is creative and that it is the lack of use of my imagination that I'm finding so frustrating on my course. And last year showed me that science can be very very creative and imaginative, so it's really annoying when it's not this year. I'm hoping this will change.

I've never been much of a diary keeper and I started this blog it was with the proviso that I'd only write when I had something at least mildly interesting to say (if only to myself!) or experiences to share. I haven't really got anything interesting to say at present and haven't done very much except study, work or swim since September, hence the dull postings (and it's taken two weeks to write this.)

The picture above was my attempt to capture the light at this time of year and there are a couple of additions to my Photo Scrapbook on the right.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
This is what it looks like after the 25 million pound research centre next door to my block of flats burnt down.
Only a couple of days before, I had been contemplating the fact I have no back up for my files outside of my flat and how to remedy that.Then on Sunday 30th October, Steve called me to ask if I was OK as he saw my University was on fire. Fortunately for me I was in Devon at the time. For those less lucky it was a story of lost PhD research and a night in other accommodation as they were all evacuated from our building. Most importantly though no-one was hurt. It's still under investigation, but the whole thing started at about 6.30 am when it's suspected that some gas canisters exploded and two buildings went up in flames.

So top of my priority list now is to get some off-site back up sorted!

Sadly, my course is quite rubbish and I'm rather hating being there. After last years brilliant lecturers, who were well organised, enthusiastic and could explain difficult concepts in a way that made them understandable, this course is poorly taught. Most of them seem incapable of giving a coherent structured lecture and rely far too heavily on PowerPoint - which should be banned in my opinion, except for the extreme examples where something cannot be explained verbally and/or with chalk. It's ironic considering they are supposed to be Engineers, which in my experience is all about communication.
To back up this point, a quick aside: I've been attending a swim club since the summer and I went for a drink with some of the others after training a couple of weeks ago for the first time. After I had been ranting about my hatred of the misuse of PowerPoint, one of my fellow swimmers revealed that he is a senior lecturer over at Biomedical Sciences and relied on PowerPoint a lot for his lectures.
Then last week, on my way into training, he stopped me and told me that he'd decided to not use PowerPoint for his most recent lecture and he observed that far less people left during the break than usual. I rest my case.

The only lecturer who seems to know what he is doing, is, unsurprisingly from another department - the Maths Professor, who rips through material at near light speed dispensing gems such as: "Being a Mathematician, I prefer not to call a spade a spade when a gardening implement will do..." and when doing a difficult bit of intergration, "This is point where we say: 'Give up!' Go home and decide to study History instead." before promptly showing us how to solve it.  I love the Maths guys! If I was up to it, I'd go and join them or the Physicists.

Most of the learning I have been doing is out of a book, by myself. Learning about the materials that make structures and a little computer programming and software use. Nothing interesting enough to mention, not even as trivia.

Addressing the request for light heartedness - how about the three young Goth lads in Cassocks last Tuesday? They were walking through the rain on campus, hair matted to their faces, mascara running down their cheeks. It warmed my heart to see such dedication.
Bet they stank of wee once they got inside and started heating up though...

Another request I received was for a picture of my new (used) bike. I'm not mad on it's looks myself, but it is a hell of a lot more comfortable on the motorway. 1000CCs of 'feelings of inadequacy' curing machinery...





So the plan at present is to stay here until at least the end of the academic year and review my options then. I'm hoping things improve, but if they don't I'll have to consider making a Plan B.

Other than being fed up, swimming, running and reading, in my life as a recluse, I've been watching some decent TV for a change:

The final series of Six Feet Under was pretty cool stuff about death. Really!
Bodies on BBC2, watching through my fingers. Gross, funny and disturbing NHS drama.
Curb Your Enthusiasm and The Thick of It on More4 and BBC3, some of the most offensively funny TV in a long time.
And on DVD cos the schedulers are too stupid to put it on a regular channel - The Wire, a superb crime series so far, probably the best I've seen. I'm only up to Episode 4.

All TV that has made me laugh and cry and reminded me that it can be a great medium.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
In a recent conversation it was suggested that I should write about more light hearted things. The problem with this is that I don't feel very light hearted much of the time.
To be brutally honest, I've been striving since I was a child just to reach the point where I wake up feeling like I'm actually glad to have woken up at all. Maybe other people spring out of bed singing 'Zip-a-dee-doo-da' and have love in their heart for every person they meet, but I don't.
Certainly I joke and laugh when I am with others, partly because I see it all as absurd anyway and partly because life is hard.
So this being my space, I kind of feel it's my prerogative to say what I feel and how I see it regardless of what anyone else says about me thinking too much or being too whatever. My standard response is: 'No, you don't think enough' - so there! (Just kidding.)
I've been surrounded by 19 year olds away from home for the first time this past week and their constant twittering is making serious inroads into my tolerance and empathy levels. I didn't like 19 year olds much when I was 19 and I like them less now. (Boys outside in the pub below my window singing Rugby songs tonight.) And then I got handed a timetable at induction with a 'Team Building Day' on it  and my heart sank to a new low. So much for science! I'm fully expecting David Brent to be running it. Or at least the Assistant to the Manager.

And while I'm having a good moan, I got a form for a scholarship with questions on it such as, 'What is your greatest personal achievement?' I am very tempted to submit, 'Not being born into poverty or war.' just to see if I get a response. Or 'Taking part in a Roasting with Stan Collymore'. What is the point of these questions?! Do they really provide any useful insight?

You may be able to detect a negative tone to this posting and, yes, I'm feeling pretty fed up as I commence Year Two at University. Whatever happens in the next few months, I'll stick it out until the end of the academic year, but there isn't much point continuing something that I'm not enjoying unless I have no choice. Such is the benefits of being a decadent Westerner. Usually in life I've found there to be periods like this and then periods when things are less rubbish. Fortunately, one gets old and dies regardless of how well or badly its going.

I'll strive for light hearted next time. Maybe. Right now - Grrr. Humans and being a Human.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: “Happy the hare at morning,” WH Auden wrote, “for she cannot read / The Hunter’s waking thoughts. Lucky the leaf / Unable to predict the fall. ... But what shall man do, who can whistle tunes by heart, / Know to the bar when death shall cut him short, like the cry of the shearwater." http://www.monbiot.com/archives/2005/08/16/a-life-with-no-purpose/

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
"Are all humans human? Are some more human than others?" Stephen Lewis UN Envoy for Africa

This first quote comes from a documentary called "Shake hands with the Devil" about the Rwanda genocide that happened 10 years ago this year. I watched it a couple of months back and with things I've been reading since and things that have happened it the outside world, these words have come back to me again and again. The original context was questioning why do we help some people in trouble but not others, but I've come to realise them as much more fundamental questions.

"The reason the Iraq torture pictures were shocking was not the events they portrayed...The only shocking thing was the act of photography itself, the realisation that people wanted to record these events, that they believed there were other people who would want to see them too. Is that really such a long way from the killer who keeps pictures of his victims?" Michael Marshall

This quote is just from a crime novel about a serial killer. Linking it to first quote, it reminded about how humans and our behaviours appear to exist along a spectrum and that our positions on it are not fixed. It is all too easy to find ourselves crossing the lines into areas that dehumanise ourselves and others.

A couple of weeks back I nearly got into a fight. Two young men throwing apples at me as I walked down the street. It sounds absurd and it was. The good old fight or flight mechanism kicked in, and said "Fight".
So having exchanged a few insults, I say to one of them, who has now approached me close enough to talk, "Would you like me to throw something at you?" "Go on then." was the response, a standard reply for this situation, a proper male stand off like you see in all the nature documentaries.
I was on my way to the bottle bank and had in my hand a bag of empty bottles. This guy had no visible form of defence to hand and for a couple of seconds I seriously thought about trying to smash him over the head with a bottle. I was so angry. Then I caught myself and engaged my brain and rattled through a few strategic thoughts i.e. it doesn't end here, even if I win now there is revenge and the law to consider. After those I came to thoughts similar to the quotes above. What do I become if I allow these feelings to rule my actions? However much I hate this guy right now, he is for better or worse a human being. I couldn't think of anything to say, so I just looked at him until he got bored of the stand off and left with a few parting remarks about me being queer. (It amazes me that people still consider that an insult! To me it sounds like trying to insult someone over hair colour or their height.)
I went on my way feeling pretty angry, fuming really, as my body had followed it's biological history and got me all prepared for a fight that never happened, but I was at least physically intact.

"They don't win matches, we drop the ball. Wrong. Sometimes the bad guys win because they're as good as we are. Strength of will and purity of hate will make up a huge technology gap." Michael Marshall

This last quote is also from the same book as the second and made me think about the 'haves' mindset when it comes to 'have nots'.

Over the last ten months there has been a lot of visible suffering on the screens.The Asian Tsunami, Iraq, Darfor, London bombings, Hurricane Katrina. It becomes easy to respond by thinking of these things as elsewhere and the bad luck of others, but in my mind we are all connected. Not in some linear narrative way, more like a network of connections like the world wide web. Even my own little local difficulty reminded me of this and that sticking my head in the sand is not an option for the long term. Everyone is connected and all these foolish divisions of nationalities and race and gender do us no favours in solving the real problems that face us all or in overcoming hate and our temptations towards the dehumanising end of the belief spectrum. Looking out for strangers is looking out for ourselves. And not only is that a moral position, it is a strategic one. It's harder to hate someone who is treating you well, so it's harder to justify doing something bad to them or see them as an object.

Humans and especially men are built for violence. It is part of our evolutionary heritage and has a role to play in sexual selection too. So while we are trapped in these shells it can't be eradicated, but we've also evolved brains that allow us to reflect and adapt. I'm trying.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
In my last post I wrote of observation led thinking and then went on to write about relativity. This might seem contrary and it does seem to be a source of endless trouble these days with the whole subjective and objective truth arguements. To me it's a fallicious interpretation to see them in opposition. My feeling and it is only that, is that subjective reality emerges from the objective rules. (See my previous musings about initial conditons for the type of process I mean.)
Thoughts can be objective even if actual observation cannot be absolutely so. If one draws up a set of rules to describe something that are consistent, such as those for chess or numbers between one and ten, this can be said to be truly objective even if they only exist in an abstract sense. Such notions can then be used to make guesses and predictions about the subjective world of actual experience. A sufficient (and what is sufficient is going to depend on context) correlation between the objective model and reality is what matters when determining the usefulness of a model.
It was the observations of successive generations of humans combined with those exploring purely abstract notions that has led to the current understanding and landmarks such as the Uncertainty Principle. Humans being humans though, struggle with this, we (well, me for one) aren't masters of subtlety, we like it simple, all objective or all subjective.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
When I finally got around to re-reading my last post,I wasn't entirely sure it made sense. Today I came across a paragraph in a Maths book that rather neatly sums up what I was trying to get at:

"To renounce the goal of comprehending the 'thing in itself', of knowing the 'ultimate truth', of unravelling the innermost essence of the world, may be a psychological hardship for naive enthusiasts, but in fact it was one of the most fruitful turns in modern thinking."

That was written by Richard Courant in 1941. My even simpler interpretation of it is to say that it is more useful to dwell on questions that can be answered and things that can be controlled, than on those which cannot. Of course determining what those things are is a problem in itself and is often far from obvious, but it is a reasonable principle nonetheless.

The turn of modern thinking that started this way of thinking and the minimisation of metaphysics, can probably be attributed to Galileo back in 1591. He was the first person to really pursue the idea of observations as a guide to understanding rather than just pure thought that the philosophers prefer.
Once you start down the road of observation led thinking, all sorts of things get ruled out, most famously in the twentieth century the idea of truly objective observation: the observer effects the object and that the observers position is relative, so the observations of one observer may differ from another observer of the same object. (It's now 100 years since Einstein first published his theories.)
These concepts have had all sorts of knock on effects into other areas of thinking and how we live. Ideas about Art and Society all got shaken up too. Out go ideas of a clock work universe and leaders with answers to all our problems and in come ideas of complexity and individuality and personal responsibility. Though most people seem to conveniently ignore that our actions always do have consequences.

I've been watching Art School on BBC2 this week (Evil TV I know!) and I've found it fascinating watching John Humphrey's. Like me, he's guilty of wanting nice simple answers and explanations for everything and is unable to just do it and accept all the happy mistakes and unexplainable aspects of why he likes or doesn't like something. He just seems constantly frustrated and it reminds me of my own experiences with Art. At the same time it looks so much like fun, proper self indulgence, and in the light of the quote above, as a naive enthusiast, it's got me thinking about doing something creative again myself. Maybe some painting or drawing. (I did make a fractal for this post if that counts!)

On the University front, I passed my resit and therefore the Foundation Year. In two weeks I begin the first year of my degree and I'll find out what Civil Engineering is really all about. For anyone that is interested you can download this excellent little leaflet: Civil Engineering PDF I've sent it to a few people before.

In the meantime, I'll put together some more music and get back to reading more books and watching some more films.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: On your recommendation I watched the omnibus edition. Interesting to see the high achieving bastion of radio 4 values acting like a teenage asbo-in-waiting because he didn't get it and couldn't see it's relevance...

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
"If you thought...science was certain - well, that is just an error on your part" Richard Feynman

This quote reminded me of something I've been frequently accused of - having an answer for everything.
The latest occurance of this accusation came at a time when I was considering that the quality of the answers one gets is directly related to the quality of the questions one asks. Or as it is more usually said, "Ask a silly question...."
Producing answers is a simple matter of logic but it doesn't

This quote appears in a lecture given in the 60s to explain what Physics is about and how it works as a method of investigation. The point (I feel) he was trying to make was that sticking one's neck out is what it is all about, but that this is done only from what is already providing a solid base from which to work.
For example, when I am studying and doing my exercises and my answers don't match with the answers provided: Is it more likely that I have made an error or that the theory I was working from is wrong? Logic suggests it is me at error, though there is the further possibilty of a typo in the answer sheet.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
A week before my resit and my self discipline is waning, so once again I have to remind myself what I'm doing here:

A large part of my adult life so far has been spent either participating in or bearing witness to the worst of human behaviour - violence, prejudice, narcissism, indifference. Engineering and Science are not magical solutions, but they point in the right direction, away from them. I'm well aware of the road to hell being paved with such good intentions: BSE or Thalidomide being prime examples. But I need a daily reminder that humans can aspire to and achieve better than I often experience first or second hand.

When I was a child I used to love and believe in the idea of magic. My favourite tape for long journeys in the car was of Greek Myths.
As I was reaching adulthood I thought that the magic could be found in Films and Art, and that guided my previous attempt at Further Education by going to Art College. What I found, as I began to look closer and closer at these things, was that they actually became less and less profound and magical. On top of which it felt more and more that the people employed to teach me were trying to convince me of how great the Emperors New Clothes were and I actually started to feel quite cheated and angry about it all. It all seemed bogus and empty.
Conversely, the more closely I have began to study science the more profound the answers become. It starts to reveal hidden connections and patterns that describe the shape of the world. It shocks me almost every time I learn something new or see some new connection that I'd never noticed before.
Funnily enough, it's also given me some context in which to start appreciating the Arts again. Now I don't look too closely and attempt to fruitlessly analyse something subjective. These things (books, paintings, films etc.) appear to me as pieces of mirror. Each piece reflecting both something of the creator and something of me when I look into it. The trick for me being, not to look too hard and long, lest I do become lost like narcissus. As a result, some of their magic has returned.

I've always found a tension between my hatred of false divisions and the human need to categorise things to make sense of them. Which is another surprising aspect of the science project, the home of reductionism, is how it also seeks to unite disparate aspects of reality. Art in the context of reality as a whole becomes more understandable, than seen as a separate reality. (Maybe I'm pointing out the bleedin' obvious again, but I'm a slow thinker and often get the wrong end of the stick.)

The first words I heard on the Radio when I woke up today was, "...we're preparing to go to Mars when 80% of humanity is still in the mud and the blood." They've stayed with me. And while I doubt I can produce some marvel of personal expression that an Artist might, I probably can go some way towards solving a science/engineering problem that'll be a tiny step out of the mud and blood.

I don't know if I like the idea of magic cos I'm lazy and that it offers a short cut to solutions or solutions to impossible problems. Maybe it's also the warmth it provides against the coldness of reality, but I'm pretty sure the only magic I'm likely to find is in a book, on a screen, in a gallery or on a CD. But that's no bad thing.

I realise I've never actually said what the magic is, but it'll be different for everyone, so you'll have to fill in the meaning yourselves.

Now it's time to study again.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: "..either participating in or bearing witness to the worst of human behaviour - violence, prejudice, narcissism, indifference .. " blimey! .. I don't think I was at that party.
When I read your newest dispatch, my brain could not find the logic on what I was doing any more. Thanks for reminding me that sometimes it is better not to put that much attention to things. =)
I've said it before and I'll say it again: You think too much. Anja x

"The most beautiful experience we can have is the mysterious. It is the fundamental emotion that stands at the cradle of true art and true science. Whoever does not know it and can no longer wonder, no longer marvel, is as good as dead, and his eyes are dimmed." - Albert Einstein

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
One of the good things about summer is the chance to bunker down with lots of books. The selection I am currently reading has given me plenty to think about, both in terms of what I do and how the world is.
One of the simplest questions in life is, "What is it for?" or even "Why is it that way?"
Why buy those clothes, choose that record, study that subject, take that job etc. ? What is the point?

I've come to realise that the answer to this is not something static and imovable, it's a qualitative answer. That is to say it changes and is not an absolute for all times, places and people.

In itself this may not be an amazing insight, but what has surprised me is that it is an understanding I've come to through reading about and studying Maths, the subject probably most associated in most peoples minds with absolutes and quantification. In his excellent book Ian Stewart describes how from mathematical (and therefore also physical) laws arise dynamic processes and that the dynamic processes also give rise to laws and therefore the futility of adopting a position of either reality is all objective or all subjective.
What this led me to think was, why do people adopt such positions? What are they for?  It seems that to me humans are often concerned with being right, when the question and answer may well be absurd to begin with.
Another description Ian Stewart wrote is that an Artist seeks to express their experiences of the world, while an Engineer seeks to change it, an Entrepreneur seeks to exploit it, a Scientist seeks to understand how it really works and finally a Mathematican seeks generalities that cut across the obvious subdivisions. While I have become drawn into Engineering, I feel that each of these things exist inside me to some extent and probably inside everyone else too.

One correspondent told me how she feels at peace after physical training.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Here's the moral right at the start: "Chance favours the prepared mind." Pat Cadigan

When I woke up at 7 am on the day of my holiday, it occurred to me that I ought to get some insurance, so I tapped away at my keyboard for a few minutes at got a policy shortly before leaving the house to catch my bus. It was a fresh sunny day in Southampton and the bus turned up promptly and took me to the railway station. This was when my troubles began.

Looking up at the board, I could see my train to the airport had been cancelled, so I went over to ask what was going on. Two people had thrown themselves onto the track at Chichester and all trains on the route were suspended. I began to wonder if this might mean me missing my plane to Sardinia. The helpful staff printed me off a new route that needed three trains, but would get me there on time and I rushed to jump on the first train.

Three trains and a lot of humping my bags about later, I arrived at Gatwick with about half an hour before check in closed. The queues were enormous and after about 25 minutes the man pulled me out of the queue and checked me in as the very last passenger for my flight. I ran to the gate and jumped on the bus meeting P, J and T.

And we waited. And then we waited some more. After about 10 minutes we then drove to the plane, going all over the place before getting aboard. And we waited some more. Sitting on the runway for about an hour. There had been a spillage on the main runway and they need to bring some more luggage to the plane, so everything was delayed. The cabin crew decided to play a quiz to entertain us and myself and the five year old girl next to me along with her Mother teamed up to win second prize! A big bag of Maltesers, which cheered us up immensely.

Two hours flying later, at passport control, I commented to P & J, that I thought we'd had all our bad luck last year during our calamitous Belgian holiday. How wrong could I be? After standing in an empty hall for about 20 minutes, watching an empty black conveyor belt go around and around, it dawned on us that our luggage wasn't arriving too. Nor was that of the ten other angry people crowding around the lost luggage desk. Easyjet weren't answering the phone.

Nothing to do but leave our details and get the car. We were already late and hot and now without luggage, so we drove down the coast to a beautiful stretch near the island of Tavolara. The first campsite had no room, but we got lucky at the second, where a nice gay man rented us his boyfriends caravan. As you can see it was a bit of a squeeze, but it was all we needed to survive. Pizza, red wine, bed.

The following morning, we got up to our first proper day on holiday. Grumpy and hot. This was soon tempered by the most beautiful little beach overlooking the island. Cobalt sky, white sand and turquoise sea. Swimming in the sea it was as if everything was perfect.
Sadly, a trip to the airport confirmed that my luggage was still missing and it was to be another night in the caravan with no clean clothes for me.

Having abandoned all hope of seeing our belongings again, a large part of day three was spent shopping for tents and clothes. I was glad of my insurance now. Mid-afternoon, just as I was looking for a sleeping bag, of course, the call came through that my luggage had arrived. After another trip to the airport, we zoomed up the coast to a new campsite, making camp shortly before dark. One final minor crisis occurred before the end of the day, when we couldn't get into the restaurant as we were too late by ten minutes. Take away pizza and beer saw out our third holiday day.

Day four and finally we started a day properly. Clean clothes, hot cappuccino, pasties choccolito and baking heat. We were on holiday! Swimming in the sea, driving through the mountains, eating pasta, drinking red wine. I could feel the tension releasing from my shoulders. We got the map out and planned our trip South west to the other coast for the following day.

There's a line from a Godfather film used in a Sopranos episode, "I thought I was out. And they pulled me back in." This is pretty much how I felt when the car keys got locked in the boot the following evening! I was running out of ideas about what else could go wrong. Me, J & T went to the beach, while P spent most of the next day getting that little disaster sorted out.

Fortunately it was a proper holiday after that. We had three trouble free days. I got over my aversion to sandals and strolled about Sardinia in them all week, very comfortably. The sea was amazing. During our final swim together, J & me swam with schools of fish and even a Ray, over some rocks in shallow water. We visited Roman ruins and prehistoric sites and then a museum to get some context about what we had seen. We had great food everywhere pizza and pasta and some tremendous ice cream from small Gelaterias. On my last night, we promenaded among the stylish Italians, not quite as obviously English thanks to the sun.

Yesterday, I left P J & T at the airport as they headed back off for another week exploring the rest of the island. It was a beautiful and friendly island and I hope to go back sometime. (You can see more of my photos in the photo album on the right.)

Now I'm back in Southy preparing for my Physics resit in 3 weeks time. I passed all my other exams and achieved the course average required to pass,  (I astonished myself by getting 100% in my final piece of coursework) but this one component, my Mechanics exam, I failed and need to retake to progress.

Back to the books.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Picking up from where I left off with my last dispatch, it's time for some proper neurosis:

I've come to the conclusion that I'm one of the world's bigger narcissists and one of the worse ways this manifests is in the suspicion that people are out to trick me (including my own brain) and that some terrible events will unfold as a result. I'm not entirely sure how it has arisen but I realised today that I am primed to look for deliberate deceit everywhere and it's not good, cos actually there usually isn't any going on.
There is even my suspicion of an inner psychopath who's unseen hand is guiding my actions in the outer world according to some dastardly, yet unknown plan. The desire to see myself at the centre of events and the battle with my rational thoughts that this pivotal role in life's events is rather unlikely, seems unending. I see meaning everywhere and often multiple meanings which leaves me tongue tied and reluctant to participate in life at large. It's so much easier to stay home wrapped up safely in the narrative structures of a book about lives much more interesting than my own. More often than not a cigar is just cigar, but how does one know without taking a risk?
And how do I know that what I think or what I say is really what I think? Often when I review my thoughts and actions I realise it was just some base motive such greed, anger or jealousy that led to that decision branch when it all felt so rational at the time. Is this how killers feel after the act?
Other manifestations of narcissism occur in my daily fight between my attempts to be kind to my fellow humans and wanting to tell them to get the hell out of the way when they are blocking my path on the pavement. As though these seconds and metres spent navigating around them are somehow vital to me, that I am somehow special and deserving of that space, when they and I are in fact trivial and others behaviour is just natural. (There are many similar situations, please feel free to add your own to the comments section!)

I know, I know, I think too much and if I was busier maybe I'd be thinking about something else. Perhaps the rest of you never have these thoughts or are just too smart to share them, but they are like picking at a scab to me, much to hard to resist even if it ends up with blood everywhere.
This is one reason I take comfort in Maths, it can be very calming to do something with clear rules and structure and prove outcomes that are as true and unambiguous as it is possible to be. Even uncertainty and incompleteness can be understood and quantified in Maths in a way that I find impossible in the fuzziness of words and humanity.

So is narcissism so bad? Yes, I think so. It leads to all these good intentions that are paving the road to hell. All that time spent looking in the mirror is time away from what is around us and creates a false sense of reality. False premises for action led to.....well, you should be able to fill the sentence yourself cos the world is full of the consequences both personal and global.
I'm not saying introspection isn't useful, it's what I'm doing now and it makes me feel better (and stupid at the same time) but I don't know if it is possible to have a good sense of oneself and everything else at same time, maybe all my readers possess this holy grail!

I guess this all boils down to a big whinge about feeling certainty and the freedom I imagine that brings - I fear the Certain, like the Pope or George Bushes and of the world - but I envy them too, as they appear to feel free to live life fully uninhibited by uncertainty and a fear of the outcomes of their choices. This may be a different kind of narcissism, one where one is convinced one is right regardless of evidence, but it's a more appealing version!

The only cure for all this is get out amongst the people again, take the risk of interaction, make a few mistakes etc. Aversion therapy to get my tolerance levels back up after a week of solitude. I may never be comfortable amongst my fellow humans but they aren't going to go away and it doesn't look like I'll be able to become a machine any time soon.

Thank you for your attention, my unseen therapists, I hope to have at least provided a few laughs.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You need a holiday Al.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
I've been having a few angry days, culminating in the conclusion that I no longer wish to be human being, I would rather be a machine, emotionless and sexless. The final straw came when I couldn't solve a physics problem on Thursday and I felt like smashing everything in my room. Being human seems to be the primary cause of unhappiness. Eliminate that and the problem is sorted. Or does that sound too much like a serial killer!?

If one is a man, there are the present social advantages of power, but the problem of having to behave like a fool or brute in order to compete for a mate. If one is a woman, one is at an advantage in the mating game, by getting to do the choosing, but at a disadvantage at present in a lot of social situations, such as pay and jobs.

So neither seem like desirable conditions for life, especially when the result of all this seems to be finding new and innovative ways to hurt one another physically and emotionally. And personally, I particularly dislike all the emotions that come with this condition and the lack of an off switch. It's rubbish and I'm fed up.

The picture at the top is of the fundamental theorem of calculus. This is the general form for explaining how one variable changes with respect to another. This theorem is now one of my best friends and I'm sure we'll be spending a lot of time together in the future. It is so important because it is at the base of a whole class of problem called initial conditions problems. These occur all the time in engineering and physics.
One of the paradoxes of science is the impression that it can provide reduced, condensed answers to questions such as "Does MMR give a child autism?" In fact a lot of questions can only be answered if you have an accurate picture of the situation at the time of looking, as this will influence the answer you get, and in trying to understand how one thing changes as another does.
The classic example is the weather. The reason forecasts are so unreliable is that in order to accurately predict the future, everything (and I really mean everything) needs to be considered at the time of the forecast and how these variables will change and interact over the time of your forecast.
Another one you may be familiar with from school is the story about time travellers accidentally killing a butterfly in the past and changing the present. By killing the butterfly they had altered the initial conditions of that moment and subsequently changed what came after.
This is the basis of chaos theory. The word chaos is misleading as it implies things are completely random, when usually they are just very complicated - and there is a difference! Complex things can be understood, random things cannot.
So does MMR give a child autism? Well, what are all the variables that can cause autism and how do they interact? and how does MMR interact with the processes of a growing human? and what situation is the child in when the vaccine is to be administered?
As you can imagine it's hard if not impossible to get a simple answer and one that is general for all time and all people. So science isn't really reductionist in the sense most people think, because the questions cannot be framed in such a way to give really simple answers a lot of the time.

One problem I find with theories in other subjects is that they don't seem to think in this way. By not taking into account how everything can change from moment to moment according to underlying processes, they become snapshots of a moment rather than something explanatory about a greater process. It seems to me why politics and economics fail so badly as theories, their lack of consideration of change and the interactions between the parts that make up the world over time.

What has all this got to do with me be angry and wanting to be a machine?

Well, we are all variables (hence the title of my blog) and we all interact and change with respect to one another too and change each other in the process. And to be honest I find the complexity of it all overwhelming and demoralising a lot of the time. The lack of control, feeling helpless leading to anger etc. etc. These are not good feelings.
Humans are mostly conservative at heart, we like routine and structure, not change and complexity. Yet we get bored so easily if things don't change. Where is the balance?! Not at a fixed point either as far as I can tell and hence the fundmental theorem of calculus. We are caught in a function changing with time throughout our lives, over which we have influence but also influences us. Makes me angry cos I feel trapped and I don't have as much influence as I'd like. It's the same as being five years old and discovering life isn't fair, it STILL sucks! Machines don't have this problem, so I'd like to be in their gang.

Some days, I solve stuff and understand it and it feels good, but I can't help wondering if it'd be better not to feel at all. It's funny to me that most people have an instinctive understanding of the algebra of everyday life, but for me it's just as hard as my course.

I'm a week away from the end of my studies this year and I was thinking about what has changed the other day. My conclusion, is that I now ask better questions than eight months ago. It's a cycle, I ask a question - get an answer which raises new questions and round I go again. A process of refinement like polishing the surface of a stone, little by little it gets smoother and the pattern is revealed.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's been a whole month since my classes ended and when we start again on Monday there will be just seven weeks until the exams which end the course.
I've been a bit short of cash, so I haven't been up to a whole lot. Mainly coming up with excuses not to study!
The results of  the few occasions when I have been out can be viewed in the photo album on the right. I've become a little obsessed with Tree Shape photographs, but I thought with it now being spring, a picture of my tomato seedlings which popped through yesterday, would be more appropriate than bleak silhouettes.

So I've slowly been getting my allotment into shape, pictures to come next time, taking me three hours to dig a nine metre by one metre trench. It made me remember just how hard digging is and pity the poor soldiers in World War One for that alone. Potatoes, carrots and onions are in so far, but I've still got about two thirds of the plot to dig over so it'll take some time to sort out.

I've also had plenty of time to read and if there is only one book you read this year, I implore you to read "How Mumbo Jumbo Conquered the World" by Francis Wheen. (There's a link to Amazon on the right.) As good a polemic as The Female Eunuch, it gives a blistering critique of inductive reasoning and the susceptibility of one and all to personal or collective delusions in the face of evidence. It's also a promotion of Enlightment ideas: of human rights, rationalism and empiricism
Pretty much everyone from the last 200 years gets a kicking left, right and centre. From free marketeers, to X files fans, to Noam Chomsky. And even though he's chastising us, he actually made me laugh, if some what bleakly with gems such as, "...people use the word "guru" only because "charlatan" is too long." or recalling books such as "Make It So: Management Lessons from Star Trek The Next Generation". Or how about Alan Sokals rebuke to cultural relativists, "Fair enough:anyone who believes that the laws of physics are mere social conventions is invited to try transgressing those conventions from the window of my apartment. I live on the twenty first floor."
As someone who has believed all sorts of nonsense in my time, as well as being an enjoyable read, it was a reminder of the dangers of wishful thinking. That wanting something to be true isn't enough to make it true and that the continued repetition of a fallacy can lead to terrible consequences on both personal and global levels.

You may find much of it offensive or disagreeable, but it should give you food for thought about your own beliefs.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's been a tough six weeks or so since the start of Semester Two and the End of Semester One and my first big hurdle, the Maths A exam. I scraped in with a pass, but like a driving test, a pass is a pass and that is the most important thing.

The general saying here is that to pass this Foundation year is the same as doing three A-levels in a year and getting grade A in all of them, as that is the entry requirement for the science and engineering degrees at Southampton.

The last few weeks has raised quite a few doubts in my mind about what I am doing here. Partly because it is very hard and partly because I have a much better idea of what academic life is really about and what the next few years is likely to be like.

The real thing we are being taught here is to think in a particular way. A logical scientific way, and I find it incredibly difficult sometimes and I'm even unsure of whether I like it sometimes too. There is a certain relentlessness to the learning here as well, every week another test and new set of arguments to absorb.

One of our tutors talked about the difference between learning by rote, facts and formulas and real problem solving. He said a real life problem is something one often has no idea how to approach at the start and one has to find a way (or give up!) What they are trying to instil in us are the necessary thinking skills to approach any problem that science has developed over centuries.

The reason they can be so hard to obtain, is that they often are not intuitive and require conceptual leaps that are difficult to adjust to. This reason is also why science/engineering graduates can obtain well paid jobs, often in unrelated areas, as they should be good problem solvers regardless of field.

This semester we have been learning about: how things rotate and move and collide – for example I learnt how to describe the way the Earth behaves, due to forces of momentum, mathematically in terms of vectors. I've been learning how waves behave and how electricity acts as a field.

All things that may seem quite baffling at first glance and although the explanations follow step upon step of logical deduction a la Sherlock Holmes, it is like being in a totally dark room and trying to understand what it look likes.

When I watch a tutor so fluidly explain some phenomena from simple Mathematical principles into something complex step by step, such as our Mechanics tutor explaining planetary motion this week, it does produce a sense of awe in me and a sense that I am witnessing natures' true form. But when I'm presented with a problem to solve and twenty minutes to do it, despair is more common!

It is both inspiring and daunting to be shown how much there is to learn, even just to get started on this journey and I find myself wondering if I am capable of travelling that path or how far I'll be able to go. It is a privilege in my eyes to have the opportunity to try, but I wouldn't describe myself as enjoying it at present and despite often being told I have potential, I am a long way from showing results on that supposed potential.

I haven't really had time for much else but studying and I'm feeling the financial pinch after six months, so that probably hasn't helped.

With spring on the way, in the absence of a garden, I am planning to get an allotment! I decided I needed an outdoor space to grow some vegetables and flowers and just somewhere to sit and read outside. So hopefully I'll have some pictures of that to come and maybe I'll eventually look like the man in the top left picture.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Although the University is quite nice, Southampton itself is by far the ugliest place I have ever lived! So it's difficult to come up with any pictures that show it in a good light.

Instead, I'm posting a picture from our Boxing day walk by the sea in Devon. The light was amazing, with the sun low and golden. This was at about 2pm, about 13 hours after the Tsunami in Asia, but before I knew about it, which gives the picture of a velvety sea in Devon an odd frame of reference time wise.

The other picture is of my first computer, which I built in our Electronics class two weeks ago. I was very proud of it. It could count to 4! (We connected two together so it could count to 8.) Described simply, by controlling the flow of electricity through the circuit (all those bits of wire and the coloured lumps) the green and red lights can be made to switch on and off to represent binary (one or zero) numbers.
This in itself may not seem very exciting, but essentially the same process, scaled by many orders of magnitude, is what is allowing you to read this message or your washing machine to work or anything that uses a computer to function.
I always find something magical in actually making a theory (Boolean logic & electricity) into something that actually works from inert parts, which is I guess why I like engineering, so this was a very satisfying experiment. A real example of how complexity can arise from simplicity.
The history of Electricity is another hidden and very interesting history in itself, as it has had profound effects of the shape of our society, and yet has only been a part of everyday life since the 1920's when the National Grid was installed.

Going back to my opening remark, the reason for Southampton being so horrible, is really down to World War 2. It was the second most bombed place in the country and was only two raids away from being abandoned and the city relocated elsewhere! The postwar reconstruction has been a really awful mixture of bad concrete and red brick laid around the few Victorian remains, which has recently begun to be replaced with functional but anodyne late 20th century design. The overall effect is one of a complete lack of identity or continuity in it's layout. They should really knock it all down and start again with some decent architects!

On the course we've just started Semester 2, having had a nasty 3 hour Maths exam to end Semester 1 last week. I do not feel at all confident about passing, but have to wait a couple of weeks before I find out. I'm still too slow.

This Semester will be all about Calculus, which for the uninitiated is all about understanding change. How one thing changes with respect to another, often how a very small change in one thing can lead to a large change in something else. A simple example being how the speed of your car (on the speedometer) describes the change in space (along the road) with respect to time. So a measure of 50 mph describes a faster change than 30 mph.
Like all Maths, it's much less frightening in reality than it sounds. In the fact the whole reason behind the science project is to make things easier to understand and if they aren't that is a failing of science not an intention. Given we live in a world where things are constantly changing, this is a fundamental process in describing all aspects of the world.

Also I have to write another computer programme. This time a group project, in which my colleagues have elected to write a program that allows the user to calculate the flight of a projectile. Sounds worryingly like a military programme! But it's all physics! (I wanted to write a program to help me calculate how fast I could ride my motorbike around a bend, but sadly it was a bit too complicated....)

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's the end of term tomorrow and it's been 12 weeks since I started at University and I'm really worn out.

After some interesting responses to my last dispatch, my original plans for this email were to pick up where I left off and write about things such as how engineering demonstrates the use of machines to solve problems once believed to only be understandable via intellectual (philosophical) means. Or how the kind of science and engineering done is biased simply by the lack of balance between the sexes amongst scientists and engineers i.e. it's nearly all men.
It was going to be the empiricist strikes back, but I'm too tired to string logical arguments together, so it's just a collection of trivia and general babble instead:

Trivial fact number one: The first fibre optic cable was invented at Southampton University. The backbone of modern communications, invented here. This email doubtless passed through some on it's way to you.
Trivial fact two: Tim Berners Lee, the inventor of the World Wide Web has just joined Southampton University Computer Science department.
And fact number three, just for my former colleagues: Finsbury Square (home of Bloomberg TV) was the original site for the Bedlam Lunatic Asylum designed by Robert Hooke, inventor of the microscope amongst other things. That last fact won't mean much to anyone who doesn't work in TV, but I thought it  a suitably ironic location for Bloomberg.

So after twelve weeks of learning, I've been starting to worry about all the things I don't know. It's as if for every question addressed, 100 more spring up to be answered and it's overwhelming sometimes. When I put this to my Physics tutor, he said the nicest thing that's been said to me since being here: in his experience the best scientists are the ones who worry about what they don't understand. It's the ones who don't worry he worries about!
That made me feel a whole lot better.

The subjects we've been covering this term are: Maths, Mechanics, Thermodynamics, Electricity & Electronics and Computer Applications.
Maths is the language of reality. It's aim is to describe things, as I wrote about last time. I love the way it is true in a way that nothing else in life can be, but it really winds me up when I can't grasp it. And like any language, it's all about practise, there's no other way, which a lot of people find dull.
Mechanics & Thermodynamics are more straightforward, as parts of it are quite intuitive. Mechanics is really about how things move and interact with each other, thermodynamics being about the behaviour of heat. Most stuff moves and gets hot, so it covers a lot of stuff!
Electricity & Electronics is conceptually as hard as Maths as it is about something that we see the effects of, but can't be seen or touched directly. So we've been learning the fundamentals of how the things we all use work, such as the computer you are reading this on, so that I could actually get some lumps of metal and design and build stuff with enough understanding.

My tutor said a couple of weeks ago, "...a theory is a logical deduction based upon a set of assumptions. Therefore a theory cannot be proved or disproved." But it can be tested with experiments to test it's reliability. The purpose of these areas of study is to make logical deductions that then allow you to do things like build a computer, because of their accuracy. It's useful to think about the historical context to all these things: A lot of what I am learning are things people deduced hundreds or even thousands of years ago and are still considered reliable today. Which is remarkable, if you consider science is like trying to describe the contents of a room you've never seen while wearing a blindfold and boxing gloves. So what I'm learning in these subjects, is the distilled knowledge of many years of scientific research and of those researching today, who will provide the ideas that give us the new technologies that we can use or abuse as we wish.

Computer Applications has two purposes, to teach us how to use computers better: I have to write my first programme over Xmas. And to teach us how to present our ideas. The second point makes me feel more optimistic about the future of science and engineering. The coming generations of scientists and engineers will hopefully be as adept at communicating their ideas as anyone else, and this will I hope go some way to changing the general perceptions around science. However, my pessimistic side feels that the world is just becoming increasingly narcissistic and is more interested in subjective experience than objective reality. Indeed, my interpretation of the Universe science presents is quite a melancholy view: a universe where there is no special meaning to it all or any real significance to a life beyond evolutionary pressures, so I can see that these theories may not sit well with most people.

I've been to look around the Physics and Maths departments, with a view to changing my degree. Maths is most appealing, partly because the Mathematicians are the nicest people! and partly as it is the only really satisfying subject as regards proof. But I don't think I'm really smart enough to do a whole four years of mental gymnastics. By the way, trivial fact number four is that Maths Graduates have the best employment statistics of all graduates, the argument being that if you can do Maths you can do pretty much anything, but I reckon it's just cos they compile the statistics. I'll let you decide....
Also, I'm not sure it really is the best use of the approx 2100 weeks I have left to live, when I could be discovering how to supply the whole world with clean water in Civil Engineering or something equally useful. (Not that it really matters according to my previous statement.)

The only decent photo opportunity recently I was without my camera. It was about two weeks ago at about 4 o'clock, when I was outside and looked up into a darkening bruise blue sky as amber sunlight was just colouring the top of the Law Building. It was as if the daylight was clinging onto the building against the too soon coming night. And would have been a great picture.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's now the start of week 6 here and there isn't much new to see, so I'm only sending one photo of the autumn colours that are around as winter approaches on the rare occasions when it isn't raining here.

Instead I thought I'd write a (rather long) summary of the last few hectic weeks on the chance that people are interested in what I am actually doing at University:

Essentially this year is a foundation year in Maths & Physics. But time also spent on learning how to learn, a much underestimated skill and probably the hardest adjustment to make. So as well as all the lectures and workshops on Maths, we learn about strategies to absorb all the information and skills on presenting information, such as how to write a formal report using Excel & Word and how to do a presentation with Power-point. This is quite an interesting area in it's own right because even in just writing this email it is difficult to convey information in a clear manner, so for graduates seeking work or presenting their research this is important skill to have and I've found it surprising how difficult it can be to do.

Which links nicely to writing about science, as it has suffered a lot, in my opinion, from a poor ability to present itself as to what it is and as worthwhile subject to the population at large. I get the impression most people either don't see it's relevance to them or consider it the tool of evil capitalists to make the world a bad place.

To start thinking about science, here's a gem one of my lecturers came out with the other day, "Definitions are the only things that can be said to be true. Everything else is just theory. And definitions are only true because we say so!"

A kilogramme, a metre, a mile, are all just definitions that we as humans have agreed upon because it is useful for us to do so. So what about everything else? Living now, at this end of history, we reap the rewards (and pitfalls) of all the humans that have come before us and the best inheritance they have given us is the results of their investigations. The people that asked why and how over and over, probably driving their parents insane at the time, all of their results combined and checked and repeated and described are what makes our world the way it is today. Ten years ago I'd never sent an email, but now thanks to scientists and engineers that are still alive and all those that have gone before I can write to as many people as I wish at once.
The reason I italicised the words "investigation" and "described" is that is essentially what science boils down to. We investigate things with a view to describing them. However, going back to human history, we've evolved languages to describe our everyday experience as social animals, so we needed to invent a way of describing things that we don't experience directly in our lives and to describe things in a universal way. Or to put it another way, to describe abstract concepts and produce a systematic form of representation. Analogies are very useful things, but unfortunately there comes a point where it just doesn't work to say "It's like..." and if the language to describe the thing itself doesn't exist, then we must invent it. Which is why we invented Maths.
So if you aren't bored already, the point of all this is to give some sense of where science comes from and then hopefully bring a further sense of why it is relevant to everyone. I hope this is all not too obvious and patronising.

We all do investigations and we all describe things all the time, whether it's finding the best bargain or telling someone why you think a painting is great.
For scientists and engineers we had to develop a systematic way of doing this, because if we hadn't it would be impossible to interpret someone's work or build a car and be confident it wouldn't explode as soon as it is started.
So learning Maths is really learning a language, but it is a language that can describe the physical universe and everything in it. Us included. And because we're trying to describe something we are part of, it requires a lot conceptual thinking, which is pretty tricky for a hairy ape that's really better at hunting and gathering than thinking. However to have a language that can be used to describe everything is a very powerful tool for solving all sorts of problems.
For example the Head of our course is an Acoustic Engineer. Her research into acoustics is with an aim to developing a way of diagnosing bronchitis by listening to the sounds produced in the chest. This would be used to create a device for use in Refugee Camps for triage purposes without needing a doctor present, and ultimately save lives by preventing the disease spreading.

Maths, Physics and Engineering really are the basis of modern life as we experience it today. Everything thing we have and take for granted from communications (just the ability to share an idea globally), to health and sanitation could not have come into existence or be maintained without it.
So what I am learning on a day to day basis are the core components of the language needed to understand the physical world. So we a lot of time spent practising solving equations and learning what patterns have been spotted and developed into theories that describe the universe, such the properties of energy or matter. Also we learn where the limits of current knowledge are.
It isn't a moral framework and it isn't a project that is ever likely to end and it is impossible for any individual to know in detail more than a small fraction of the whole, but because it is so powerful, it is in everyone's interest to have some understanding of science. It can be used or abused in all areas of human life.

It is really hard work too! We study for 40 hours week in total and I'm exhausted at the end of most days from having to think so hard.
Nominally, I have been accepted to go forward to study Civil and Environmental Engineering, as I think there are a lot of interesting problems to work on involving the environment we live in, but I have the possibility to change to any other area if I pass the course. To do that I have to get at least 60% in all exams and course work.

That's enough I think and I hope it hasn't been too dull, but I couldn't think of how to explain things without some context. I'll try for more pictures and less words next time.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's Thursday & I only finished unpacking last night. So it's taken me a while to getting round to sending an email to say thank-you to everyone for such a great send off last week. I enjoyed myself thoroughly.

Needless to say it's a bit of a culture shock arriving here. I started moving on Sunday, but didn't finish until Monday night. Since then it has been endless rounds of phone calls, emails and bureaucracy to get everything sorted out, I even have a lock-up for my Motorbike, just like Arthur Daley.
I've yet to get a timetable, but I finally met my fellow students today and they are just what you'd expect: a few Kurt Cobain T-shirts, lots of silly hair, 19-year old boys with really bad beards and even one young man in a big trilby hat. Nice to see someone cutting their own fashion path in the world, but I won't be following him. I only spotted about half a dozen women out of nearly a hundred, so I guess engineering, Maths and Physics is stills a boys world.

My studio flat is really nice, but it is small. The picture of the Gower from outside looks best, my flat is on the end, the first two bits sticking out.

The campus is really nice too, lots of trees and plants and sculptures dotted about like I've included here. There's a gallery and theatre too as well as top notch sporting facilities for 50 quid a year all in. I'm ashamed to say I haven't made it too the Student Union bar yet, so I can't report on the price of the beer.

Anyway, next week I start studying for real and actually I'm looking forward to that as it's all been a bit stressful and boring moving house and enrolling. Bring on the calculus! I
shall send another dispatch soon....

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Four years and 20,000 pounds later, I now have a BEng in Civil Engineering with First Class Honours. I got my results for the year today and they are as follows:

Geotechnical Engineering 76%
Structural Analysis 71%
Hydrology & Water Resources Engineering 59%
Design Project 73%
Hydraulic Engineering 92%
Individual Project 74%
Engineering Project Management 77%

Which is an average of 75% for the year, having dipped down to 69% back in Febraury.

I might write at a later time saying what I think about all this, but I don’t really know what to say right now, except that if you have children or are planning to, start saving now.

I was trying to think of a way to illustrate some of what I’ve been doing in all this time, other than these posts I’ve written. My report for my individual project can be downloaded here (3Mb PDF). It’s not light reading, but the abstract and introduction should be accessible to everyone as an example of degree level engineering work – there are still a couple of typos in the equations. And lest it seem too esoteric, the wider context is that one consequence of understanding the kind of problem in this project is that it influences the cost of oil extraction and ultimately fuel prices, a subject close to many people’s wallets. Whether we should be extracting the oil at all is another matter...

The next step could be Plans A, B, C or D. Plans A and B are both PhDs: One being the computer modelling of irrigation systems I wrote about in my last dispatch, the second being a bit of a change of direction. It’s also computer modelling, but the design and simulation of biological systems, specifically the human immune system as a guide to future experimentation relating to cancer research. This arose out of a conversation in the pub with a member of the swimming club who is looking for a student to take this on. I’m going for an interview on Tuesday and it may be a bridge too far in terms of transferable skills, but the money is in place and it answers two of my fundamental questions – is it interesting? And is it useful? So it’s not impossible that I’ll end up with a PhD in Medical Science, which kind of makes sense in my crooked life.

Plans C & D involve either getting a job or fulfilling my ultimate fantasy of divesting myself of all my possessions and finding some way to step outside the system that doesn’t involve becoming a hippy and believing in nonsense.

After I finished my last bit of studying I went camping in Folkestone for the weekend which coincided with the opening of the Folkestone Triennial. This event it turns out is largely down to Roger De Haan, local resident and heir to the Saga empire and who is obviously a keen art lover, judging from the amount of Art-based urban regeneration on display and the line-up of Artists taking part. It’s all outdoors installations and if the weather's good, it’s worth a day exploring the town to see them – I enjoyed it anyway. The camp site was overlooking the beach and we could clearly see France twinkling in the distance at night. With the sound of the waves and the moon reflecting on the water, who’d have thought Folkestone could be so romantic? The picture above is of the Beach Huts made from a Pitch and Putt Golf Course. I’ve grown to love concrete more and more over the last four years and that’s one parallel I can make between engineering and art, the more one understands what one is looking at, the better the appreciation of its relative merits and faults. I definitely see the world in a different way now that I know a little of what all this everyday stuff that makes up my environment is and how it works. There are some more pictures in the scrapbook.

Recently read, viewed, listened to and appreciated:

Air – Geoff Ryman. I really liked this speculation about the effects of technology on poor communities, as one reviewer has said this is the sort of book that shouldn’t be seen as genre fiction and deserves to be promoted up with whatever people are calling literature these days.

The Left Hand of Darkness – Ursula Le Guin. Likewise, I can’t believe how much of a latecomer I am to the work of Ursula Le Guin. She blows me away with her writing and if Doris Lessing can get a Nobel Prize then she deserves one too. It must be the awful covers that put people off. It took me a while to get going with this as she throws the reader into an alien world with no preparation so that we experience the alienness of the place and alienation of the narrator who is also alien in this world. She is such a human writer, by which I mean that she takes time to explain and understand the motivations of all the characters for good or bad rather than writing in archetypes or stereotypes.

Victory Conditions – Elizabeth Moon. The final book in this space-war series, which have been great fun and easy reading as she writes in a very straightforward way, yet linger in my mind as they have been all about members of a family of strong women and told from their relative points of view. So there’s lots of stuff about female attitudes to violence and the struggles to be taken seriously in their society, but like the Wire, one never feels like one is being preached to and it adds to the drama rather than subtracts from it.

Northline – Willy Vlautin. Neil gave me this one for my birthday and it comes with a soundtrack CD. Which I have to say works really well as another dimension to the book when I had it on while reading. A sad, tragic tale with a little bit of light at the end of the tunnel about Allison Johnson and her life in contemporary North America.

The Red Men – Matthew de Abaitua. A dystopian London novel, which was really good for the first two thirds, but then never really seemed to go anywhere for me. He’s a funny and talented writer though and it was entertaining to read about places I know well filtered through his near future visions of life in the UK.

I’ve had so much new music to listen to over the last couple of months, I’ll just make a couple of honourable mentions here that have been getting a lot of play recently and the rest can go in the side bar.

The Midnight Organ Fight – Frightened Rabbit

The Evangelist - Robert Forster

TV has been a dead zone with the exception of the transmission of The Best of Youth on BBC Four which I’ve wanted to see for some time. A tremendous six hour Italian epic about the life of one family over forty years, split into four parts for TV. Despite being a little bit soap opera on occasions and subject to the necessary plot contrivances that stretch the suspension of disbelief, the characterisation was so good it was very moving, funny and life affirming and taught me more about the recent history of a society of which I’m largely ignorant. Track it down if you can, once you get into it I guarantee you’ll want to watch it all the way through.

I’ve also been onto series 4 of The Wire on DVD, excellent as ever, this series is focused on the educational and political systems.

So that's it for now, maybe I'll have a proper rant when it finally feels real and I know what I feel about it all. And when I know what happens next.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Bodge Many congratulations on the 1st. Well deserved. What amazes me is that you managed to fit in so many books and albums at the same time! See you sometime, I'm sure. Coop
Hey Al, Many Many congratulations on a great achievement. Wow...... Bestest Sanjiv
CONGRATULATIONS! Well deserved! Phil + Jenny + Thea

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday after 10 weeks of training I ran what turned out to be my first race in years, a 10km (6.22 miles) run around the Bay in Bournemouth. I initially thought I'd just signed up for a charity run, but it turned out to be a proper race. Fortunately the weather came good and it was a beautiful spring day to run beside the sea. The only hiccup being the last minute discovery that public transport here doesn't start early enough on a Sunday to get me the 30 miles from Southampton to Bournemouth before 9am, so I had to hire a car. Is this the 21st Century?!

Anyhow, I ran round in 39 minutes 15 seconds, which met my target of going under 40 minutes. That corresponds with an average pace of 3:56 per km or 6:20 per mile. I'm well pleased with that as it's something I've wanted to do for a few years now. Training works, there is no substitute. And in many ways the training has been more important than the race was, as it's reignited my love of running. Interestingly, if I'd been able to run the pace I ran in training (3:45 per km) I'd have gone round in 37min 30s, which goes to show the effects of pressure on performance. I am kind of fascinated by the effect of ones state of mind on all sorts of things. I knew because of my accelerometer that I wasn't going as fast as I can, but I didn't feel that I could go any faster at the time.

You can check out the full results here. I officially finished 15th overall out 851 runners (or 10th position out of 258 men in the general mens class as an alternative measure, but there were 5 men in the over 35's classes faster than me) and it's no false modesty to say that this is more a reflection on the quality of the field than on my performance. It was quite exciting (and a bit weird) running up to finish by the pier with hundreds of people clapping and the announcer calling my name and number over the tannoy.

Thank you to everyone who has offered their thoughts and advice in response to my previous post about Phd's. I've decided to take it on and am in the process of submitting the application. I won't know until around August whether it is definitely going ahead as I need to do well enough in my degree and the department won't make a decision about funding until sometime around then. My potential supervisor seems sufficiently optimistic that it will go ahead though that he has taken the research topic for which I have applied off the website. So here's some information as to what it's all about - in a kind of round the houses explanation:

The topic I'm applying to do research into is the application of queuing theory to irrigation.

Shooting straight off at a tangent, let me begin with a bit of motivation theory from 1943 with Maslow's 'Hierarchy of Needs' in which he reasoned five levels of needs that act as motivational forces in peoples lives:

1. Physical: Freedom from thirst and hunger

2. Security: absence of fear

3. Social: the need to feel accepted and wanted by others

4. Esteem: the need for personal recognition and respect

5. Self-actualisation: the need for personal fulfilment

This isn't a theory I hold in particular high regard and I've only used it for the purposes of this explanation as it is illustrative of the kinds of differences that different people will be experiencing depending on their circumstances. Most people, if not all of you, reading this are living at level 5 according to this theory and me too. And doing a Phd is definitely a level 5 activity. However the subject of my Phd speaks (rather indirectly) to level 1 and for many people, if not the majority of people on the planet, trying to meet levels 1 and 2 are their everyday experience. Which is not to say that I think this is any more worthy than other subject areas, but hopefully it gives you some idea of how it fits into the realm of human endeavour.
