Even for those of us living most of our lives at the upper levels of needs we are most likely going to experience large increases in the costs of food soon due to pressures on several fronts: increasing global population, climate change effects leading to the decrease in the supplies of fresh water and climate change effects leading to crop failures through increased droughts and floods. Hence good management of irrigation systems in order to grow food is likely to be of increasing importance.

For example, you may or may not be aware rice prices are at an all time high at the moment as demand outstrip supply. It takes 10,000 tonnes of water to produce 1 kg of rice, which you can think about by imagining that 1kg of water is two small half litre bottles of Evian and 10,000 tonnes of water is 10,000 kg of water or 20,000 small bottles of Evian for a 1kg packet of rice. Meeting need 1 for everyone is therefore a major logistical and economic challenge.

And across the hierarchy of needs, when things go wrong on level 1, it's all bets off further up the pyramid and that leads to all sorts of other problems that may not be immediately obvious, such the effects on gender equality or war in Darfur due to issues around water. So although it's not something that will be on the minds of most people in developed countries most of the time, the effects of level 1 problems reach us eventually in the form of higher food prices or increased levels of refugees and acts as an obstacle to solving many problems related to inequality. I'm not saying providing everyone with enough to eat and drink is going to put Nuts magazine or the Pope out of business, but it gives people one less thing to worry about and then they may have the time to learn or do something that might empower them to take the idiots to task if they wish.

Much of the focus of the climate change discussions are - quite rightly - concerned with energy and irrigation is a pretty unfashionable subject, especially in this country where irrigation is largely unnecessary at present. However, I'm of the view, for the reasons already mentioned, that it is a subject that will be of increasing importance in the future, both here and globally - everyone needs to eat. Which brings me back to the Phd itself, irrigation and queuing theory:

At the moment I know little about either! But essentially irrigation is really about taps. You turn the tap on to water your farm and when you've got enough water you turn the tap off again. What could be simpler?

Queuing on the other hand is all about supermarket tills. You go to the supermarket and queue up to buy your goods at one of the several tills you have to choose from and sooner or later you get through and go home. Again, simple enough.

Here's the trick - say you have 20 people, all with a different amounts of shopping and only 5 tills. What is the best way to serve everyone? First come first serve? Allocate the people to the tills so that the quantity of shopping is spread evenly amongst all of them? Serve those with the least shopping first?

Replace the shoppers with farmers needing water and the tills with an irrigation network and you have what is a deceptively simple concept for a really tricky problem for a Phd. (Change it slightly and it's a also a problem for a Manager at Tesco's or the designer of TV Mutliplexing System.)

At present most irrigation is done by opening the taps so everyone gets the same amount of water at the same time regardless of need, which is both inefficient and bad for the environment. This link to a satellite picture of Pakistan shows a white patch at the bottom. It is in fact a salt pan, where all the salt washed out of the soils, because of the irrigation method described, to the north of it and have been carried downstream and deposited there. Look at the scale! Much of the green to the north is irrigated land that would otherwise be desert. One of my lecturers said it took three hours to fly over the irrigated land when he visited, such is the scale. Imagine how much water is wasted (think of the one kilo of rice) using current methods and what washing all those nutrients, fertilisers, pesticides and salts out does to the environment and it gives you some idea why this is not a trivial problem.

You may be wondering why, if what I've said is correct, no-one has addressed this already? The answer to that is that the problem is both hard to solve theoretically (it takes a long time to solve even simple models at present) and more importantly, it's not cost-effective as a practical proposition at present, so there hasn't be any economic driving force to come up with a solution (except for some places in the U.S. where they have the money and impetus to start trying more sophisticated methods due to drought). However as I've tried to make a case for the future,I expect that this will change and that irrigation methods will have to change as a matter of necessity - which in my opinion is usually why anything gets done, as the invisible hand of self-interest gives us a shove. In the meantime then this is a Phd that aims to develop theory, but I would hope that it eventually becomes part of applied real life engineering solutions.

I can't honestly say I've got high expectations of doing a Phd filling a level 5 need (or 3 or 4 for that matter) but it seems like it's worth a go. My TV work does address aspects of 3 and 4 and I hope to keep that up for years to come. And maybe it'll lead somewhere interesting and be a small contribution along the way to addressing the problems I've outlined. It is really through the cumulative efforts of many people making small contributions that things usually get done after all, whether it's feeding everyone, putting a TV programme on the air or enacting ideological change.

On the cultural front I finally got round to seeing There Will be Blood! which while very good, like No Country for Old Men and Mad Man, it was a very male experience of a particular type - not the kind of experience I've had in my own life - interesting nonetheless, but I feel like I need something new and something that engages me emotionally. TWBB certainly had echoes of Citizen Kane, but I'm not sure I go along with this, 'changes the nature of narrative cinema' argument I've been reading about.

The aforementioned Mad Men on BBC4 has taken a while for me to get into as none of the characters are very likeable, but it's grown on me and it is a beautifully crafted piece of TV.

Two other bits of TV I finally caught up with and surprised me in that I thought they actually lived up to the hype were Boy A and Gavin & Stacey. Boy A - more male behaviour focused drama! - was as good a bit of British TV drama as I've seen, while Gavin & Stacey has made me laugh more than any comedy in a long time. It falls flat occasionally, but then comes back with some great gag that makes me forget the less good ones.

Books wise I've recently enjoyed one existential crime novel by one of my favourite writers James Sallis: Drive. And one non-fiction read Survival of Sickest (props to Anna) which explores the relationship between diseases and human evolution.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Got my Semester One Module Results, these are combined results for exams and coursework:

Geotechnical Engineering 76%
Structural Analysis 71%
Hydrology & Water Resources Engineering 59%

That's an average of 69% and leaves me 1% off a first class degree, so I need to try and get my average up during this semester if I'm going to hit that target. A 2:1 overall may be more realistic, but it would be frustrating when I'm so close! It's going to be a really tough few months.

I'm really pleased with Structures cos over the years that has been my worst subject - up 6% on last summer. And conversely I'm pretty disappointed with Hydrology as the water resources area is the one I'm most interested in and I would have expected to do better. I put that down to having a bad day in the exam (worth 90% of the total mark) having got 85% in the coursework.
Geotechnical Engineering was all (really hard!) coursework and I'm up 9% on last summer.

Next week I plan to talk to my potential supervisor again and make a decision as to whether to apply for a Phd here.

This semester features four modules: Management, Hydraulics, Group Design Project and the continuation of my Individual Project from semester one. The latter being the biggest cause of stress as (as well as being worth double credits) it involves designing and carrying out an experiment. I had hoped to be at the analysis stage, but I'm still stuck on the getting the experiment to work and gathering some useful data. It is a little taste of what Phd work would be like and is a bit of an emotional roller coaster as things go well and go wrong - mostly wrong it seems! - and I'm running out of time and still feel like I don't know what I'm doing...

The Design Project is to design a pedestrian and cycle bridge and has been relaxing by comparison, as I've got to spend some time drawing, but the constraints of the design brief mean that'll it probably be quite a boring final design. Really not overly interested though, just want to get a good mark.

Management is kind of interesting, as an insight into the theories of how to run a business properly. It covers current rules for disciplinary and grievance procedures, theories of motivation and the numerical methods that are (supposed!) to accurately cost a project. Some of this spills over into everyday life in dealing with people generally and managing a domestic budget. It's also interesting to contrast the theory with my own experiences as an employee.

Hydraulics this semester is concerned with flood alleviation  and the effects of building structures in terms of causing or alleviating floods. This may not sound particularly exciting, but as well as doing some interesting Maths, we get to look at a real problem down at Brockenhurst in the New Forest and have to come up with a solution. Personally, I find this kind of thing (albeit just as an exercise) by far the most interesting stuff we get to do.

I've managed to get out to the cinema a couple of times and I really liked Juno and No Country for Old Men was excellent, if incredibly violent, bleak and male. I found it really uncomfortable to watch.

On DVD I've enjoyed A Scanner Darkly, Zodiac and I finished watching Firefly. No-one else I know seems to like Josh Whedon stuff, but I really like his writing and think it's actually quite subtle and clever for what it is. I plan to re-watch Serenity now I've seen the series.

The fourth series of The Wire is out on DVD in March, so other than my new running shoes and the prospect of a new Portishead album in April, this is my greatest source of excitement! What a life I lead. The fifth and final series is on the air in the U.S. at the moment and I'll have to wait until 2009 for that to reach these shores.

Not much time for reading novels of late, so nothing new that was really good to recommend.

Music I've been enjoying recently: Okkervil River, Strategy and James Yorkston. Props to Neil for all of those.

The picture is of the sky in Lancashire where I was a couple of weeks ago enjoying some absurdly spring like weather in Febraury.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
So dear reader, I find myself arriving at a major crossroads in life much sooner than I had anticipated and I don't know which way to go. Let me lay it out for you and if you have any good advice or suggestions, please send it my way....

Just before my exams two weeks ago I went to see my tutor cos I was having trouble with my calculus - no change there - and we got into a conversation about Phd study. The long and the short of it being that he advised me that my current grades were good enough (which was encouraging to hear) and if I wanted to do a Phd I should graduate this summer with a BEng and start my Phd then rather than carry on and do the extra year that would give me a MEng.
Yesterday I went to see a potential supervisor who researches in the area of Water Resources and he also suggested the same thing and then explained to me what's involved with doing a Phd: Essentially, having found a novel research topic that is available and a supervisor willing to take me on, I would get three years of funding for a project that is likely to take four years! Most of what happens then is down to me, to do research, teach myself or find ways to get taught what I need to complete the project and any experiments involved. And what happens after that is pretty much unknown at this stage - more research? Get a job?

Financially I'd be better off than I am now (at least for three years), think it works out about £1000 a month tax free and I still get the benefits of being a student re: council tax, discounts etc. Which beats taking on £5000 a year in debt. However that's obviously peanuts compared with a job in the commercial sector.

And the other thing to consider is that I'm free to apply for Phd's wherever I like if I can get them to take me on, so I could go back to London or anywhere else for that matter. I have an advantage in that few British people want to do Phd's, especially in Engineering or Science, so the bar for entry is set a bit lower than it would have been in the past. So that raises a whole other set of questions about where do I want to live? As a city I kind of like Southampton, cos it's so unfashionable and uncool (that's gonna upset someone!) and characterless there's no sense of missing out on anything and instead it's functional and relaxed. Compared with dysfunctional, characterful London with it's cliques and pressures and general sense of self-importance, that's actually quite nice a lot of the time.

What are the alternatives? Finish the MEng and worry about it next year! Finish this year and try and get a job in Civil Engineering. Finish this year and try and get a job in TV. Finish whenever and go and do something completely different.

I've got about a month to make a decision, but to be honest I'm finding it pretty hard to think about sensibly cos I feel like I'm burning out at the moment. I've been putting in a lot of 6 or 7 day weeks since October between work and University. And with the latest bit of Geotechnics coursework, even Ingrid, always the smartest person in the room, has been sending me emails of frustration about how tough it is. And I need to find new tenants for my house in London - if anyone wants to rent a nice house in East London,it's available from March, do let me know...

Life just seems far too complicated and with a definite lack of fun. I keep having these fantasies selling as much of my stuff as possible so that I only own a top specification laptop (with back up and internet connection), and some clothes and perhaps my bicycle. Plus whatever books I'm reading from the library. Everything else can go, it's all surplus to requirements.

I am sorely tempted to see if I can go back to TV work full time, partly because it'd be nice to not always be worrying about money and partly because it's the only thing I've ever felt genuinely good at. Don't know why I'm good at it or why it makes sense to me, but there's a certain rationality that one should spend ones time doing what one is good at rather than trying to be or do something one is not so good at.

So that's the deal - any ideas anyone?

A quick round up of life since Christmas - work, exams, coursework. I got some money for Christmas, with which I bought some ace Maths software for my computer (yeah, I know) and a device which I attach to my shoe while running that logs my time and distance and then uploads it to my computer. This is one of the best gadgets (talking of surplus to requirements possessions) I've ever had. It is fantastically pedantic and I can now spend hours looking at graphs of my telemetry. If I was richer I could have got the GPS version which logs your route too and plots it on Google Earth and you can annoy all your friends with your runs. Ain't technology grand? Speaking of which, William Gibson posted this link as a sign of the times we live in. Hard to disagree.

Notable reads of late: Things the Grandchildren Should Know - the Eels front man's memoirs. Tokyo Year Zero - David Peace's latest about post war Tokyo, which led me to watching Kurosawa's Stray Dog which is a tremendous film. Like Kenneth Clarke says, you know Art when you see it and this is it, social commentary and great cinema.

Better go finish my coursework and hand it in. Semester 2 starts on Monday, which means I get a whole day off tomorrow. Hurrah!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: do it. do it in Australia :)

Well, being someone who is truly averse to making decisions, I can sympathise with your predicament .. but at the risk of sounding complete banal .. try and imagine where you would like to be in 5 years time (and I don't just mean which town) .. make a list of your options, and for each write down all the pros and cons that you can think of. This should help you start creating a division of desirability. If your fantasy is to sell all your stuff, then I'd say do it (I would consider keeping your motorbike though .. they're fun and more useful over longer distances).. it's good for the soul to have a proper clear out .. and having a "small footprint" is very Zen .. (which ties in nicely with the motorbike .. Zen and the art of.. etc .. The Road Less Travelled is also a good book, about making decisions funnily enough .. I'm sure you've read it) To my eyes, it sounds like the Phd is calling you .. you said, you'd be financially 'better off' .. so if money is a worry, this would be a step in the right direction.. plus I would imagine you'd get a better paid job in Civil Engineering with a Phd (that's a guess). As for where to study .. perhaps you should apply to, and visit some places, and see what happens, and what you think .. that decision could be made for you by an Enrollment Administrator, or a particularly unpleasant Friday night out.. I would also like to point out at this juncture, that "a job in television" is what you left to do your course, because you wanted to do something that would benefit others, rather than work in an anti-industry, that parks people's arses, and stiffles freedom and creativity. In the short term however, you can always feelance, and wash yourself thoroughly in the shower afterwards! here endeth the lesson.

Alex is right man. By the way thanks for the answers to my questions a couple of blogs ago. I regularly take a shower after a freelance gig. Figuratively speaking of course. It is easier now as I can meditate and yogically exorcise myself in India. Bloody hell...... Al.... If I had even the slightest incling of being able to do a PHD I would do it. It gives you status that goes beyond materialism. You will be able to travel all over the bloody world as everyone and his dog in the engineering fraternity will want to here what you have to say especially in the field that you are in. This is no plug but take a look at my most recent blog entry www.delhidigest.blogspot.com and you will see that you have the opportunity to do what I am craving to do at the moment !! Al ....do the PHD. In the immortal words of Del Boy "You know it makes sense" Peace and Love Sanjiv
Of course I cannot do a PHD I cannot even spell Hear !

item.title: SF I've Liked
item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Exams season. I sleep worse than usual and I find myself thinking all sorts of nonsense in during my insomnia and something I often seem to end up doing is making lists to get through the endless hours. And I started thinking about books I’ve liked and categorising them so I thought I’d write some of it down. Most people I meet don’t seem to read much these days, for a variety of reasons I guess, but I love reading and I love genre fiction. So here’s a list of author’s and some of their books I’ve particularly liked over the years from the Science Fiction/Fantasy canon. I was making the list for myself, but I thought other people might be interested. (I might do a Crime Fiction list next time.) I made this up in the middle of the night, so I’ve probably left off loads of books much better than what I’ve included, so please feel free tell me I’m wrong and offer some suggestions.

In no particular order:

Cyberpunk

William Gibson – Neuromancer

I read this holed up in a hotel room in France when I was 18, after the guy I was travelling with bailed on me. I’d borrowed his short stories book Burning Chrome from the library, but I had to buy this one! Genre defining and Molly is such a great hero, even if the overall plot is maybe a bit nebulous.

Jim Courtney Grimwood – The Arabesk Trilogy (3 Novels)

An alternate history for the Islamic world set in Northern Africa with more than a touch of cyberpunk. (This is kind of a successor to George Alec Effinger, who explored similar territory a back in the late 80s.)

Jeff Noon – Vurt

Or Pollen and Falling Out of Cars are brilliant too. Manchester’s own cyberpunk answer to Lewis Carroll.

Neal Stephenson – Snow Crash

Though maybe The Diamond Age is better, this is a classic cyberpunk novel, funnier than William Gibson. Great opening sequence about pizza delivery. Still haven’t read his Baroque Cycle...

Bruce Sterling – Schismatrix

Another classic, but this time imaging a post-earth future for humans. Incredible imagination.

Pat Cadigan – Tea from an empty cup

One of the few women cyberpunk writers, but one of the best. She’s one of those authors like Maupassant or Camus that really knows the art of the ‘mot juste’. To quote Wikipedia, ‘Her novels and stories all share a common theme, exploring the relationship between the human mind and technology.’

Richard Morgan – Altered Carbon

Kind of taken on the cyberpunk mantle into the 21st century mixing it with noir crime fiction (and Poe) and a bit of the politics of war to produce this cracker.

English Fantasy

Alan Garner – Red Shift

A work of heart breaking genius as the cliché goes, but this short tale of growing up the hard way set in multiple time periods in the same location near Manchester is exactly that.

Alan Moore – Voice of the Fire

His only novel to date. Tread’s similar ground to Alan Garner mixing history and location, here around Northampton, but so clever and moving. Takes a while to get into though.

Other Stuff I don’t have a catergory for

Jack Womack – Random Acts of Senseless Violence

One of my all time favourite authors, but not necessarily easy to track down. This is a kind of Anne Frank’s diary for the future. One thing that I think makes him so good is his ability to create new language from present use and combine this with present social concerns and extrapolate them to their logical extremes.

Philip K. Dick

I can’t choose a book by this guy. I think whoever ordered books for my local library was a fan, as from the age of 14 to 16 I consumed novel after novel by him and there was always more.

Walter Tevis – Mockingbird

From the author of ‘The Hustler’ a beautiful book about the power and joy of language after the human race has driven itself nearly to extinction because of an obsession with individuality and abdication of responsibility.

Walter M. Miller Jr – A Canticle for Liebowitz

As good a book damming the human race for being stupid as you’re likely to read ;-)

Margeret Atwood – Oryx and Crake

Almost as good as A Canticle for Liebowitz! And of course A Handmaid’s Tale is outstanding too.

Ursula Le Guin – The Dispossessed

I’ve written about this before, so ‘nuff said.

Tim Powers – The Anubis Gate

And Last Call is brilliant too. One of those authors who likes to take real historical figures and weave magic around them blending mythologies together. The Anubis Gate mixes up time travel with myths of Punch and Judy with Egyptology in Victorian England. Last Call is all about the Fisher King Legends and Tarot in Las Vegas. And Pirates of the Caribbean must have been influenced by On Stranger Tides

Michael Marshall Smith – One of Us

Or Only Forwards and Spares are great too. Before he went onto to write rubbish crime/horror novels he wrote these three great books about dreams, technology and love.

Neal Asher – The Skinner

Bit of a guilty pleasure like watching Top Gear. Like Clarkson I can never decide if he’s actually as right wing as he’s makes out or just messing with us. It’s so violent and yet entertaining to read his writing has earned the sub-genre title of Splatterpunk.

Robert A. Heinlein – Starship Troopers

Speaking of people with a reputation as right wing! I read this as description of what happens when societies go to war and people end up believing crazy fascist things because of the extreme experiences they have and the need to make things black and white, but its reputation is that this is literally what the author thought was true. Joe Haldeman’s The Forever War gives the other side of this coin.

Douglas Adams – Hitchhikers Guide...

I think a lot of people are put off by the mixing of humour and s.f., but it’s one of those books that just sticks with you and the observations seems to get more and more accurate as time goes by.

Christopher Moore – A Dirty Job

This is a tale of death and of life as a beta male single parent in San Francisco He’s the king of the foul mouthed one liner and while he’s maybe not so good at the mixing of narrative with social observation as Douglas Adams, he’s very very good. For example the simile that ‘it was a mixed blessing, like herpes on the popes’ ring’ works on so many levels.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Eight weeks worth of stuff here, so it’s quite long!

Starting with a positive for a change, the course is much better this year than the previous two. Which with hindsight feel like the equivalent of Army Basic Training; beasting us to get us to a point of mental fitness where we can do something more interesting than just proving we can jump that high.

This is not to say it isn’t really intense and the level of the work has increased significantly again. It is different to doing TV work, which is intense in different ways, but the time spent is probably in excess of what I would do in a working week there and it’s not something I can easily leave on campus at the end of the day. Lectures have been cut to about 50% of what they were in previous years. This may seem like less value for money! But it means that the supervisors become a resource and we learn by doing, rather than spending all day listening and then studying at night or on the weekends. Stopping studying at 7pm and maybe having a whole day on the weekend with no studying at all feels like a luxury.

Here’s what I’ve been doing this term:

Geotechnical Engineering. By far the hardest subject as it is so complicated. We had a class test in November and I ended up with 17 pages of calculations for this one problem. Then we had the coursework to design a retaining wall on the Channel Tunnel Rail Link that the school has been involved with designing and monitoring. It took me one month, yielding 28 Pages of calculations, 5 spreadsheets and learning a new computer program (and making a lot of assumptions) to come up with a design for that.

To give some context, because a wall is not an exciting thing and it’s hard to imagine why anyone would choose to spend their time designing them: There are many cases of natural and human structures that have failed and killed people, a famous example of the failure of a human made structure being the collapse of a slag heap at Aberfan.

This collapse could have been prevented if the theory of how such heaps of materials behave had been better understood. The equation that describes the mechanism of collapse is actually very simple, but it wasn’t known then and hence no one knew about the risk. (We’ve also considered the collapse of the Levee’s in New Orleans in earlier lectures.)

Now imagine the consequences of a failing wall on a track designed for trains running in excess of 150 mph and perhaps the significance of good design for something as mundane as a wall is more obvious. Something to think about next time you’re on the Tube, a train or driving through a cutting.

Hydrology as I’ve probably mentioned before is the subject I find most interesting. This subject (perhaps familiar to anyone with Geography GCSE or equivalent) deals with the water cycle from an engineering point of view. By this I mean considering water resource management and the topics this entails such as providing potable water to everyone, flood prediction and the effects of climate change.

My coursework for this module is to design a water supply system for a (hypothetical) village in Tunisia. This is a challenge that involves estimating the water requirements for a population for their personal use and for agriculture and then designing a delivery system for this water in a way that actually works and is sustainable for decades to come. I’m at an early stage with this coursework, but for part of it I will be using software designed and produced in part by my lecturer for the United Nations and which is used for crop irrigation studies worldwide. It’s freely available to anyone and you can read about it here

A lot of this module has been focused on understanding the water cycle for Southampton and the South East of England and the climate change stuff is quite worrying when one looks into it. I expect for most of us living in this part of the world (and probably everywhere else too) things are going to have change significantly in order to adjust to these changes, not least in the way we use fresh water in the next twenty years.

My Vortex Induced Vibrations project is the other main use of my time. It took the best part of a month to work through the theory and carry out all the calculations necessary to start building the experiment. Now the challenge is to try and build it and I’m running into all the practical issues of actually trying to construct something that has a chance of testing the theory and thus making the experiment worthwhile. The days I’ve spent in the Lab so far have been really frustrating, trying stuff and finding it doesn’t work and then having to think of something else, finding that doesn’t work and so on. This is the difference between being able to look up something in a book and doing something for which there is no manual! In itself, this is a very instructive process, but I’m definitely on the wrong side of the hill at the moment.

The point of this project is to try and understand the effects of how a structure (in this case a long thin cylinder) is fixed (in this case with restraints that can move about) have on the way it vibrates when fluid flows over it. This is significant for marine structures such as the tubes that bring oil up from the sea floor, but it is also of interest just as a part of fluid dynamics theory that is still not well understood.

Lastly, there is my least favourite subject: Structures. I still don’t really have a feel for how forces in structures behave, so I find this a tough subject that I mostly learn by rote rather than actually understand. I’ve been spending yet more time learning about reinforced concrete beams and columns! But if one wants to build strange structures out of this stuff (I don’t), I guess one better understand it. 

This subject is also linked with Finite Element Analysis, which a very clever if rather mind bending mathematical technique, particularly suited to computers, for solving problems that could not be solved analytically. Attempting plain English, I mean that some problems such finding the area of a circle can be solved in a way that produces an equation that symbolically describe the solution; in this case the familiar Pi-r-squared equation. Numerical Solutions are always approximations (such as Pi is equal to 3.142), albeit very good ones, so good in fact that computers are used to design pretty much everything we actually use in everyday life.

As the name suggests, Finite Element Analysis breaks (for example) a structure down into small approximate parts that can be analysed individually and then put together to produce an overall solution or set of solutions to different scenarios.

It’s a very powerful method, but one that is the complete opposite of intuitive to learn and that’s what makes it difficult (well, for me anyway.)

I find it difficult to describe what it means to try to learn to think like an engineer  – they have such a bad and often well deserved reputation for poor social skills and general geekery – that the stereotype gets in the way of the positive aspects that should in my opinion be seen as something to aspire to. The best engineers I’ve met combine the ability to think freely – by which I mean they have a whole library of experiences, theories and critical thinking skills that can cut through their or others prejudices -  with the ability to communicate effectively to whoever their audience/collaborators are in order to actually solve a problem.

So that’s my course and other than the usual bit of reading, watching films, listening to music, running and swimming, that is my life. Notable films I’ve watched Michael Clayton, The Lives of Others, Volver and The House of Mirth. Notable books – None! But I have some lined up for reading over the vacation. New music I’ve liked is Burial, Scout Niblett (props to Ms. Grayson) and the LCD Soundsystem Mini-Album.

Finally, it wouldn’t be December if I wasn’t obsessed with the light – I think maybe it’s something to do with it being in such short supply - as well as the angle at which it hits this part of the world at this time of year that makes it seem so special to me. So here’s a picture from a particularly colourful December dawn at the top.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Whoa !!! I am particularly interested in one aspect of what you do and how it must be linked with financials ?? For example.... the research you have been doing with regards to the re-inforcing of the channel tunnel walls.... Presumeably the powers that be who would authorise the money to actually action this kind of work would also be thinking about future value to be gained... possible impacts on the life of the tunnel and therefore how much actual profit can be forecast in the years to come, share pricing etc etc. Is that something that you would have to possibly get invovled with in the future ??? Does that mean one you have finished this degree you will have to then go off and do an MBA or something :))) By the way .... how many years should the channel tunnel last. Hope you are well otherwise Alistair and keep up the good work. I am absolutely convinced now that I have read the above that I am not capable of doing what you do. In fact I only understood a couple of words.. like .... ""and"" and ""the""... hehehe.

Hey Sanjiv, Yes the financial aspect is very much part of the course, though not one I've really written about. We do management modules dealing with the organisational aspects of running a project so as to minimise costs and waste as well as teaching us about the laws involved with these things. And certainly after safety, producing an economical design is probably the biggest consideration. In the case of the Channel Tunnel Wall they actually lost faith in the design and took a decision to lengthen the wall depth by two metres more than what the calculations estimated to ensure its’ safety. For a wall several kilometres long this extra depth would have come at considerable expense and therefore cut into any profits the design company would hope to make on such a project. This is also why the wall is part of a monitoring project, so that seeing what happens in reality can help refine the models and give designers confidence in producing the most economic (as well as safe) designs for future projects. This is true for all engineering. It’s also important in terms of sustainability and general ethical considerations that engineers can produce designs that are safe and have minimal impact on the environment and people within it and so producing an optimum design is important for lots of reasons – but certainly, most engineering even in the public sector is done by private companies who are obviously looking to make a profit. Personally I see the challenge as to line up everyone’s self interest in the same direction as in the past the interest of the engineering companies and the population and the environment have been very much in conflict. Whether this is always possible remains open to discussion, but good use of contracts and regulation to guide people is certainly possible in many cases if people can get out of the short term quick profit mentality that has been the human way for the last 150 years when we thought our resources were infinite. In answer to your other question, generally design life is for 120 years, but as was mentioned in another lecture it’s unrealistic to imagine swapping out all our infrastructure every 120 years! Can you imagine replacing every road, wall, building, drainage system etc.?! It’s not only impossible in terms of cost and inconvenience, but in terms of materials. So in reality, just as we convert Victorian Houses for 21st Century living, our infrastructure gets serviced for modern use, such as St. Pancras Station has recently and only completely replaced as a last resort. Hope that answers your questions.

like Sanj, I'm always left a little confused after reading the indi variable - it's great. Are you up in town much over Christmas? I'm heading back to Oz in March so I have to see you before then. it's great to hear that you are enjoying this year more, lots of happy holiday cheer to you ... Jen

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
There was a few bits and pieces I didn't write about last time that I thought I'd add.

One was my current track listing. As most people probably know I love making mixes and I have a list which I change all the time with 'Things I'm liking now' on it. As I travel to London often for work on the weekend, this is what I listen to on my journey. So as of the end of the week 19th October this is my current playlist for anyone who wants to check out any of the tracks. (Ignore the Genre, rating etc. columns, Media Monkey just generates this nonsense and I couldn't be bothered to edit the HTML):

Rip it up and start again is my kind of theme tune for the moment as it seems to be where I end up whenever I try to do any studying. If anyone wants me to send them a copy of this mix, let me know.

I finished the The Dispossessed and it got me having a bit of a rant in my own head about science fiction. It is a really moving book about personal freedom and anarchism and is at least as good as any straight fiction I've read dealing with similar issues. Most people's experience of science fiction seems to be Star Wars or Star Trek which are pretty much cowboy films set in space and not really an important part of the genre in my opinion. One important function of SF really is to explore and extrapolate issues affecting people now and this can be done much more effectively if the context of the real day to day world is taken out of the picture. So one can get hung up on the fact William Gibson didn't think of mobile phones in Neuromancer or the stupid names characters always have - or one can accept the imperfections in predicting the future and experience the chance to think different in a fantasy world (as Apple would purport to have us do).

So as I say the Dispossessed is all about an anarchist society and the role of an individual within it. It's very hard to imagine what anarchy would really mean from our everyday experience and so it needs the construction of a fantasy to allow this to be played out and explored. It's extraordinary for something that was written in 1974 to seem so new and most people on the planet I think would still find the ideas it contains a threat and ridiculous even now. But ironically it's also not hard to see how they could connect to the problems of and solutions for global warming, overpopulation, fighting over scarce resources and the rise of dogma that threaten to wipe humanity off the planet in the next 150 years.

Likewise I'm watching series three of the new version of Battlestar Galactica and I find it extraordinary that such a mainstream (and occasionally clunky and cheesy) series is dealing with genocide, internment, suicide bombings and summary executions in such an explicit fashion. Because it's in a fantasy world they can explore things that would just not be acceptable in a drama if replaced with times, locations and people familiar to us in the here and now. It manages to be exciting, silly and thought provoking in one shot. And it's far superior to something like Heroes or Lost in my opinion which are all gloss and have nothing to say that I can see.

I'm not writing this to say it's better than other fiction, just that it is as good and deserves the recognition and to be consumed as widely as other stuff. It serves a purpose political and ideological and just plain imaginative that is as worthy as any classic form of narrative. So I'm glad Doris Lessing got her award and I'd like to see more people taking a chance on this stuff and exploring all the sub genres too.

The only other thing on my mind was to lay out where I'm at and what I'm actually doing this year. I'm starting year three of my degree and year four of my studying at Southampton. I potentially graduate in summer 2009. This semester I have four modules to study:

Structures and Geotechnical Engineering (aka Soil Mechnics) are the two core modules for Civil Engineering. They're the ones I have most trouble with, really hard and quite dull. As we get further into the course these get further from complete theoretical models and more towards a mix of theoretical approximation and empirical experience. In engineering and science approximation has a subtly different meaning to its everyday use. This is because there is always uncertainty in real life and for engineers it's about what are acceptable levels of uncertainty and/or approximation. The usual example being that one will quote ones height to the nearest centimetre or inch as knowing to the nearest atom is either impossible or unnecessary.

These two subjects then are about understanding and predicting what will happen to structures build on or in the ground so as to make them safe for people to use. It's not something I really have any strong interest in, but the methods and the maths have a lot of correlations with things that do interest me.

Thirdly is Hydrology, which is much more interesting to me and is all about Water Resource engineering. How we work out how much water there is, where it is, predicting future behaviour and engineering accordingly. It's quite a scary subject in terms of making one feel pessimistic about the future of humanity when facts like it takes 10,000 kilos of water to produce 1 kg of Basmati Rice are banded about. Or it takes about a minimum of 25 kg of fresh water a day to sustain a human being - ever considered having to carry that weight about? Millions of people do that every day to survive, while we use 7 kg of drinkable water every time we flush the toilet. Crazy world.

Lastly there's my individual project which is all about hydrodynamics - water movement over a circular cylindrical tube creating vortex induced vibration - in plain english. An effect most famous for causing the Tacoma Narrows Bridge Collapse. Which sounds quite dull, but is pretty challenging in terms of the maths and physics and is an area of research that has been going on for years but is still not well understood. I have to design and carry out an experiment and it's quite daunting at this point in proceedings.

I'm not sure there's much to be gained by expressing my feelings about my studies (or what I'm doing in general) cos it makes me feel miserable if I dwell on it. Just got to get on with it.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Following some good advice that I counter my rising anxiety about get back to studying by doing some drawing, I've indulged myself by drawing some of my favourite current student stereotypes that I see every day. At the risk of offending some of my readers, I thought I'd publish the results here, please click on them to see them bigger.They are affectionate. Honest!

From left to right then we have:

1. The Emo Kids, easily recognisable by having a long fringe over one eye, skinny black jeans with a studded belt, converse style trainers and some kind of skinny band/skate T-shirt (though some of them only wear long sleeves, presumably to cover up their self-harming). Both sexes tend to dress the same, generally quite androgynous, the boys often favour some kind of chunky /nerdy glasses too. They are so cool and well groomed.

2. My favourite group, partly cos of my own dodgy fashion history and partly cos of the shear effort required to maintain the look, are the Cassock-Wearing Goths. They always fill my heart with joy when I see them, especially if it's raining and their hair has gone all lank and their clothes are starting to smell like wet lunchtimes at school (slightly like wee). Black is the default setting, nail varnish and eye-liner included and generally a lot of buckles and piercings going on. Must be a nightmare at Airport security. Sometimes they sneak a bit of purple into their outfits too and of course no tans allowed.

3. The next group are what I can only describe as inappropriate flip flop wearers - boys and girls. Whatever time of year and whatever the weather there's always loads of people wearing flip flops and board shorts. If it's really cold sometimes they'll put on a hoody. It's like the young persons equivalent of a nice pair of slacks and slippers. Awful clashing colours and patterns, but ask them what the hell they're doing wearing flip flops in February and they'll tell you it's cos it's so comfy and they only have to walk a few hundred yards from their bed to the nice warm lecture theatre and they can sleep in their shorts. Sloth thy name is student.

4.Last but by no means least  are the Posh Girls: Expensive hair, Ug Boots, Tight blue jeans with a huge belt, Hoody with a slogan of whichever department/society they're part of on the back e.g. 'Geographers do it in the field' and a top of the line Mobile Phone (how long til I see my first Iphone on campus?) on which they're usually texting or speaking in a loud horsey voice to one of their friends. Walking evidence of how white and middle class Southampton University is. (We do have a fair amount of foreign students and British students from ethnic minorities, but it is very much a minority in percentage terms.) Still, the Posh Girls are so entertaining in terms of voyeurism, I can't dislike them. They wear big bug-eyed shades when the sun is out too.  I'm so like, yeah, whatever...

Continuing the student theme, I've had a couple of conversations about money recently and I thought I'd work out what it costs me to be a student and how much I actually have to live on. I was quite surprised with what I calculated. This is not me whining by the way, I could change my lifestyle and cut my costs substantially - by living in a student house for example. I just thought it might be interesting to some people to see what it's like these days.

My net monthly income after taxes, expenses, rent and bills over the summer has been approx. £352 a month, £100 of which goes into savings, leaving me £252  a month to spend on food, clothes and anything else such as going out. In other words if I estimate £30 for food & household goods each week, I have about £27 a week disposable income. Which actually is not too bad, all things considered (£8 goes on swimming fees each week)...I won't be getting a yacht any time soon though!

(I didn't factor in other one-off costs such as MOT, Road Tax and re-insuring my bike that I've had to pay out too, so this may even be a bit of an overestimate.)

And for each year of study I incur just under £5,000 in debt in student loans.

So I make it that I need to receive about £10 worth of learning every day I am at University to get good value from being here! Not sure how I measure that though, unless I can accurately predict my future earnings...

Term starts properly on Monday, so I doubt I'll post again until Christmas unless I really feel in need of a rant. I've just finished a 10,000 word report that I have to hand in for one of this years modules already, so I'm expecting a massive workload again.

I did find time to sneak in a couple more novels before I go back:

Oryx & Crake by Margaret Atwood which is just excellent. This and Power of the Dog are the two best novels I've read this year so far. O&C is Post-Apocalyptic stuff. It's a long time since I read a novel in 24 hours but I really couldn't stop with this one.

Attack of the Unsinkable Rubber Ducks by Christopher Brookmyre : Not one of his best, but still pretty good. If you've ever wonder how psychics do their tricks, some of it's revealed in here and he's still quite funny.

And I've just started The Dispossessed by Ursula Le Guin which is supposed to be something of a feminist SF classic that I've been meaning to read for some time. Pretty good so far

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Shall we send you money? Now or sooner?

i went and got my fringe done the emo way today.... oryx and crake is my favorite margaret atwood, its very different from the rest of her stuff. what was 'magic for beginners' like? ------- Well Jen, you are very cool and well groomed so I'm sure your new fringe is perfect. I've only read two of the stories in Magic For Beginners so far. I can only really compare them to a more humorous version of Jorge Luis Borges. Really beautiful prose and bonkers stories, yet troubling and moving. The first one is about a handbag made out of a live dog in which the people from under the hill live! Which makes about as much sense as it sounds! See for the handover on Saturday night...A

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
I'd kind of given up writing for a while, for various reasons and this is going to be more of a list of stuff than any diary/commentary kind of entry (you'll probably be glad to know).

Since I last wrote I finished out the academic year with another set of exams and stack of coursework including a three month long group project that generated over 66,000 words of reports on it's own. Much to my surprise I passed my exams which was a big relief, but has the irony of meaning I've no justification for quitting. To I do that I'll have to find another reason - fortunately spurious justifications are a staple of humanity.

Summer's been about as gloomy as me and I noted one week that seven days had passed without more communication than it takes to purchase milk from the Co-op, but on the plus side it's given me the chance to read books that aren't textbooks. So here's a record of what I've been reading so far:

Power of the Dog by Don Winslow - Excellent fictionalised account of the drugs trade in Mexico

Command Decision by Elizabeth Moon - Latest instalment in this space opera about a family of women.

Winter of Frankie Machine by Don Winslow - Like a really good episode of the Sopranos.

Black Man by Richard Morgan - A bit disappointed by this. Dense and not very exciting, but with some really good bits.

The Intruders by Michael Marshall - Don't bother. Boring horror. Read his first three novels as Micheal Marshall Smith instead

A Dirty Job by Christopher Moore - A highly amusing book about Death. He's a king of the one-liner. Must read some more of his.

A Spot of Bother by Mark Haddon - By the Curious Incident of the Dog... guy. Not sure if I liked this or not, sometimes funny, sometimes quite depressing and what was it trying to say if anything? I dunno.

Brasyl by Ian Macdonald - been one of my favourite writers for years this guy. Extraordinary imagination he has. He generally makes my head hurt a bit and this is no exception.

Spook Country by William Gibson - He has a special way with prose, so that even if the story is not remarkable, the way it's written definitely is.

And from the non-fiction section:

No Logo by Naomi Klein - been meaning to read this for years and should be finished in time for her new one. It's really raised my consciousness another notch about globalisation. She's a really good writer too in laying out the complexities involved and even if some bits seem a bit out of date, the first two sections No Space and No Choice are brilliant. And I hadn't realised how much of a feminist issue this stuff is too. It's also made me reflect on how this aspect of human rights is less in the public eye in these days of global warming and wars on terror yet is surely related to both issues.

Stumbling on Happiness by Daniel Gilbert - Completely misleading title and cover to this book. Covers similar ground to Irrationality in laying out ways in which intuition fails.

The Canon by Natalie Angier - A really excellent popular science book outlining the key findings of science. Written to partly bridge the C.P. Snow Two Cultures gap, her passion that everyone should enjoy science as much as they do the produce of art really comes across. I'll definitely read her prize winning book on female physiology Woman when I'm done with this one.

And I'm just starting The End of Mr. Y by Scarlett Thomas and have a book of short stories Magic for Beginners by Kelly Link (which are crazy Borges style stories) on the go too. Plus a couple on the side I've yet to start.

I've got a new project on Vortices's to start working on prior to the new semester in a month and have write a report on my TV work. So I'm learning a new Matrix Maths program MATLAB and have to try and design an experiment to go in the wind tunnel here which is going to be quite a challenge.

The picture above is a face I helped to make on the beach at Littlehampton last week. I went to the Pallant House Gallery nearby at Chichester too which was really good if you're in the area. Made me want to learn more about Paul Klee. I also went to see the Helio Oticicia exhibition at the Tate Modern when I was in London.It is still on until 23rd September if it appeals. That kind of appealed to me in it's math-rock way with it's use of geometry and light. It also kind of reminded me Edward Hopper because of the light aspects to the work.

With the exception of the William Gibson, Richard Morgan and Natalie Angier books, all of the above books came from the library, so save your money if you like the look of one or more of them.

I've listened to loads of new music too (see sidebar for more). My favourite albums so far this year are the LCD Soundsystem one (Thank you Steve) and The Cinematic Orchestra one (Thank you Neil).

Too many links!

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
This post has been rolling on since February and I just don't like what I read each time I finish typing. Still, my reality feels a bit altered at the moment so maybe I'll just post it anyway. I spent the afternoon watching the latest David Lynch film - Inland Empire. Three hours of Low Res Digital Video Surrealism. No one makes films quite like him. I've no real idea what it's all about. It'll probably make more sense when it's worked it's way around my subconscious for a few days. And I'm sure to be having nightmares about Laura Derns face for weeks to come. If he ever makes a straight up horror film I think I'd be too scared to watch it, this was disturbing enough. He is a master of the intense soundtrack effects and making it so murky one is straining to see what is lurking in the gloom while petrified at what freaky image it might turn out to be. And when I came out the whole world seems like a bit of dreamscape. Quite an imagination and well worth checking out if you can find it on anywhere.

Seeing Inland Empire is as close as I've had to a holiday since Christmas too, in the never ending rounds of assessment that is a Civil Engineering Degree. It's a world away from equations and rules and regulations. My next batch of exams is in three weeks and they're real tough ones too. A proper step up in difficulty from what I've done before and the real possibility of failure. I've been on the edge of quitting several times in the last few weeks because I'm not sure I'll ever be able to perform well academically, especially in exams. And I'm starting to think after all these years that actually teamwork isn't for me. I think I've been encouraged to believe it's good for me to work with other people, but it just pisses me off so much sometimes having to deal with their crap. Makes me miserable.
The other thing that has really started to bug me is how everything is about getting over hurdles, acheiving a pass mark or getting accredited in this that or the other rather than focusing on the thing itself - the subject matter. Now I'm pretty much an empiricist and measuring and quantifying things is great when I'm trying to understand a problem, but it seems like the tail is wagging the dog these days in Education (and everywhere else). It feels like Standards, League Tables, Accreditations etc. are everywhere and that more time and effort is put into passing the measurement process than into the thing it is supposedly assessing. Things can becomes a game of manipulation to reach the standard and render the whole thing largely meaningless and a waste of time as an accurate indicator of quality. It's irrational in that it defeats what it has set out to achieve. I'm assuming that things are this way is partly because of the competition for funds, jobs etc. combined with the psychological effect of sticking a simple number on something so it can be ranked and clear choices made accordingly - everything has a star rating these days. It got five stars in the Guardian? It must be a good film mustn't it?
As everyone knows, passing a driving test does not make one a good driver, it just indicates that a set of standards have been met that enable one to pass that particular test. I'm not saying do away with exams or assessments, obviously the driving test serves a purpose, but I wonder how useful a measure a lot of these things are and that they may often interfere with the process of improving standards rather than actually raising them.
It was really refreshing when we got to the end of our Hydraulics module and the lecturer said, 'Today I'm going to teach you about some stuff just because I think you might find it interesting. We could do revision instead and this will not help you pass any tests, but I thought we should go back to how University education used to be for a change.'
I have a similar issue with my attitude to the sports I do - other sports people often seem bemused that I'm more interested in the feeling of doing the sport and not overly fussed about achieving a particular time or competing for a place - where as I can understand their interest in the standard arbitrary measure of betterness i.e. time or ranking - I do often take my time, it is a useful measure - they don't seem to be able to understand my existential approach to sport!

Maybe I've been watching too many zombie films, but I've been thinking a lot about death over the last few weeks. Especially when it's 3 am and I can't sleep and I ask myself how many more sleepless 3ams do I have left? And I found myself going over when I first became aware of the finite nature of life and who I've known who is now dead and how they died and did it mean anything anyway, given that it comes to us all and eventually the universe will expire and no-one will be left to feel bad about anything. I'm much more scared about having to cope with the death's of others than I am of being dead myself.
Zombie films aid this line of thinking because in the zombie format the protagonists are relentlessly battling creatures that are trying to kill them and there's usually no escape or victory at the end so it's essentially a futile task. If you get killed, you become one of them and it's really just a matter of time before you do. So at 3am this is, as an analogy, perfect for filling my head with dread about the coming day and life in general.
I decided that the first real awareness I had of the arbitrary nature of it all was when I was eleven and Mark Tildesley, a couple of years below me at primary school was abducted (and I found out subsequently, murdered.) Everyone at school appeared on Crimewatch, it's really weird looking back, this strange kind of excitement around the whole thing followed by life just carrying on as usual for me. He'd be 31 now.
At secondary school, I remember joking about the statistical nature of how as a group we'd be picked off throughout life and I think it was about two or three months after I left school when I was 16 that Thomas Seward got knocked off his bike and killed. We weren't close friends, but we'd been in all the same classes for five years and it was shocking to think that was where his existence ended. Just like that.
It was my grandmother dieing that probably hurt me the most. That was when I was still a teenager and was when I fully realised that some things just do not make sense. No amount of thinking works. I remember being at the funeral and crouching between some cars and a wall trying to hide while I was crying my eyes out because I felt embarrassed about it.
When I was 27, Glen who I had been living with for six months before he left, killed himself not long after leaving (although the coroner was unsure whether the heroin overdose was deliberate or accidental). That one made me feel somewhere between angry and jealous. Again we weren't really close, but when I see someone every day for six months, I felt I knew him well enough and it just felt really unfair. Cos that's the rub for me. Once you're dead you have no problems anymore, it's when you're alive you've got troubles. He got out, I'm still here. It's very confusing.
When I watch the news I often have to remind myself that the dead person or people that are shown as numbers or individual hate figures or whoever they are on TV, must have meant something to someone. And yet it seems bizarre to contemplate all those who have gone before me and whose DNA has led to mine over millennia in an emotional way, let alone the billions of years still to run ahead where everyone I've ever known will be gone and surely forgotten. (Though I find doubtful that humans will still be around for more than a couple of hundred more years.)
I've come to no great conclusions about any of this. It doesn't make me prize life more greatly or have greater fears about death, though I do fear grief. It's too difficult and probably unhealthy to maintain the emotional pitch that occurs around thoughts of mortality of those close to us. I'm still taken aback by how arbitrary it all is though.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Al..... Why doesn't it make you prize life more??? We have all been through the same feelings, have had similar trials and tribulations in life ( although not able to write them as eloquently as you :) Of course you should enjoy it to the max man !!! That is what I try and do everyday of my life. I'm not talking about jumping out of planes and doing extreme stuff like that. I am talking about simple things like really relishing going out with an old friend or watching my kids play together and really cherishing the sights and sounds of their laughter. I suppose it is a state of mind. Hey ..... I moved continents in search of a better way of life and living. It was the best thing I have ever done :)) Best of luck in your exams. You must keep your chin up. You made the decision so the least you can do for yourself is to go in fighting for every mark :)) Warm........ Warmest regards Sanjiv

Blimey .. That's quite the black mood you managed to capture there .. Well the clocks have changed now, so think about the summer sun that's coming to cheer you the f*** up. This post is pretty dark, and made me think .. much like the Lynch movies you seem to like so much (but in my opinion, even thinking about watching anything by him is a complete waste of my time) But the question I was left asking is, why don't you take your attitude to sport into everyday life? I went to a boarding school where sport was compulsory, and used as a weapon (method of punishment), and so since then I have found it very difficult to enjoy any form of group sporting activity (rugby, football etc) or indeed running. Like you, I also like to take an individual, existentialist if you will, view of physical activities. Cycling, surfing and snowboarding are things that I enjoy, when played out in an absence of competition, unless you count getting one over on cab drivers at the lights. I always have at the forefront of my mind, that I could easily be mashed by the nearest bus or van .. knocked out and drowned under a violent wave .. splintered and smashed against a snow covered tree. These thoughts don't however, stop me from doing these activities. They may temper my rashness, but they also add to the excitement. The knowledge that you are just about in control of something that could pinch out your tiny fire, is in a way empowering. But then all of life should be like that; every moment you are still alive, a tiny miracle to be celebrated. Obviously, another person's death can be truly devastating. As you know I lost someone I was very much in love with, 8 years ago almost to the day. She loved her life as an A&R scout, and there was so much more she wanted to do. So every time I go to a gig, I think about what she would have made of the band. But I still go to the gigs. You never get over the death of someone you care about; you just get used to it. I think you're afraid of having an emotional response to something, in case it weakens you in some way, either in yours or others opinion of you. But to live you must feel. Grief is life. Sure, when you're dead you have no problems; you have nothing at all; you are nothing. But I figure that, seeing as you started this course of yours to make the world a better place and help provide sanitation and fresh water to people that don't have it, you don't really want to be nothing. If you've had enough of the course .. jack it in .. make a change. Dead people don't get to make choices. Anyway, there's no such thing as bad decisions, just alternative outcomes. Unless of course the decision is to top yourself, because that's a decision that stops you making anymore decisions, and that's just plain stupid. Now get on with jumping through educational hoops for godsake .. and if you find yourself thinking hard about the meaning of life at 3 in the morning, remember those who don't have the luxury .. have a bit of a cry or something .. (I've found Nam Myoho Renge Kyo also helps - look it up on Wikipedia) .. and get on with living Lots of Love Alex

Steve......my man.... how are you :)) Love the prose. Very appropo. I do love his Almond slices too :) Sorry Al I am going to use your site to advertise my blog. www.delhidigest.blogspot.com Not as well written as Al's but still....it is my blog. Hope you are well... you too Alex Take care all

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
This is probably going to end up as a long moan, sorry about that, I know it's my fault the way things are:

Term ended yesterday and it's been another tough 10 weeks. I'm exhausted and there's still plenty to do. 5 pieces of coursework and three exams to revise for over Christmas. Engineering is properly hard - at least I think so.
It's a good thing I don't have a social life, as I wouldn't be able to have one anyway with the amount of work we have to do. And the difficultly level has gone up a few notches this term, some of the Maths lectures have been mind melting - especially when it's a mono-tonal Finnish man, who is hard to understand, filling a board with equations I've never seen before, at lightening speed, who is doing the teaching...It makes me nostalgic for our Croatian Maths lecturer who used to laugh all the time when she was explaining theories and solving problems. I don't think I've ever met anyone who found such joy in life and while I couldn't quite see why exponential functions are funny, she did. I guess it takes all sorts to make up the species...

What can I say that I haven't said before? Not a lot really. I'm still not sure if I really want to see this through, but don't know what to do instead. The only cure for this disease is to kill the patient. Like other daily intrusive thoughts, it's best not dwelt on. (I was watching a TV drama a couple of weeks back where one character said, "I don't think I've experienced a genuine feeling in years." and I thought - you and me both pal.)

I am finding the more I learn, the more amazed I am that anything actually happens when I switch on a light or open a tap. It is hard to comprehend how complicated the world in which we live is, once one starts to analyse it. We wrote a 46 page report just looking at one road junction for our Transport Engineering coursework and it wasn't even a large junction.
And it's just as bad when one is trying to understand what is going on at the small scale, such as what it takes to make a piece of metal fatigue and fracture. It can take several pages of calculations for one component which could be from a bridge containing hundreds of components. A necessary procedure if one wants at least some certainty that a design will not fail and kill people.
I've probably said this before, but it's all the mental gear changing we do all the time that I find makes it so hard. And I think my attempts to detail the scope of civil engineering in my last post shows what I mean by that.

Y'know, I've been looking the archives and it seems I write the same stuff every December - banging on about how tired I am and how I like the light - this is why writing things down is a bad idea, it becomes a record of just how tedious everyone actually is.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
T.S. Eliot may have had April down as the cruelest month, but November and December both rank highest for me. So perhaps it's best to heed Stuart Sutherland's words, ‘Be wary of your memory: you are likely to recall whatever fits with your current views.’ And to think of what is in the present rather than what is gone, what is broken and what can never be fixed.

It's four weeks into the second year of my degree and therefore four weeks into my third year in Southampton at University. Time dilates such that each day seem long and intense, while the months and weeks seem to contract and pass quickly. Including this year, I have another three years before I graduate.

This year then my timetable consists of the following subjects: Construction Management, Transport Engineering, Hydraulics, Structures & Dynamics, Soil Mechanics, Materials and Statistics. I won't go into them one by one as I can't imagine you'd be interested, but here is some detail of what we do.
As the course progresses the theoretical aspects, the parts shared with all sciences, Newtonian physics and such are starting to diverge and become more empirically based and specific to Civil Engineering. That is to say that when it comes to really building something like a water supply network or even just a building, the level of complexity involved rises to a level where it's too difficult to use purely theoretically derived equations to analyse a problem. So the equations become based on coefficients derived by experiment - excuse me if I'm being patronising here - For example to understand what effect how rough the inside of pipe is has on water flowing through it, someone had to make a lot of pipes with different roughness's and measure the flow of water through them. This results in a number (a coefficient) for each degree of roughness, representing the loss of flow caused by the roughness that one can use to multiply theoretical values (such as a pipe with a length of x metres long) to calculate an accurate prediction for what would happen if one was to really make the pipe and put water through it.

That's all pretty dull and I know most people don't care how they get their water or how the roads work etc., just as long as they do, but this gives you some idea of how solutions are arrived at. This kind of approach is used all the time in Engineering because it's just too difficult to model accurately the real world with our present abilities in Maths and Physics. Besides which these kinds of approximations are often sufficient for what it is we are trying to do.

Just to pop back on my soapbox for a moment, often I find people think of scientists and engineers as doing some kind of exclusive magic, but all they are doing is problem solving using a particular kind of method and probably one you use yourself all the time without thinking about it. It develops into this systematic, mathematical approach because it saves time, it saves money and some people are interested to see if it can describe something fundamental about reality. Personally I love it when the equations all come together and something complex can be described in a simple powerful expression, to me it reinforces ideas about what it means to be human. If reality can be described through a series of connections described by equations, then that says something to me about how all life is connected. Which is one reason I get frustrated with our explicable, but often narrow minded behaviour/world-view as a species.

As usual my inability to think in straight lines means I've completely digressed. I was trying to convey something of theoretical aspects of my studies and before I move onto the practical side I should add what else the theory is about. We look at how structures and materials behave under loads such as people or wind or changes in temperature. How traffic moves along roads and through junctions. How the ground on which we build behaves. (This all being necessary prior to any actual construction.) 
The practical side of the course is then how all this gets used and work gets done in the world today and throws up lots of interesting questions about policies and methods. So in Construction Management we learn all about Health and Safety Laws and the actual process of a building project - which is extraordinary in that it fails to serve almost everyone involved! Likewise with Transport Engineering, it will come as no surprise to discover that we don't really have a Transport Policy in this country. So while the skills have been developed to solve the problems from an Engineering aspect, we lack the governance to enact sensible solutions. Two other interesting points arising from the Transport module were Home Delivery and the matter of data collection.

Studies into the rise of Home Delivery since the Internet has become established show increases in congestion due to use of both delivery vans and the use of cars by people during time that would otherwise be spent travelling to and from the shops. So rather than reducing traffic, Internet shopping increases it as it frees up time for people to do other things and make more journeys. Counter-Intuitive, is it not?
Secondly, the matter of data collection and privacy. In reference to my earlier remarks about empirical methods, statistical data is another way of analysing a real situation and very detailed data may provide useful information for devising solutions. In the case of traffic, this could mean recording traffic flows at a particular place, which in turn could involve recording number plates, which if cross referenced with addresses would give a detailed overview of what journeys are occurring. This could be very useful to Engineers to help find measures to improve flows and reduce journey times - indeed if you have an Oystercard, I would expect this is what London Underground try to do - but what else could this information be used for? who is allowed to see it? and who can gather it? Given that we live in a country where it's possible to lock people up for months without charging them or even telling them what they are charged with, these are not trivial matters and all sorts of Engineering use things like RFID tags which effectively monitor people as well as things.

I've probably said many times what a massive subject Civil Engineering is - from the bending of a beam to freedom of information - it covers a lot of things and the simplest question often unfolds (at least in my mind, maybe not in other students!) into an answer of huge complexity. Hopefully what I've written above gives you some sense of this and what I'm learning about in not too boring a way.

Other than studying, it's been the usual run, swim and book/film/music cycle. I've become a bit more involved with the swimming club and have built our Website and taken on the role of Competition Team Manager. This is because I don't like to race and they needed someone to handle bureaucracy of swim events. I'm not coaching.

Book wise I've been rather haunted by a science fiction novel I read a couple of weeks back. It was something like a British Philip K. Dick or Jack Womack book about how the world has decayed environmentally to the point where Mass Suicides are sanctioned by the government and are a regular event as people seek to escape. A really disturbing book about belief that my mind keeps returning to. Dark Heavens by Roger Levy if you're interested.

Finally, the picture is from my window at 7.30 this morning. One thing I like about this time of year is the light, though I can never quite catch it exactly. Not the way Edward Hopper does.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's unusual for me to watch a proper French Art Film and having just finished spending three hours watching one I remember why. I can't decide whether it was absolute rubbish or if it was completely brilliant. All that lyrical talking makes my head hurt. Anyway it's called 'King's and Queen' and is available on DVD for anyone that is interested. If you watch it, let me know what you think. I reckon having invested three hours of my life watching it makes me want to convince myself it was good!

It did get me thinking that having not written on here for a while I could use it to make a record of the best things I've watched, seen and read over the summer for myself and anyone who may wish to check things out. And what with school finally starting tomorrow, now is the time to do it. So here in no particular order are my hi-lights from the last four months of books, films and music. By the way, the sidebar with the books and music lists takes you straight to the Amazon page for each item :

Music - There's so much I've been exposed to in four months it's hard to narrow it down, some great individual tracks as well as albums, but here's six recent repeat plays from the album selections:

Juana Molina - Tres Cosas : Supplied by Neil and it's been on a lot this week. She has a great voice, this Argentinian singer. Some kind of electronica folk thing.

Extra Golden - OK-Oyet System: I came across this lot on the Thrill Jockey Label website, home of post-rock bands and it's Kenya meets US Indie rock. Sprawling tracks, but I like it cos it's different.
