Micah P. Hinson - Micah P. Hinson and the Opera: Another donation from Neil to my collection. I've been listening to a lot of Country as usual, the true home of melancholy music. This album is beautiful. (Sackville and Sin Ropas deserve a mention too.)

The Triffids - Born Sandy Devotional: Sort of Australia's version of Country and a re-visitation for me after some years. Still plenty of brilliant tracks on here. Tender is the Night is outstanding.

Dangermouse - The Grey Album: Dangermouse came to my attention because of Gnarls Barkley and he's now working with Sparklehorse too. This is his mix of Jay-Z's The Black Album with The Beatles The White Album. Strange, but addictive.

Richard Hawley - Cole's Corner: Essentially an impression of Scott Walker circa 1965, but enjoyable nonetheless and I keep going back to it.

Books, also lots to choose from, another six here:

Irrationality: The Enemy Within by Stuart Sutherland: Probably something everyone should read. Brought to my attention from a posting on the Bad Science website forum about the best science books. A systematic description of ways in which humans are irrational and the consequences by a clinical psychologist. Funny as well as chilling at times.

The Rise and Fall of the Third Chimpanzee by Jared Diamond : A good companion to Irrationality. This book is an explanation of our animal heritage, the ways in which humans are unique and the ways in which we are like other animals. It is also a description of how we have spread around the world and what we have done in the process. It flags up loads of unanswered questions too. A great book for anyone who wonders like me 'Why are things the way they are?'.

Practical DemonKeeping by Christopher Moore and The Devil You Know by Mike Carey : I put these two together cos they are both horror novels, with comedy thrown in. Sounds bad, but Christopher Moore made me laugh more than any other author this summer. The Mike Carey book is set around near where I work in London so I liked that aspect.

Forty Signs of Rain by Kim Stanley Robinson : Why more novelists don't write about Global Warming I don't know. While a lot people seem to be getting incensed about what some women wear on their heads or whatever is today's immediate issue of apocalyptic concern, this is probably the real misery maker and killer sneaking up on us all. It's the subject of this novel, but he covers a lot of related ground. I don't particularly like his US-centric view, but I do like the way he makes Scientists into heros! This is the first in a trilogy, part two is also available.

Two Way Split by Allan Guthrie: Couldn't leave out a crime novel. A recent Scottish novel with undertones of Jim Thompson.

Films - I never seem to make it to the cinema these days and of all the media where I think, 'I've seen that before, only better...' (A sure sign of getting old) Film is the one that suffers the most. So I've only got four recent viewings on DVD worth a mention, (Kings and Queen I've already written about):

Shaolin Soccer : Kung Fu Hustle, also by Stephen Chow is better, but this is very good too. For shear imagination I've not seen much to match his stuff in the last year. Comedy and martial arts might sound awful, but the fact it is so surprising kept me enthralled, I never knew what was going to happen next. One moment it's a crazy fight, then a dance sequence, then slapstick. Got five year old Stan's seal of approval too.

Iron Monkey : A Nineties Kung Fu classic. Don't mess with the King Kong Paw.

King's Game : An excellent Danish Political Thriller. (No, really!). Maybe more like a TV show than a Film - I tend to think of a Film as something that tells you stuff through pictures and sounds, not words (which is why I hate voice-over) though sometimes a lot of talking is okay - but it gripped me and was original enough to leave me satisfied.

Looking at my choices it is very male dominated, only one women on the list. Maybe this is just the natural bias in me. I do consume work by women muscians/writers/film makers too, but this is what I've selected this time around and I still think there's some good stuff for everyone in there.

There's no picture this time because I haven't taken any recently and the reason the numbers jumped from 21 to 23 is because as often happens when what I write things, I started writng 22 and then decided it was idiocy and didn't post it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Al, I have missed your posts. The fact that I have not heard of any of the music films or books that you have ctitiqued does of course mean that I am living in another world (I have heard of Shaolin soccer having said that :)) Actually I AM living in another world. India. A place where the rules on roundabouts are totally opposite to those of the UK. If you are coming onto a roundabout here you have right of way. If you are already on the roundabout you have to give way..... ????!!!! Mad Mad Mad. See more on www.delhidigest.blogspot.com Hope you hava a successful year at uni. Sanjiv

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
I was thinking about my weblog today and thinking about how (copyrights not withstanding) I wish I could make it like a scrapbook of all my favourite current bits of TV, Books, Music etc.
My computer is slowly evloving into this kind of thing anyway - although not TV clips - and it would be nice to share some of the stuff I come across in a sort of 'Try before you buy' kind of way. It'd be nice to see what other people find too.

One of the things I'm currently reading is a novel by Kim Stanley Robinson. I've never been too sure about this author, there's something I can't quite put my finger on, but is unsatisfying about his work. Maybe it's the characters, maybe the US-centric view of the world. However in his favour, he is one of the few authors I've come across willing to bring together big ideas from across the sciences and make novels out of them. His current series, of which I picked up book two in my local library, is about global warming. The thing that has struck me reading it so far is why aren't there more novels about this?
A particular bugbear of mine over the years is when I hear someone comment something along the lines of, "There is no such thing as absolute truth." It is correct to say, as far I am aware, that scientists cannot say things with strict absolute certainty, but they can say things to a degree of certainty fine enough to make this computer work and allow us all to go on holidays without our planes crashing. The point is that Truth is determined by the boundaries within which one is working. How true does it have to be before one is convinced?
Well, if I compare one report suggesting a link between the MMR vaccine and autism and then subsquently discover that NO follow up studies - that's none, not even one out of the 31 I'm aware of - find any link at all, I'd say that's true enough for me and yet many people are still hestitant about vaccinating their children.
There have been 449 cases of measles in the UK in 2006 up to June compared with 77 in 2005 and in April this year the UK had it's first measles death in 14 years according to the BBC. The child was unvaccinated, although also suffering from an underlying lung conditon.
One of the things that I find frustrating about people still saying stuff about absolute truth is that this discussion was put to bed in the scientific community by people like Guass and Boltzmann in the 19th Century and then by Hesienberg in the early part of the 20th. It's testement to how little or how slowly ideas filter down to society at large from science and where Hesienberg is concerned, how mangled they get along the way.
The irony is that I tend to find that most of us behave as though we have absolute entitlements to a certain way of life and our own particular behaviours, which brings me back to global warming. As a phenomena it's not something I claim to understand in detail, but I do understand how many people from different areas of science are really concerned about what is happening.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Back to misanthropy corner after two weeks camping in France and I'm no closer to figuring out what a person obsessed with television and kinda interested in everything else is supposed to do with life.I find I've been missing some fine TV. Steve Coogan, Rob Brydon and Armando Innaucci all having programmes stuck on in the summer schedules which although not perfect have been enough to force much laughter out of me since my return. And Charlie Brooker keeps lifting his material from my blog, recommending Civilisation, Ascent of Man and The Wire on his Screenwipe show. His impression of Jonathon King is uncanny. It's not that I even particularly like TV but I am obsessed with it, no doubt about it. (I blame Globecast for getting me into Love Island Aftersun though.)

Anyway, holidays. The first picture shows the route we took (in pink, the black dots are where we stayed), first across to Normandy, travelling over 2500 km around France.
It ended up being a holiday of bridges and churches, crossing two of the largest cable stay bridges in the world: The Pont du Normandie and the Millau Viaduct as well as visiting the 1000 year old Roman Aqueduct, The Pont du Gard. This and the Millau bridge can be seen above. The deck of the Millau bridge runs at the height of the observation deck of the Empire State building in New York and is over 2 km long. I doubt it will still be there in a thousand year's time, but it is an impressive example of the current abilities of engineers and designers just as the Pont du Gard reflects the state of Roman society in that they could and did build such complex and long lasting infrastructure. I guess Millau reflects just how much we love cars!

Churches also reflect the changing nature of societies over the years. The course has given me more insight into why buildings are the way they are and one of a church's main functions is to impress. How impressive a building is tends to be limited by money and technological ability. So we visited a Baptistery in Poitiers that dates back to Roman times which was a small simple brick design and without stained glassed windows. The windows were in fact made of thin pieces of marble and it was decorated inside with beautiful fresco's. This contrasts greatly with the largest Gothic Cathedral in Europe at Amiens. Huge, complex and carved from limestone with flying buttresses and tall columns. It was decorated all over with intricately carved figures and large stained glass windows. While I can imagine this being very impressive to a person from the middle ages, being from the twentieth century it was the Chapel at Ronchamp, pictured above that impressed on me most. This is a building from the 1950s by Le Corbusier and to me reflects both the change in material use that came about with the development of concrete and steel at the start of the twentieth century and also the change in mindset a product of the intellectual changes in the preceding 100 years. This is just my interpretation, but I see here a building where the concept of a church has been taken apart, just as scientists and engineers were taking apart materials and ideas. It has then been reconstructed through the mind of an artist to make something new in a way impossible before. For example, in a Gothic church one finds the Nave, a vaulted ceiling resembling the hull of a boat, hence the name, the point upwards a necessary part of its structural strength. At Ronchamp this has been inverted, so the point is inwards and it floats above the roof, a shape only possible then using reinforced concrete and this creates something new, yet reminiscent of something familiar. And it's like that throughout making it somehow surprising and reassuring at the same time, which is how I found it impressive.
In The Ascent of Man, Bronowski comments that one of the features of Art contrasted with Science is that one can witness both the Artist taking the World apart and putting it back together in their work. We see the process as well as the outcome. (It strikes me that this is one reason why Science will never have the mass appeal of Art. One really has to do Science to find it interesting, but one is given access to Art directly through consumption which is in its self a form of participation.) I think this view of Art can be extended to reading the world we live in and I find it interesting to know and see how things have ended up the way they are and seeing this stuff gives me some clues about that.
The last chapel we visited was near Dieppe and is the burial place of the Cubist painter Braque who had made some of the stained glass windows there, one of which I've included here too.

Those are the cultural highlights for me. We also did plenty of drinking and eating: Cheese, Croissants, Eclairs, Wine etc. And we had our obligatory disaster with the exhaust coming apart on Phil's car. That held us up for a couple of days. The weather was a bit hit and miss: Hot and dry in the South. Cold and wet in the North. And windy everywhere. The Sunset picture is from the Poitiers campsite.

The only other thing of note I've done recently was the Pier to Pier charity swim at Bournemouth the week before I went away. I've never done a long open water swim, so it was quite an interesting experience. I don't know how people can swim the Channel though - it's too boring. 44 min 38 sec. was my time over the course distance of 2.35 km. My T15 pace is around 1000m so if I could maintain that pace over the course it would equate to a 35-36 minute swim, which I'd be well pleased with.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's hot enough to make my computer malfunction and the air is full of the organic stink of life, even two stories up in my building.
I was on the beach just ten days ago in Wales huddled around a fire to keep warm for my biannual June camping trip. If the scientists are right, this is just a taste of the extreme weather to come in future years...

Anyhow, I got my exam results today which is the purpose of this post.

The headline figure is that I managed a year average of 74.3% which means I met my own target of 70%.
So that's good and if I was to achieve that every year I'd get a first class degree. (None of this year's grades actually counts towards my final degree.)
The full breakdown is as follows, the grades are module averages, for some reason we don't get separate exam and coursework grades, so I don't know my actual exam marks:

Materials 76%
Structural Mechanics 64%
Mathematics 65%
Graphics and Communication 80%
Structures 82%
Numerical Analysis 78%
Surveying 69%
Engineering Design 84%
Geology 74%
Hydraulics 71%

Of these I'm most pleased with Hydraulics, as it is probably the hardest subject conceptually. The Mathematics is a bit disappointing and demonstrates my problems with exams, as I was averaging 90% in the coursework and it's probably my favourite subject! I'm a bit of a tortoise when it comes to Maths and as one of our lecturers said, "If you are having to think during the exam, the battle is probably lost already."

Since I finished I've been fortunate to be getting a lot of paid work and it provides a nice counterpoint to this educational work and its measurement of success. At work, a successful day is one where things go smoothly and according to plan and no one gets too angry or upset about anything, rather than a simple statistic.

I keep mulling over whether or not to quit the course for several reasons:

One is the financial costs of studying, even with working my old job, I'm accruing around £5000 of debt a year in student loans. Two years in and three to go.

Secondly, I've always had a chip on my shoulder since school about being stupid and not up to achieving in Education and I know that I can do it now, so a part of my motivation for doing this is now gone.

Thirdly, there is the subject itself and near constant state of frustration I find in studying it and that my future will be difficult when and if I graduate. If I try to have a career working in the Industry, I've been told my age is against me and that the alternative is to pursue a career in Academia as a researcher.

So what to do? I dunno.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Difficult decision, but you should stay the course. Just because age is against some people, it isn't a problem if you can show an exceptional talent. Also - you could always come back and work here - I'm sure we could find a job for you...
Since you're dissatisfied with the course you opted for why not try a year of one of the other pathways that were open to you after the Foundation year?

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's the end of the first year of my degree and I thought I ought to write some kind of summary of what I've done in the last eight months.

Douglas Coupland in 'Hey Nostradamus!' describes everyone carrying a 'glory meter' around with them. This is an invisible device that prompts one to say things that help to convey to others the sense of the importance of ones existence such as, "Ken says I make the best coffee outside of Italy." or "I once nearly won the Southern England Go-Kart Championships." This is instead of just regarding ones life all just being a futile and pointless exercise - my default setting. (By the way, I make OK coffee, I don't know anyone called Ken and I haven't ever been in a Go-Kart competition.)

So this is the opportunity to crank my glory meter into action.

I don't what this says about my priorities, but the thing I feel best about from the last eight months is swimming ten kilometres last week. It's the first time I done over 10k in a week, over 4 sessions and I did a 3k session for the second time only. This following on from the formal establishment of a new Masters swimming club here. And I did 100m in 1m 16s, which I think is a PB, though times are not really that important to me. Some people meditate, some take drugs or any number of things to find some peace of mind. For me the endless task of trying to cut perfectly through the water gets me close. Running also comes close, but oddly I usually feel less self conscious in the pool. (My millionaire's fantasy involves having my own 50 metre pool.)
To give some perspective, Australian Olympian Grant Hackett swims about 70k a week in his training. And I did my 10k in about 4 hours, he's probably doing 10k about every 2.5 to 3 hours. I learnt to swim properly in 2000, so I'm pleased with my progress. 

Second to all this, but taking far more of my time has been the course. It's been toughest in the sense of time as the workload is pretty relentless for engineers (of all sorts). I think this is partly to do with the fact that engineering is a place where 'the real world' and scientific theory meet - a bit like medicine I guess, mostly less dangerous, sometimes more - so we have to switch gears constantly between thinking about something purely abstract such as Maths and the practicalities of actually doing something like a building a power station with all the possible consequences.
This year has been about doing some core subjects that affect almost everything in the built environment, so that's - Maths, Structural Mechanics (aka Newtonian Physics), Geology, Surveying, Materials, Hydraulics (aka Fluid Mechanics), Computer Programming, Graphics and Communications.
Here's a theoretical example of why all this is necessary: If London doesn't have enough electricity generation for all the people and all their stuff, how does that get sorted? Well, first one needs a plan and for a plan as much as one should have imagination, one must consult and discuss with the public and people in power the options and consequences of each option. So there's the Graphics and Communication requirement. And when drawing up a range of options, one must do the sums correctly and make a correct assessment of possible options, which is where all the Maths, Physics and Geology etc. comes in. There'd be no point in advocating a wind farm if the soil on a site isn't strong enough to support the windmills, or building a gas fired power plant on a flood plain for example. When a plan is agreed upon, the design must be done in detail, so the knowledge of materials comes into play. For example a real piece of steel is not like a theoretical, perfect piece of steel and knowing the differences and limitations is essential. And I've talked about the significance of being able to measure things accurately before. Once a plan is agreed upon, all the abstract calculations created during this process must be then conveyed as a design that can be worked from and understood by everyone working on the project and ultimately communicated to the public/users. So there should be a sense in which communication skills and the science become integrated in the mind of a engineer. Sadly, this often isn't the case and hence the reputation for the poor social skills of engineers.
So what I've been doing is following one process of learning scientific theories and then translating that into a design process, which then eventually becomes the built environment we inhabit. We've really only just been introduced to things, even working as hard as we do and I do find it quite mind blowing if I think about how complicated things actually are for any length of time!
Personally, I'd like to broaden it out even more, as the moral and ethical questions all this raises are peripheral to the course. As I've said before it affects everyone, but most people are not able to or don't choose to engage with this world changing process.
I should probably clarify that design from an engineering point of view is primarily about making something that is safe more than how it looks and feels. Aesthetics are really a form of engineering specialisation, such as being an architect. Originally, there was no distinction between Civil Engineers and Architects, but increased complexity inevitably leads to specialisation. Still, as almost everything has to be done as part of team process, it's generally misleading when people say something was 'designed' by one genius individual. There may well be a leader, but they have to draw from the ideas and expertise of a whole range of people and find ways to integrate competing priorities and a design in the general sense is the outcome of this process.
In terms of my day to day, the course has two halves, a lot of working through engineering problems based on our lectures, essentially Maths and Physics and secondly doing laboratory work, experiments and field visits based on material from the lectures. The latter half generating reports, of which I've written somewhere between 20,00 and 30,000 words in the last three months.

Following on from my soaking up of 'Civilisation', I got hold of the next series David Attenborough commissioned. It's a kind of companion piece to 'Civilisation', with a splendidly sexist title, 'The Ascent of Man'. Once one has got past the jarring way everything has a male prefix - it was made in 1973 - it's a brilliant account of the evolution of global societies through environmental conditions and 'scientific' discovery. This juxtaposes nicely with the previous series account of Western European society through Art and Architecture. I put scientific in quotes because science as separate discipline is a relatively recent phenomena, but ultimately it was experimentation by humans (or man, as this series prefers!) that led to the progress from hunters to the kind of technological society we have today. One thing that struck a chord with me was the highlighting of how its the interaction between humans and their discoveries, not the discovery itself, that is the key point in determining what happens next. Having the luxury of time to think and reflect is only possible once humans moved beyond just surviving and Jacob Bronowski shows how this happened and what was necessary for it to happen.

Now I have nearly four months before I return to studying. Having just finished today, I'm a bit shocked at the ending of such an intense period of time and don't really know how I feel about it or even what I should feel about it. I think mostly that life is disappointing whatever one does.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: (I think I'm commenting on Blog #19 - 7 Jun 06) Aside from your opening and closing comments of life being futile, pointless and disappointing you seem to communicate the content, relevance and direction of your course and studies very well. Perhaps your vocation lies in communication; the translation of the engineering concepts into reality through your good and concise communication of the ideas and feedback that are obviously necessary to the completion of projects. In this way your training as an engineer could help tackle '... the reputation for the poor social skills of engineers' using your undoubted '...sense in which communication skills and the science become integrated in the mind of an engineer.'

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's nice when I see people and they say they like my blog and ask when I'm gonna post again, as my usual attitude in life is that 99% of the things I think of to say are not worth saying and the 1% that I think is, on reflection, actually isn't either . So I either write it and delete it or don't bother in the first place. But here I am again:

The picture on the left here is from the week I spent in Derbyshire as part of my course making a map aka surveying. It was a hard week,as it was quite a physically and mentally strenuous activity - walking up and down the hills for 8-10 hours a day doing something that is repetitive yet requires a high level of precision. And working with five 19 year old boys, whose personalities ranged from Kevin The Teenager to fully functioning Adults. I hope at some point to be able to upload the map and some photos for anyone who cares to see. The area was about the size of three or four football pitches and took five days to map.

Apart from the confirmation that I do not want to be a surveyor, the thing it got me thinking about again was the invisibility and necessity of engineering. When I got back I watched the end of the Civilisation series I've mentioned before in which he describes the humanising (and de-humanising) effects of Engineering from the 19Th and into the 20Th Century. It was one of the thoughts I had as I stood in the rain with a tripod and theodolite measuring angles, that this is the sort of problem (i.e. making maps) that needs to be solved in order for a society to evolve to the point where people can do things like have discussions about Heat magazine or gender roles in society or Privacy or are Mac's better than PCs or whatever. Of course people can discuss these things without maps or Engineering developments, but I can't help thinking it's the infrastructure engineering has created that has been central to these things coming into existence.

Which tied into other thoughts I'd been having about how so much of the Engineering (and therefore society) we have is a product of history and expediency rather than grand planning. Here's a for instance: We've been studying Water Wheels in Fluid Dynamics. Up to about 150 years ago these were really popular in England and helped start the industrial revolution for powering factories and mills etc. This was the early days of formal science and engineering practice, so research was not really a well established field and most of what was known about water wheels was from trial and error. When coal and then oil was discovered as a source of power, this technology was more or less abandoned, people looked at fossil fuels as being infinite in supply and didn't consider the long term consequences. So here we are today having built our global infrastructure around fossil fuels wondering about all the problems both social and environmental we've created and what to do about them. That's a whole other story, my point here is that no-one knows what Water Wheels are capable of because no-ones ever asked properly.
It's part of a familiar theme from me, '"Why don't people try to see how it all fits together? And why are they all in their little boxes thinking their bit is the important bit when it's all important?" followed by a big sigh and the sound of me opening another beer and then hitting the delete key.

It's fair to say I don't like my course very much, but when I think about quitting one of the few things that stops me is that I feel to need to actually have some understanding of how things work in order to have the right to have an opinion on them (and potentially to do something.) And it bothers me that most people seem to be under the impression that truth is just some semantic subjective thing that cannot be tested in some way and that this belief then undermines attempts to discuss why the hell so many people are still living short painful lives and that inequality is the default setting for human life. 

In many conversations over the years I've said I think Art and Science are the essentially the same thing, a drive to express/understand something about the nature of Reality and our experience of it. And so it is with Engineering. Though I sometimes wonder if Engineers egos are even more out of control than those of Artists and Scientists, as they keep getting together and imposing monstrosities such as Chernobyl on the world. So when I'm back downloading our map data onto the laptop and it draws a little map representing all our hard work, boring as it was to do, I'm blown away at the ingenuity it took for someone to figure out how to do that and all the things maps allow us to do.
And I'm also thinking what questions aren't being asked that should be? What problems aren't being solved that should and could be? What would it be like if everyone thought a little about this stuff - how it works and why we got where we are - asked questions and held all our leaders to account?
As often happens I find myself back with Adam Smiths Invisible Hand. The hand is good, it just needs guidance and that is a product of inquiry - what does self-interest really mean?

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded: I've been out of the flat, working and socialising, which is a strange experience after a period of solitude, and have been encouraged to continue writing/ranting on here. I'm entertaining one person anyway.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It has been a very long three months since I had either the time or inclination to post on here. Coursework and Exams endlessly in succession, so that when I handed in my final piece of work for this term a short while ago, I thought, 'What next?' and was a bit confused to find there is nothing I'm supposed to be doing right now. My next deadline isn't for a month. Allegedly, the Engineers have the fullest timetable of all students and it certainly feels that way.

So it's all been a bit grim really, I've probably learnt quite a lot, but there's been little pleasure in the process and my toleration levels for being around other people have been at an all time low.

Since Xmas, the emphasis has moved more from theoretical understanding to empirical based ways of understanding. This is really then the difference between pure science and Engineering. In Maths a purely analytic solution to a problem - one based on equations - to describe reality is sometimes (though far from always) possible. Such as Pi r-squared to describe the area of a circle.
Many situations, and the ones Engineering is concerned with, require solutions which are essentially very good approximations derived from what is actually observable, through experiments and tests which produce numbers with a real world meaning, such as the strength of a material like steel. And if that sounds simple, here's a Betrand Russell quote that neatly sums up my feelings about trying to design a concrete beam to a level of confidence that it won't fall down and kill anyone,

"Everything is vague to a degree you do not realise until you have tried to make it precise."

A block of concrete, how complicated can that be? Very! And then there's other stuff, like how do fluids flow? How does one make sense of the Earth, it's age and formation and behaviour? Little of it is intuitive and these things all coincide in the real world of building stuff, so the level of complexity soon gives rise to the conclusion of how limited we would be without computers to deal with the calculations. My tutor said to us the other day, 30,000 equations on a civil engineering project is a small number. Hence we also have to get some understanding of how computers really work, so that we can have confidence in the models we create for testing and the answers they produce.

Now depending on whether or not you care about the True Nature of Reality in an objective sense, (I do but I have no justification as to why, in fact I'm sure it doesn't matter at all really, it's just another way to pass the time) this is all very interesting. Then someone (a tutor or guest lecturer usually) goes and ruins it all with a more human interpretation of reality, the profit motive and it all becomes very boring and it becomes clear why we live in such a rubbish world of crap buildings and starving people.

It is very paradoxical to me how Adam Smith's Invisible Hand of Self Interest can drive us to produce all this amazing understanding and technology and Art etc. while at the same time promoting inequality and mediocrity. I was thinking about Standardisation the other day (standard sizes of paper, distances, screws etc.) and how life as we have it now would be impossible without it (and yet people still can't give up the mile or the inch) but how when it is a tool used for profit it produces the blandness of ubiquity - imagine a world of only Ikea furniture and Ipods. Doesn't matter how good something is, without variety it becomes oppressive.

So I don't know just how possible it will be for me to ever make a career in Civil Engineering be an experience that is about more than just making a profit, if I ever get a degree, but if it isn't I'll just have to study Maths part-time and learn about Reality whilst living in reality.

As I've been spurning human company, (other than to swim with and one can't talk and swim at the same time) I've been cutting the Engineering by watching DVDs. In particular Kenneth Clark's 1969 series Civilisation, which is a documentary series about the history of Western Europe since the Romans through Art and Architecture. I can't recommend it highly enough. One you get past how slow it is (this is a good thing) and have taken on the dated nature of some of his opinions (it is pretty much exclusively male), it's genuinely uplifting. It's all about humanity, the desire to be better and understand more and how this becomes expressed through Art. My favourite quote so far comes from the 12th century Cardinal, Pierre Abelard:

"The beginning of wisdom is found in doubting; by doubting we come to the question and by seeking we may come upon the truth."

I wonder what he'd make of all the fundamentalism and dogma in the world today? And watching this series serves to make me more passionate about the need for reason over nonsense and mumbo jumbo and blind acceptance of irrational rubbish that goes on everywhere I look from my own classroom to the News and our political and business leaders. And how the battle against prejudice and inequality is endless and must be fought daily in small ways everywhere.
It would be so sad if the idiots win and drag us back down when all these people like Abelard and the Artists in this series have striven so hard to civilise the world. I think it's well known I'm not a big fan of humans, but this does show some of their best aspects and if you like Art and being made to think in new ways about why things are the way they are, then this is for you.

On the other hand, you might prefer to watch The Wire, the best TV show not available on TV. I've mentioned it before, but it's so good if you like crime drama. And I mean crime in the widest sense, not narrow cops and robbers simple stuff. All human life is there in the Wire. Rent it from Amazon.

Well, I didn't really think about this much in advance, so if it makes no real sense I'll have to edit it later cos it's time to go to the Pool. We had the Annual Swimming Gala last week which I was in for the first time - 2nd in the T-shirt race - what a result!

And I just stuck in a picture from my geology field trip to the Isle of Wight where I had lunch on the beach on the one spring day this year so far.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
"Science is a way of trying not to fool yourself. The first principle is that you must not fool yourself and you are the easiest person to fool" Richard Feynman, 1964.

13 weeks to go to the end of my PhD - well, of my money anyway. It's reached that point where it's become a real monkey on my back.

And I keep meaning to write something down, but it's been such busy and hard year so far, my thoughts are largely negative. But it will also be over soon and I've documented nothing of my thoughts and feelings this year.

I try not to over-think, which is tricky for someone who has been described as hypervilgilant (you know who you are). But I had one of those"This is it" moments last week when I was at ParkRun. I was running across the Common, one lap to go, trying to catch my team mate Mark in the golden September sunshine tracking three swans flying close overhead like miniature Concords. Not for the first time, but for the first time in a while I found myself talking to myself, "This is it. This is your life. Some of these trees were here before you and some will be here long after you've gone. Everyone running here, the swans and the other creatures will die and we'll all be forgotten and eventually the Universe will die too. You're a speck and it's not fair and there's no meaning other than what you choose to give it. So remember to at least try and enjoy it and use it as wisely as you can. This is what you get."

So I thought I better write something, anything, down for my own benefit.

The first three months of the year I remember as dash to try and progress experiments that have been on-going without success for over 2 years now. Then it was off to Cambridge for three months at my co-sponsors Microsoft Research.

I tried really hard to enjoy my time in Cambridge, but it was mostly an intense experience that I was doing my best to survive. It perhaps didn't help that my lodgings were not ideal, but other than that everyone was very welcoming.

Then it was back to Southampton for another month of trying to get the experiments working and then off to work on the Olympics in TV. Which was hard work, but successful and very instructive in reminding me of both the differences and similarities between academia and industry. On balance, I came away thinking that my time is more valuable to me than money, so while I can and would do either, at the moment I still value the academic route to the industry one - if they'll have me.

Now it's head down and try to get things finished - which is perhaps the major issue for me with academia, things never seem satisfactorily complete! Which as "hurry up, completer" (you know who you are too) I find really annoying.

Hmmm...just realised I've labelled myself twice in this post. I hate labels.

I'm writing this whilst I wait for my samples to de-frost so I can set-up an experiment to run overnight. Not often I work on the weekend, but needs must.

Changing the subject entirely, props to Phil for sending me Sight and Sound with their Greatest Films of All Time poll. This of course got me making my own list, although I only managed 7 out of 10 so far!

1. The 400 Blows

2. Tokyo Story

3. 35 Shots of Rum

4. Once upon a time in Antolia

5. Breathless

6. The Bicycle Theives

7. The Conversation

There are so many other great films I could make a huge list, but these are ones I think are truly great - today!

Discuss.

More later.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yes, I wondered where The Conversation was too. (dir. F. F. Coppola starring Gene Hackman? I am remembering the right one aren't I?)

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Radio

Having had a nice weekend in London, I managed to come down with Norovirus or something similar this week. It completely wiped me out and brought my working year to an abrupt and unplanned end. Nature giving me a reminder of the illusion that is "being in control."

(I'd just given Thea a book on viruses as a present. If I'd stuck around she could have had a real life case-study to accompany the text.)

 Anyhow, the upside of being ill and not spending my time thinking about protein molecules - other than to wish they'd do their job a bit quicker - was listening to the radio. I tend to forget what a great thing it is.

So I've listened to lots of science and current affairs stuff on Radio 4 and music on Radio 6, but my hi-light has been the ﻿The People's Post: A Narrative History of the Post Office.

It's one of those little 15 minute gems that only the BBC make. There are 15 episodes and I know I won't have time to go back and listen to them all, but it is a fascinating way of thinking about the development of our society.

If you only have time for one, follow this link and listen to The Post Code. It's just a perfect documentation of humans response to new technology. Auberon Waugh was pretty much the Jeremy Clarkson of his day. It's also great at demonstrating how we can't know in advance the consequences of new technology.

On the science side I've been enjoying the Infinite Monkey Cage, The Life Scientific and (not strictly speaking Radio) the Guardian Science Weekly.

PhD



Following on from last time and for the uninitiated: a thesis is the argument that is contained within the dissertation that I will have submit in order to receive the Doctor of Philosophy qualification.

In the domain of science, the thesis is generally some novel findings that increase our knowledge about a particular subject.

Without going into detail about unpublished work and being any more boring than is necessary, the general thrust of my work is to push forward our understanding about a key protein in our immune system that helps protect us against viruses, cancer and autoimmune disease.

It'll be a tiny, little incremental step forward if I get there, but such is the complexity of biology, progress is hard-fought.

And although I work under the banner of Cancer Science - there really is no way at present for it to have any meaningful impact the treatment of cancer. Maybe one day it'll be a useful piece of the puzzle, maybe never, but that's the beauty of science, no-one really knows in advance what will turn out to be useful!

My favourite quote of the week - definitely going on my heuristic list - "Science is the best way we have of not fooling ourselves" from Jon Butterworth.

The work itself is a kind of dance between computational, mathematical methods and experimentation.

I was aiming to get a purely computational component of my work looking at how the structure of the protein moves finished before Christmas, but failed! Once that's done, I'll be back in the lab trying to bring to fruition the experimental component that has been ongoing for nearly two years without a lot of success. Then in March I'm off to Cambridge for three months to develop another computational model and hopefully learn some new Maths. Then it's back to Southampton to finish up and write a thesis.

By the end of 2012 then I would aim to have some coherent new insights regarding the structure of the protein and its behaviour in forming a complex - that is to say a larger molecule comprising of three different molecules - that together can trigger an immune response in our bodies.

Ultimately it's about delivery. If I deliver something new and meaningful then it's possible that there will be more money to do more research. That's how it works and it's highly competitive and we're all feeling the pressure in my group.

In as much as I have my own work to do, it's really a team effort. I've included here the project map I drew - aka the Tube Map - to depict how everyone currently involved interacts. It gives a sense of how many people and disciplines are involved in untangling something so complicated. My boss Tim is King's Cross as he's involved with every aspect.

The credits list on my dissertation is going to be a cast of thousands at this rate too. A feature of my PhD is that annoying buzzword "interdisciplinary" - which I tend to think of as synonymous with "multi-tasking" i.e. "doing a lot of things badly rather than one thing well". My solution is to rope in as much expertise as possible to help me out and hence the many links I have on the map and many people I have to thank!

When I think of myself I tend to think of myself as an Engineer. I was never really much of an Artist and I'm not much of Scientist, but I have some aptitude for problem solving, getting stuck into the unglamourous stuff and getting things done - albeit imperfectly - which is what I think Engineer's do. My friend Hannah used the term "a hurry-up, completer" once and I think that fits me quite well. Getting on and doing is the best way to fight the crushing existential angst and fear that comes from having nothing to do or things being unresolved! (I consider thinking as a type of doing.)

That said, there is an optimum level of busyness where I'm operating at the level of playing. I've heard this said a few times over the years and recently too and I think playing gives the best results. Playing allows my subconscious to get to work, which I think is where the real problem solving gets done. However, most of this year has been operating at level of stress. Too many problems and not enough solutions and it's the opposite of fun and may be partly why my immune system finally cracked!

Many people I've been around or spoken to recently have been feeling the same, only more so. Tough times for a lot of people and generally much more pressing than my little troubles.

I don't know if I'll continue to get the opportunity to carry on getting paid-to-play after 2012, but I'd like to. I'm not ever likely to live a lavish material lifestyle following this path, but it's a pretty decent quality of life when you subtract all the background noise of politics, moaning, money troubles and personality clashes. The noise can be very loud at times!

Art

Honourable mention to Grayson Perry and his exhibition at the British Museum. One of the best exhibitions I've seen in years. His curation of objects from the collection alongside his own work and commentary are just brilliant. His thoughts on Art, Celebrity and the relationship of the Modern World with the Past really resonated with me. His eye for interesting objects and juxtaposition with his own work has such a light touch. I'd never seen his work up close before and he really is a Master Craftsman himself. And as well as being really accessible and intelligent, best of all is how funny he is. One of those exhibitions where I came out thinking, "Yeah, Art is pretty amazing at making me think and feel when it's done well. That guy is definitely an Artist"

Tablet

Just a quick note to say, yes it does everything I want - and I've rediscovered gaming! (Not a good thing) - however it's definitely one for people who like to tinker. Great value for money too, but if you want something to use without messing about and don't care about the specifications I wanted or walled-gardens and all that: Get an iPad! :-)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great review of Grayson Perry's exhibition. Do you mind if I quote it on Facebook to let friends know how good it is? I entirely agree with you about the importance of play as an element in any job. It can lead to a more creative, relaxed, intuitive and curious, more exploratory state of mind which makes the job 'fun' and leads to new discoveries almost without trying. And it makes the day go quicker. The Swedes discovered (many years ago) that the most rounded citizens were those that had had a lot of free play when they were younger. And speaking of 'play', I recommend 'The Mysteries of Lisbon'. It's 5 hours in the cinema but it's worth it. A story constructed very much like (Voltaire's) Candide.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Problem Solving

It kept coming up, so I decided to finally draw up my generic problem solving algorithm as a diagram. If you want proper rigorous analysis then I suggest starting with How to Solve It by George Polya, but this diagram is my heuristic and contains what I call the Zeroth Rule: recognising there is a problem in the first place (aka "Am I in denial?"). Maybe someone will find it useful...

Dawn Simulator

...speaking of which, if you are like me and have (more than usual) trouble getting out of bed at this time of year, then why not make a dawn simulator?

 All you need is a timer switch, a lamp and a daylight frequency bulb.

Stick it away from your bed, so it doesn't shine right in your face when it comes on. Set the lamp to come on 30-20 minutes before your alarm goes off and hopefully it'll be a bit less awful when it does.

It may be placebo, but the science behind it is the fact that we have cells in our eyes that are sensitive to blue frequencies in daylight that regulate the hormones associated with waking up.

Tablet Computer

Next a bit of consumer information.

I've been looking at tablet computers with the stipulation that it must be good for watching TV and Films, listening to music and potentially using as an e-reader - an entertainment device. I also decided that it should have a HDMI output so I can connect it to a TV to play movies, a USB connection for file transfers and have expandable storage with a slot for a flash card. And obviously it needs to be mobile. I don't need 3G.

This ruled out the Ipad for me, but I will give a nod to the fact it is reviewed and I agree from my playing with it, the most complete user experience. By this I mean that it's smooth and works without tweaks. However not the best screen, interestingly.

Having then looked at the Windows and Android options, I realised that I'd need to wait for Windows 8 to come out to get a decent mobile computing experience. Windows 7 is not optimised well for this type of machine, so they got ruled out too. If you're buying next year, Windows 8 has good preview reports, so worth bearing in mind.

This left the Android machines. I narrowed it down to the Asus Eee Pad Transformer and the Motorola Xoom after ruling out the Samsung Galaxy Tab and Sony Tablet S as they didn't meet the requirements - no HDMI or standard USB. Which is a shame, as like the Ipad, they are much more elegant devices than the Xoom or Eee Pad.

In the end it came down to the screen and the price. The Motorola Xoom has the best screen (along with the Sony and Samsung) of all the tablets I've played with, as well as being the cheapest. (This is because it's heavy at 730g and they've just brought the lighter Xoom 2 out.)

I've yet actually purchase one, but the Xoom is now at my price point of £300 and if anyone is interested I'll update you on what it's actually like to live with day to day.

I'm going to use the other half of the money I put aside to replace my broken workstation with a new cheap workstation with the kind of power and proper functionality that the tablet won't have.

PhD

I've got my offer through for my time at Microsoft Research Cambridge, so this means my thesis submission date will be December 2012. Just a year left and it's not a barrel of laughs at all. In fact I'm completely fed up with it. Problems, problems and more problems. That's all I want to say.

Intellectually I know this is a privileged life I'm leading, but emotionally I'm not feeling it!

Hopefully I'll be over this hump by Christmas and then I can write a more descriptive post about what I'm up to.

I hope everyone else is having a good end to the year - if you need a good read, I'm loving The Dervish House by Ian MacDonald at the moment.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Reading List

I thought I'd start with books this time. The picture shows the books I've got in my 'still to read' pile at the moment. I'm lucky if I get through one book a month, so there's enough there to last me until May next year. I've even stopped getting books from the library at the moment - much as I appreciate them, no more please.

My favourite reads from 2011 so far have both been non-fiction, unusually for me, and I can highly recommend them to you:

  • Mistakes were made (but not by me) by Carol Tarvis and Elliot Aronson
  • Supercooperators by Martin Nowak

 Both are popular science books, the first one being a Psychology book and the second a Maths book. What they both share is their attempt to explain why we behave the way we do and both have given me plenty of food for thought.

'Mistakes were made...' is all about self-justification and how people (including me of course) struggle to deal with choices and information that conflict with our self-image and our perceptions about reality. In other words: why we make mistakes and are so bad at facing up to them. This might sound like a depressing read! And certainly it's uncomfortable when one identifies with the examples given. But working from the principal that more information generally increases ones certainty about what to do, it gave me a lot to think about in how better to deal with my own mistakes (and in responding to other peoples) as well as about social policy.

'Supercooperators' is all about using the mathematics of Game Theory to explain the paradox of 'survival of the fittest' as a principal underpinning our diverse natural world that is almost entirely based on cooperation. What I particularly like about the book is that it interweaves the authors story of becoming a scientist with the ideas themselves. It's an inspiring read too, showing the power of simple ideas to explain a range of observations from the small scales of cells to that of societies.

It immediately got me musing on the fact that people are less friendly in cities than in small communities. Following the ideas in the book, I reasoned that due to the lack of repeat encounters in a big city there is less incentive to be nice to someone in the street, as you are far more unlikely to see them again and have either the kindness or the rudeness repaid, than in a small community. Further in a city, your behaviour is less likely to be witnessed by people with who you interact and there is less risk to ones reputation by behaving badly.

I'm presently reading The Count of Monte Cristo, a 1200 page tome that is something of a detective novel precursor, but also has something of the Cowboy genre to it.

TV and Films

Speaking of Cowboys, I've been enjoying the latest series of Justified. Worth a look.

Probably the best thing I've seen this year is Treme, after Neil gave me the DVD for my birthday. It's hard to describe as it's rather meandering as a narrative. However, it's a drama about the lives of people in New Orleans 6 months after Hurricane Katerina in 2006. The music is fantastic and as with everything by David Simon, it's funny and moving in turns.

I finally gave Being Human a go and was pleasantly surprised. The set-up sounded appalling (Vampire, Ghost and Werewolf living together) and the narrative is a bit all over the place and it doesn't really work when it tries to be serious, but when it sticks to funny I thought it was very good.

Not much to shout about at the cinema this year. Perhaps the thing I enjoyed best was Source Code. This was the film Inception wanted to be. A total B-movie, but so much the better for it.

PhD

When I last posted I was about to go to London to try and get my experiments to work - well that was a total failure!

I'm coming into my last year and still have yet to get any experiments to work. The pressure is slowly starting to mount, but I remain at least mildly optimistic that I'll have something working by this time next year.

It would be pretty frustrating to get to the end without anything working in the real world, but I'd be far from the first person to get a PhD without having got their experiments to work. I have a plan for the next few months and Tina did give me some good training at Birkbeck, so I've been able to resurrect the machine in Southampton to continue the experiments here.

On the positive side, in the world of simulation I have one of the biggest computers in the UK to use and I'm making good progress with this part of the work having initiated a collaboration with some colleagues from the Chemistry department. Watch this clip from the BBC to check out our machine.

There is a certain irony that I'm running out of time just when I feel I'm starting to get a handle on the project after 3 years. There's masses to do if we are ever to nail down how our bodies process and present the information which our immune systems use to recognise disease. Although the money is rubbish, the quality of life is pretty good. I spoke to my supervisor about staying on after I finish and I'm pleased to say he'd be happy to keep me on. There is, however the small matter of funding my research and in this financial climate, money is pretty hard to come by. I'm hopeful that a grant can be successfully applied for before my current funding runs out, but it's as least as likely as not that I'll be looking for a job come October 2012.

Running

I've kind of lost my focus a bit since the Marathon and the PhD has become all consuming at times. It's the summer cross country season here at the moment and I'm presently 14th in the table and I'm happy with that.

I did get to run in the London 10k at the end of May as a club athlete. This was fun as I got to warm up with Paula Radcliffe, Jo Pavey and Mo Farah. Professional athletes like them are on another level, yet they were all so friendly to everyone. (The race itself was far too hot and I didn't really enjoy it all!)

And the rest

I feel like there should be more to say, but there really isn't. This is it. I'm always slightly surprised to find that I'm still here, but here I am.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: ...and we're all very glad that you are still here! Whatever the problems are I'm glad they're in the best possible hands. Phil (See you next week!)
Its good to see I'm not the only cheesey cheerleading type in your life... I concur with the previous comment, Yay, go you!

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Running

I completed my first marathon on a lovely spring morning in Paris on the 10th of April.

You can click on this link Paris Marathon Results and enter my bib number 12819 in the number box to search for my result and see videos of me etc.

I've never seen myself running before and I had this image of myself being smooth and graceful, rather than the wonky, slightly mincing style I actually have!

It was a surprise to me how much I enjoyed the marathon. I'd expected I'd enjoy Paris, but I expected the race iteslf would be hard and uncomfortable. In reality I was caught up in the atmosphere and ran round with a smile on my face all the way. They printed our names on our bib and the cheers of 'Allez Alistair' and high-fives from spectating kids were particulary fun. There were supporters and bands and cheerleaders along the whole course as well as all the sites of Paris to see. I did find it a bit uncomfortable once I got past 20 miles, but I never felt like stopping or had any real pain. My strategy of walking 20 seconds through every mile marker seemed to work pretty well. As did my homemade sports drink. The only downside was getting a bit of heatstroke and having to sleep for 14 hours afterwards.

There is something kind of absurd about running 26.2 miles and I don't feel a tremendous urge to do it again, but I am thinking about another one for next year. Next up is the summer cross country season here and the BUPA 10k on the 30th of May in London...more of my absurd idea of fun.

PhD and the rest

I just need one decent set of data and then I'll have something to write a PhD dissertation about! Sadly this always seems just over the horizon.

I got a bit fed up a couple of months ago when it finally dawned on me that my supervisors don't have the expertise to guide me towards the goals they have set! Fortunately my principal supervisor is supportive of my delcared intention to go and get the expertise I need however I can. So I've made contact with an experienced kineticist in London and will be up at UCL in May to try and do the experiments under her guidance. 

I'm actually writing a short essay for one of my sponsors about doing science, so maybe I'll post that here when it's done.

Something that's come up a few times recently is what I shall call My Heuristics for Life. Or Rules of Thumb, if you prefer. It's a list I've been compiling, deleting and editing for about ten years or so. It's been pointed out to me that it is similar and to the estascatological laundry list of Sheldon Kopp. And I can't claim any great original thoughts, most of them are other peoples thoughts that struck me as worth remembering, but here's the current version for anyone else that might find it useful:

  1. Be kind. This is entirely practical. There’s not much to be gained by being mean, but there is a lot to lose.
  2. If you are not for yourself, who is? If you do not look after yourself how can you be of use to anyone else?
  3. Blaming yourself or other people when things go wrong is essentially a useless activity.
  4. If you do the same old things, the same old things keep happening.
  5. Don’t agonise over decisions too much. Whatever you decide, chances are you will end up convincing yourself you made the right choice – even if in fact it was the wrong one!
  6. Perhaps the only useful question when considering the past is: What could I do differently next time?
  7. Generally people are very bad at learning from their mistakes. You only have to be moderately good at learning from your mistakes to be above average!
  8. You tend to find in a place what you bring to it.
  9. Fortune favours the prepared mind. (Louis Pasteur)
  10. Focus on what you can do. Don’t linger on things you can’t control.
  11. If I’m in a bad mood there’s a good chance I need to eat something.
  12. You can have quick or easy, but rarely both at the same time.
  13. What is a journey of a thousand miles, but many small steps repeated?  Big changes are often the sum of many small ones.
  14. When faced with a problem you don’t know how to solve, just try anything new. (But maybe be conservative in what you try!) Chances are it will be wrong, but the new information it yields will be useful for the next iteration.
  15. If you want to be good at anything, it takes practice. And at least 6 months to form or break a habit. Remember this when the initial enthusiasm for something new starts to wear off!
  16. You can do one thing well or many things badly.
  17. However much data you have it’s never enough, but intuition fails more often than not, so in data we trust. If something feels intuitively right, take a moment to look at the data, cos your intuition is probably wrong!
  18. That said, there is no substitute for experience.
  19. What one fool can do, another can. (Richard Feynman)
  20. There’s never a good time to make a change or take a break. If not now, then when?
  21. Being an adult is difficult, but it’s better than being a child.
  22. If you’re not doing it for fun or for money, why are you doing it?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Love that running style...Like an urgent John Inman!

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Science

Having trudged through the snow in my running spikes to the hospital, I looked at my lab book on Friday the 3rd of December after I took the readings that confirmed that I'd finally got a working experiment to note that I had first attempted it on the 28th of January 2010. Apparently this is not an especially long time to take.

Earlier that week I'd commented that what I most wanted for Christmas was a working protein refold and this was what I got. Happy days! I should point out that making protein is only the first step. Protein is the raw materials I need for the experiments proper that I need to do to actually do some novel science, which is what I hope to do in 2011.

Back-tracking a moment: We're trying to understand one of the processes by which our bodies know when we are ill. The strategy (part of the wider project) I'm pursuing is one where we isolate as much as possible individual components of the larger system so we can control and observe their interaction when we put components together. Making these components, these proteins is a tricky business.

What we do is first isolate the DNA from which the protein is made into a molecule called a plasmid (another problem in itself) and then insert this into bacteria (in our scenario) and trick the bacteria into growing and making lots more bacteria, each making lots of the (human) protein using its own protein production machinery. We then kill all the bacteria, split them open and harvest the protein and purify it. The whole process takes one to two weeks. The protein is then like a big tangle of spaghetti and we have to tackle the hardest part of the process, refolding the protein into its natural structure.

Structure and function are intimately related, for example sickle cell anaemia where suffers lose function of their red blood cells is caused by a single mutation in one of the amino acids that changes the shape of their haemoglobin protein.

I want to look at the behaviour of a human protein complex (complex because it actually comprises of three separate proteins that are bound together) called MHC Class I molecules. These proteins are the flags on the surface of our cells that indicate the health status of our cells.

In our bodies, nature has evolved all sorts of mechanisms using proteins to ensure they fold correctly, although it is far from perfect, Amyloidosis being an example of misfolding of proteins that contributes to many diseases such as Alzheimer's and kidney failure.

So in the laboratory, in solution rather than in a cell, it's a matter of biochemistry to try and fold the spaghetti tangle of protein we've expressed from DNA in bacteria. And that's the problem I've been spending much of this year and certainly almost the whole of the last three months trying to acheive. Thankfully I've got it to fold - I don't know why it's worked this time, this will be a matter for further investigation - but now I've got it, I can start doing experiments to understand the MHC Class I molecules behaviour and maybe move the knowledge forward a tiny little bit.

I'd never used a Gilson pipette before January and my left thumb now has calloused skin on the top from time spent using one, while my right thumb is likewise calloused from opening and closing eppendorf tubes. So even my body is starting to resemble that of a laboratory biologist.

I'm just past half-way in the time I have allocated for my PhD. The deadline (academically and financially) is October 2012, so 2011 is likely to be a busy year in which, with luck, I will gather lots of useful data with which to produce some kind of thesis report with. My thesis being something to do with how another protein called Tapasin influences the binding of small proteins to MHC Class I molecules which ultimately determine the immune response.

Running

After a long recovery period, I'm slowly getting my fitness back.Which is a great feeling.

I was re-reading part of one of my favourite books, The Lore of Running where he reflects about what running has taught him about life and I was not entirely surprised to be reminded how many of these reflections I share: the need for solitude, humility, the importance of play, it's role in creative thought and the lessons in honesty, as he says: "There is...no luck in running. Results cannot be faked and there is no-one but yourself to blame when things go wrong." But the thing that struck me that I'd never really thought of as a postive attributes before are the roles of insecurity and failure. He comments that, "...it is in our inevitable failures that the seeds of real personal growth are sown and eventually blossom." And I think that has certainly been true for me so far and that in running (like any worthwhile activity) through the highs and lows, fears and doubts, successes and failures, it teaches me about myself, my limits and my place in the world. 

Anyhow enough of the existential angst...Entirely against my usual philosophy that it is the thing itself that matters, not ego trips, I've signed up for Paris Marathon next spring and the London Triathlon next summer. So if you see me hobbling down the street next year, feel free to quote Tim Noakes comments about only having myself to blame back at me...

And the rest...

It's been so long since I wrote and it's all a blur...I had a holiday to Germany with Phil, Jen and Thea in August. Which was great, although the weather wasn't terribly kind to us. I'd reccomend it to anyone. The bread was a revelation. The Spa's were brilliant. Beautiful scenary in the Black Forest and cool Cities. I should sort out the few photos I took and post them...

Then I did my best man duties at Neil and Laura's Wedding, which all went off without a hitch largely thanks to Laura's hard work and meticulous planning.

Not read too many books or seen much in the way of TV or Films worth mentioning. The Quiet War which I read on holiday is perhaps my best read of the year.

Oh and I made my own Dawn Simulator using a timer switch and cheap Ikea lamp with a Daylight frequency bulb. It may been entirely psychological, but for someone who hates getting up, especially at this time of year, it definitely helps.

It's been a pretty tough year I'd say - but then aren't they all - but I'm finishing in a good position for the next steps. What's that saying? Sometimes you eat the bear and sometimes it eats you. Right now we're about even.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: A very positive blog. A little bit of success makes a world of difference! Worth the wait? Last time we spoke you were quite despondent about carrying on. What a change! So I was surprised when you said 'enough of the existential angst'. I thought your paragraph on the Lore of Running was equally positive - "...it is in our inevitable failures that the seeds of real personal growth are sown and eventually blossom." And I liked the idea of the Dawn Simulator too. (A bit like the joke where the man changes his brown curtains for blue ones.) Good that things appear, after a long time, to be looking up for you. Hope that carries on.

That was quite an inspirational read for me. The thought of someone taking so much trouble to work out solutions to health problems that may affect me one day has never really occurred to me. It is more real as I can visualise the complex, intricate process and the tenacity! Best wishes for the progress next year and the running ambitions.I look forward to seeing the photos.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
All I can do is what I can do - I can't remember if I read it or somebody said it, but it feels like my 2010 mantra.

Sport

Starting with what matters most to me! ;-)

I began a new running programme in January and it was all going really well. My times were coming down and I got a new personal best over 10km of 36 min 50s in March. Then a couple of weeks later I got my first serious sports injury and had to stop running  altogether for 6 weeks and I was walking with a limp for a while.

I damaged a tendon in my right foot, probably a mixture of doing too much, wearing the wrong shoes and ignoring the warning signs and trying to run through it. It was probably the first time I've not run for that long in over 10 years and I didn't take it very well. My big running book cites a study detailing how runners develop an emotional and physical attachment to the sport and to not be able to do it is unthinkable. Well, that is certainly how I found it - unthinkable and unbearable until I finally resigned myself to it. It ruined my chance to improve my position in the summer cross country league as I missed most of the races and I'm only now just starting to reach the point where I can train hard again.

Luckily I know a physiotherapist through the School of Medicine and along with her podiatrist colleague I got great advice and support for free - well, the quid pro quo was being a control in some of their experiments researching rheumatoid arthritis, but that was actually good fun.

The silver lining came through my running club. Quite a few of my colleagues are into Triathlons and they took me out swimming and cycling while I couldn't run. I bought a wet suit and dug my old road bike out of the garage.

Swimming in the sea here has been a revelation. I'd forgotten how great it is and I've been in most weeks since May. You have to drive half an hour to reach the sea from Southampton, but it's fantastic. I did only last 10 minutes in May and my hands were blue when I came out, but I've been able to dump the wetsuit recently.

Cycling too has shown me so much more of the surrounding area. The picture above is from a ride out to the New Forest in July. I don't think I'll ever love cycling or swimming as much as running, but I'm definitely going to do more cross training from now on and I'm thinking about the London Triathlon for next year.

Most recently, I've been offered a place to do the New York marathon in November as part of the Cancer Research UK staff team. I've never run a marathon - 20 miles is as far as I go in training - but it's a tempting offer if I can get fit in time.

Also, I decided to have laser eye correction a few weeks ago too which is going to make sports so much better. I had most of the money from selling my big motorbike sitting around for two years and had still not spent it due to my inability to think of anything I really want or need. (I have enough running shoes.) So I now have 20/20 vision and won't need contact lenses for sport ever again, which is life changing in a small but important way.

PhD

Last Thursday after 6 long weeks, 29,000 words and 133 pages, I handed in my report for my transfer thesis. I will be exactly two years and half way into my time in October and now is the point where I transfer to properly be doing a PhD. (I spent the whole of July without drinking alcohol in a vain hope it would help me get the report done!)

To be blunt - it's not going very well. I put in a lot of time, but I have no real results to show for it and feel so out of my depth most of the time, it's not funny. This is one reason I was running so much and led to getting injured - to cope with the stress.

My supervisors seem to think it will all come good, so I try and hold onto that reassurance, but it's tough to believe it.

Since January I've been in the laboratory at the hospital. We are soon to relocate to our new home in the shiny new Life Sciences building. I've been trying to perform experiments to evaluate whether our model of how our cells tell our immune system whether they are healthy or have diseases inside them is correct. I do this by working with the proteins that exist in our cells. They have been isolated and produced in solution, what we call in vitro.

However, as I'm discovering, most experiments don't work. Getting a working experiment is a real battle, taking months of work, if not years.

In one sense it is a nice quality of life - getting paid to find new stuff out. But ultimately it's a results business, so no-ones going to give me a job if I don't deliver in the end. And I'm aware that the money for what I do comes from people doing things like sponsored runs etc. and so it's not much good if we don't actually push the knowledge forward towards treating cancer better.

In terms of my particular project - and I've only myself to blame for agreeing to this, lest it sounds like self-pity - the problem is trying to master three disciplines of which I have no experience: Cancer Science, Structural Biology and Computational Science.

So like I say - All I can do is what I can do. Here's a quote from my colleague Neil which neatly sums up the situation and is the kind of thing I try to remember when I feel that rising sense of panic about it all:

`I totally understand your concerns, I think that much of it derives from you being “at that part of your PhD” where you are sufficiently familiar with what people have done previously, but figured out how difficult it is to do original research, and now concerned that you have to get the majority of the results that will go in your final thesis within a year!  Rest assured, this is entirely normal.'

And the rest...

Last week I made the decision to sell my house in London, so if anyone wants to live in East London, do get in touch!

My tenants are moving out and I find it hard to imagine ever going back there, even if I moved back to London, so it seemed like a good time to try and sell. I've been trying to simplify my life a bit further this year - so far it's been a horrible year emotionally to be honest and having one less thing to worry about would be good.

At this point I've no idea what happens when October 2012 rolls around, but I want to be as flexible as possible. Right now I just want to go to sleep for a long long time, maybe forever.

I'm off to Germany at the end of the week for some camping, so a break at last and hopefully I'll come back refreshed. Just been picking out my holiday reading for the trip. What follows is what I've read this year so far that I enjoyed and would recommend as worth a look:

Jame Sallis : What you have left

Cory Doctorow: For the Win

James Ellroy: Bloods a Rover

Willy Vlautin: Lean on Pete

Adam Roberts: Yellow Blue Tibia

George Pelecanos: The Way Home

Charlie Huston: Sleepless

China Mieville: The City and the City

Mike Carey: The naming of the beasts (Felix Castor Vol. 4)

Elmore Leonard: Pronto

I see my unconscious bias has led me to choosing all white male authors - this is why I love science, once I start looking at the data I see the truth appear! My prejudices are revealed!

One non-fiction read I'd highly recommend:

Dennis Lindley: Understanding Uncertainty

On TV I've been enjoying Justified which features the cowboy Ranger from the Elmore Leonard book above. It's not exactly deep, but it's entertaining enough.

The best film I've seen this year are, belatedly, is Where the Wild Things Are. It really captured for me what it feels like to be a child. Be interested to know what a child would make of it though.

I really like A Prophet too. This follows the incarceration of a young man in France and his rise in the criminal ranks.

So I'm sure there is lots of stuff I've forgotten that may be of interest to someone from the last 6 months, but it feels like it's been one long week since I updated this blog such is the intensity!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Al, Thanks for the update. Quite a tumultuous time you are are having.??
