Savour it ... relish it.... you have so much knowledge of life and living that you are passing on through this blog. To be quite honest with you my thoughts are. and it is purely my thoughts...I don't give a f"£! whether you get the PHD or not. It is clear how much effort and work and sweat you are putting into this. That I believe, and again I emphasise my opinion only is worth more than the letters PHD. Of course I hope you do get it though ;)) Best of Luck Alistair. Have no doubts..... I hope we can sit and have a beer soon some time.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
I don't especially like having photos taken of me, but for your amusement I'm posting two recent ones.

The top one is of me in the lab at the hospital where I'm working at the moment. I happened to be there when they were taking publicity shots for Cancer Research UK, so I asked for a copy. That look on my face is me trying not to mess up (again). Andy the guy mentoring me is in the background.

The second one is from the last race I ran back in November (not sure it's possible to look good when running) - the weather has led to three races I'd have run since then being cancelled. I'm still trying to decide what my goals are for 2010. More on running later.

So I've been in the lab since the 18th of January. I'm absolutely exhausted. It's a whole other world of jargon, protocols and etiquette that I'm having to absorb. I put my foot in it the other day by remarking about how slow progress was! Andy thinks we're going really quickly and he should know. I have nothing to judge it against. Actually doing experiments is fairly manual and repetitive. I was mulling when I was watching a really bored barista make my coffee the other day, how similar what we were doing was.

What is good about lab stuff is that it's more tangible than computer/maths stuff. What's bad is that there is no 'Undo' button, mess it up and it's start again. Which is kinda tense after 7 hours of work and knowing that one mistake would mean it's all wasted. And the experiment dictates my day. There's no pausing for coffee whenever I feel like it, I go when it lets me - and there's no drinking coffee while I'm in the lab.

The point of these experiments is to try and evaluate if the real proteins behave like the pretend ones in our models. Which in turn is trying to understand how our cells tell our immune system if they have cancer (or other diseases.)Testing this is incredibly difficult. After three weeks we're still establishing how to do the actual experiments we need. It's lots of pipetting, centrifuges, mixing liquids and measuring things. I am learning a lot of stuff.

Something that is very familiar is the politics of work places - same old, same old. It's hard enough learning all the technical stuff, but then add in the effort required to understand the various tensions and rivalries and layers of resentment and general bitching and moaning that goes on and that's why I'm so tired. I'm feeling quite sick and tired of people to be honest! Moving on...

Props to Katherine for bringing Born to Run to my attention. Sure, he takes a few artistic liberties to tell the story, but this is a great non-fiction book about running - as a pastime, as an industry and as part of human history. A real page turner. Even if you aren't a runner I think most people would enjoy it.

As I was reading it, Daniel Lieberman's latest paper on barefoot running got on the cover of Nature - he's also in Born to Run - enjoy the video summary here. I've long been suspicious of  sports shoes as a cause of injury and the case for barefoot running has been around for a couple of decades. It seems like we're getting closer to proper evidence, so I've made the switch to minimalist running - that is virtually barefoot, just a 1mm of rubber beneath my feet and the ground in my Feelmax. It's been a revelation, like I'm learning to run again, but learning to run properly. I'm having to ease my way in so that I don't end up with stress fractures, but once my muscles have adapted to take the load, I'm hopeful this is the way to faster pain free running for decades to come.

The only novel I finished since I last wrote was Breath by Tim Winton. I'm not sure about this book. The description of the exhilaration of surfing was second to none from what I remember of it myself. I can't put my finger on why I felt unsatisfied by the rest of the story about teenage boys growing up in Australia, but it didn't quite work for me. That said, I read it in a few days, so I was pulled along.

Neil got me James Ellroy's latest book for Christmas and I'm working my way through that tome at the moment.

At the cinema I've enjoyed Up in the Air recently. Gorgeous George puts in a fine performance in a film about attachments and expectations. Funny, but not too sweet.

On TV, I've finished Season 2 of Breaking Bad - definitely my favourite programme of the last 12 months. I see it's getting more attention now, so watch it before the hype really gets going.

I've caught up with Mad Men and am watching the latest series. Can't help feeling it's mostly just a period drama for people who don't like bonnets and bustles, but it does have some great lines and tries to make a few social observations/contrasts.

Music wise I've been enjoying the latest Spoon album - they've gone for a stripped down guitar and drums sound this time. And the latest from Four Tet is rather lovely electronica.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Don't worry us about messing up in the lab: that's the sort of thing newspaper headlines are made of! Yeah you do look good running - like a proper runner! Bit worried about the 1mm soles on your running shoes - stones, broken glass, etc!? My friend Tony also highly recommends Born To Run: think Jen might like it for her birthday. I can recommend Ponyo (Studio Ghibli) as a film: a lovely film - the animation is beautiful; took Thea and her friend to see it over half term holiday, they loved it. (Yes, Thea in a cinema!!) The only jarring moment is when some horrible Teeny-bop pop music plays over the end credits so run out as soon as the film's over. Pity about office politics - you'd think scientists would be more logical about it but there you go. It's always good to do something practical; satisfying; there's pleasure in honing a skill or perfecting a craft (I miss darkroom photography and film cameras). Good blog Al. Must see you soon. Phil

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's the end of the working year for me. I realised that since I started in October 2008, I've only had one full week when I did no PhD work at all. That was when I went to Corsica in the summer. So I'm not going into the University for just over two weeks, but considering I mostly work from home anyway, how much I'll resist the constant worry that I should be doing more I don't know...

2009 has been a roller-coaster, that's for sure. Tim said to me at the outset of this journey it's all about what level of uncertainty one enjoys in life as to whether I'll enjoy research science. So depending on the day and my mood it can be inspiring in the way exciting mysteries are or it can induce the most depressing feeling of powerlessness and hopelessness. And all other colours of emotion in between.

Here's the story so far...

There have been long standing efforts to try and understand how our cells, that comprise our bodies communicate to the cells that guard against disease - collectively known as our immune system - whether they are healthy or unhealthy.

Unhealthy cells are those that have been compromised by pathogens (bacteria, viruses, parasites) or, like cancer cells, not properly formed cells. The immune system kills them once they've been identified.

As an aside, it interests me to realise that the only human cells that ever get to have descendants are the sperm in men and eggs in women that fuse to make a new human. All other cells sacrifice themselves to ensure that this is possible. So cancer cells are rebels in that sense, they seek to reproduce independently and not be sacrificed in the greater cause like all the rest. Unfortunately, what they can't know, is that in their struggle to survive they will eventually kill their host and thus themselves.

Back to the research: in trying to understand how this cellular surveillance happens we're looking at the molecules (proteins) involved in the pathway of communication between our regular cells and immune system cells.

The first few months of my PhD were focused on the structures of two of the proteins and trying to figure out molecular/atomic level interactions using computer modelling. Experimental evaluation of this part will hopefully occur in 2010.

Since the summer, I've moved on to trying to model mathematically a system of proteins we think are critical to deciding what information our cells present . This has been more than a bit challenging for me! I've still a lot to do with this to have working models - I mostly have a stack of equations which need to be implemented. The point of this is to try and draw out mechanisms and understand how decisions are made about what information is presented and then make predictions that can be evaluated using real proteins.

It may not be immediately obvious how useful this is - but if one imagines be able to predict whether an immune system cell identifies a cancer cell correctly on the basis of flipping a particular switch inside the cancer cell so it sends a message to the surface flagging up its status, then maybe the power of an accurate equation becomes more apparent. Do X, observe Y. Of course it ain't that simple, but hopefully you get the idea...

Next and perhaps most interesting is that in the New Year I'm going to do some laboratory experiments with the proteins themselves. Finally after all this fake science, I'm going to do some honest lab coat wearing, pouring potions type of science. This is partly to help me understand how to improve the models, partly to improve my biology and most importantly to try and answer other questions raised by the models.

The whole basis of my PhD is that it is interdisciplinary and managing Computer Science, Structural Biology and Immunology was always going to be one of principle challenges. It was also a big selling point to me. So I've done some structural stuff, some computer maths stuff and now I'm going to do some hands-on immunology. Not sure how long that'll take, after which the focus will move back to one of the other aspects, but I'm looking forward to a change of scene. And if you see on the News that Southampton General Hospital has burnt down - that'll be my fault.

That's where I'm at after 14 months, with up to 34 to go. I'd like to say I know something really useful that will help treat cancer, but mostly I just realise how much I don't know and how much there is to learn. Like I say, it's a stern lesson in learning to live with uncertainty.I've maybe had two points in this time where I've seriously thought about quitting, but I've been reassured that whatever I felt in the first year, the second and third will be much worse!

I've ended my running year well though. I did my first half-marathon in November and clocked a time of 1hr 24min 48sec, which I was pleased with. I placed 110th overall and 66th in my category out of 1200 runners. It was a race that had everything: Started in the sun, then came a howling gale and a downpour. We had to run through twenty metres of water, half a metre deep - twice. And then the sun came back out at the end. A guy from Winchester Running Club took a picture of me from the middle of the race, but it's not the most flattering image, so I decided not to post it!

My next race is not until January and I have to say running in the dark and the snow is not the best fun, so I've eased up a bit at the moment.

Books, TV, Films and Music

I've read a few too many post-apocalyptic novels this year. The latest one being Margaret Atwood's The Year of the Flood. A follow up to Oryx and Crake. It's good, but I did feel it undercut the original a bit.

One of the best things I've read this year is You are Here by Christopher Potter. Ostensibly a guide to the Universe in terms of science, he goes into the whole human condition and how we conceptualise the idea of the Universe and our place in it. My kind of guy - he repeatedly uses David Mermin's remark, "Shut Up and Calculate!" - to underline how science runs smack into philosophy and what a mess this becomes once we are forced to consider the meaning of the data we collect.

On TV I've been enjoying True Blood, The Thick of It and most of all Breaking Bad. The vampire thing has been overdone, but True Blood is sufficiently entertaining and sophisticated to keep me watching. The Thick of It I enjoy simply for the pleasure of imaginative swearing. While Breaking Bad takes a really dark concept - a guy with lung cancer - makes it really funny and uses it to explore relationships and mortality in an excellent way.

Film wise, I really liked 35 Shots of Rum. I saw it on DVD and watched it in two parts cos it was making me feel really miserable - what a recommendation! - but I'd really like to see it again at the Cinema. It's unusual to see a film like this these days. One that tells the story mostly in pictures, without much dialogue and no voice over. A proper film! I read a review comparing it to Ozu and I can see exactly what they mean. A terribly intimate story of familial and ext ended familial relationships in Paris. Certainly one of my favourites of the year. Soundtrack by the Tindersticks!

Up was excellent too, which I did see at the cinema. I needed a feel good film at the time and this did the trick nicely. Dogs, Kids, A Grumpy Old Man and Balloons. What's not to like?

The Bicycle Thieves. I've been meaning to watch this for years. Amazing film. It really feels like its made by people unafraid to do anything but explore the medium and story they want to tell. No compromise for trying to capture a market that ruins so much modern film making and in so doing has produced some great cinematography that are now classic images, as well as being a social document of post-war Italy.It was incredibly sad though and I thought it was going to make me feel better after a rubbish day and instead it made me feel miserable!

The only new music I've enjoyed recently was The XX - pretty derivative and badly made music, but this still managed get under my skin. And Everything Hits at Once by Spoon has been my track of the Autumn

I've not taken any decent photos in ages, so the image above is one of my lino print Christmas cards from this year. I enjoyed making them enough that I'm considering doing a print making course in the New Year.

And on that note, I'll sign off.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: mr bailey, good luck in the lab! remember to wear goggles. a very, very happy christmas to you.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
All about my summer:

It probably doesn't reflect well on me, but looking back over my summer the thing I feel most strongly about is running. It's sort of crept up on me over the years - something in life I can rely on even when everything else has gone to hell. If I could do science as a hobby and running as a job I think I'd prefer that. This in the knowledge that most people think running is an odd thing to do at best.

Anyhow, I ran the summer cross country RR10 league here for the first time and while competition is not my prime motivation for running, it has made me better. I finished 22nd in the league overall out of ~200 in the 10 races over the last four months. The women's team for my club won the league too. Today I ran a 10k as a preparation for the winter season and went round in 38m14s, coming 5th out of ~500 mostly fun runners. It is satisfying to finish highly, but for perspective, the fastest guy was round in 35 minutes and world class is about 26 minutes!

I've been helping another club member train for her first marathon and that's been interesting too, running with another person and exploring new routes and going further than I would normally in my training. The world really does seem like a different place on foot and takes me to places I've not seen around the city. I was a bit worried about running with someone, rather than alone, thinking it might spoil the experience, but while it is different, it's actually been good fun and motivating, pushing the runs up to 20 miles over the summer. Though I still don't feel inclined to run a marathon myself! I have signed up for a half-marathon in November just to try that distance as a race.

Other than running, most of my summer has been spent studying. I finished my part the project I started back in November last year and spent most of August writing up. I ended up with a 17,000 word report! My supervisor Tim gave me some nice feedback last week, so although the slope is still just as steep going forward, I feel like I am actually going in the right direction. This part of the project was all about identifying a mechanism in our cells that influences how our immune systems see whether the cell is infected or part of a tumour. My colleague Andy is now doing some experiments with real cells to see if my models are in any way accurate. We should know around Christmas and in an ideal world the lab experiments validate the model and we've done some science - a small step in the long journey.

As I commence my second year then I'm looking at another aspect of modelling this phenomena of antigen presentation I just described in a bid to refine things even further. The more detailed the question, the harder it is to get a precise answer, but if we are ever going to develop therapies that take advantage of the power of our immune systems to fight cancer, we need precise answers. The reason we get side effects (or worse toxic effects) from drugs is exactly because the resolution of our knowledge is coarse.

Rationally, I always know I'm a lucky boy to be doing what I'm doing. Emotionally, it's hard to stay motivated faced with the difficulty of the problems and volume of information that has to be understood to even figure out what is the right question to ask. Science is not about faith, but much of the time that is exactly was is needed to get through the day. Faith that if I just keep going, keep chipping away, things will eventually get clearer. It often feels much more masochistic than even the hardest run though.

I did have time for a couple of camping trips during the summer. A week in Corsica where the temperature wasn't below 30 all week during the day. Those small pleasures such as seeing the stars - seeing the Milky Way! - or swimming in the sea - seeing fish - or in a mountain river, while in the company of friends is what makes it a holiday. And I ate enough pizza to put me off pizza for some weeks. Something I didn't think was possible.

We had a short trip down in West Wittering at the beginning of September, which is a beautiful beach if you've not been. The visit to the CASS Sculpture Park in Goodwood was a highlight too and I've been telling everyone I've seen since to visit! Pictures from both trips in the scrapbook and above.

Films, Books and TV:

Highlights from the summer books wise:

Halting State by Charles Stross - I originally bought this for my brother for his birthday, but he loaned it back to me. A funny tale of game playing and crime, yet convincing at the same time as a vision of our increasingly augmented reality. How long before we really do have GUI's overlaid onto the real world as we walk about? I particularly laughed at the idea of getting onto a bus to see icons blinking over the heads of kids with ASBO's so one knows where not to sit.

Lavinia by Ursula Le Guin - another masterpiece from one of the best living writers imo. An imagining of the life of a character in prehistoric Italy from Virgil's Aeneid. Moving, exciting and always so much to think about afterwards. She really knows how to unpack a story so that I have to keep reading.

Candide by Voltaire - a birthday present from Phil. A short and fast paced book, but so dense with ideas and jokes that I'll probably have to re-read it sometime to get things I missed first time out. Quite horrible and yet much of it is still sadly relevant to how humans treat one another.

The Turnaround by George Pelecanos - my favourite of his for some time. A smaller story than of late about Washington and more subtle and satisfying as a result.

Cyberabad Days by Ian MacDonald - a collection of short stories set in a future India.

The Road by Cormac MacCarthy - this has been recommended to me a couple of times and I wanted to see it before the film came out. Not quite finished yet, but considering post-apocalypse survival is almost a genre in its own right of which I've read several, it is very good. He really crafts his words and that just makes it all the more sad and uncomfortable to read and yet paradoxically hard to put down.

At the cinema:

Moon - David Bowie's sun pays homage to Silent Running, 2001 and Space 1999 with music by Clint Mansell of Pop Will Eat Itself, who seems to be doing a nice job of scoring films these days. Sam Rockwell is a fine actor.

District 9 - Really excellent for the first 45 minutes. Very funny and satirical. Then it goes a bit rubbish as they forget the satire and turn it into something akin to a computer game shoot 'em up which goes on for far too long. And it has plot holes you could drive a car through. That said I really enjoyed it cos it was fresh and I really hope they don't ruin the good work with a sequel.

On DVD:

The Wrestler - speaking of Clint Mansell, he scored this too. I felt so depressed watching this I watched it in two sittings! A study of decay and lost dreams. Very good.

The Corner - again really hard work, but fine stuff. Docu-drama of life on a Baltimore street in the 90s. Along with Homicide, this was a foundation for The Wire. I'm sure we used to make things like this in this country once upon a time.

Battlestar Galactica - from the sublime to the ridiculous. The first couple of series were cheesy but pretty good allegories and examinations of a society's response to terrorism/war. It's ended up in some sub-Matrix pseudo-religious nonsense.


Soylent Green - I've been having a bit of a dystopia festival recently including this film! Charlton Heston from 1973 in an overpopulated world where the dead are taken out with the rubbish and the greenhouse effect has killed most of Nature. Not brilliant but has some great bits and the mood is spot-on.

On TV:

The Cell - It's been on BBC 4 and will be on BBC 2 soon no doubt. Pretty decent biology primer. I learnt a fair bit and it's related to my work if you're interested. The Professor in the office next door to me was the consultant for the third episode!

Spiral II - the French crime drama is finally back on BBC 4. Highly unbelievable and suffers from some of the problems of most mainstream crime drama, but still pretty good and different enough to be interesting.

Getting On - I watched quite a lot of this through my fingers. Excellent cringe comedy from Jo Brand set in a hospital.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Before I get into the real body of this post, I need to address the comment Phil left about evolution - if I interpret this correctly as a question 'does evolution have a purpose that it is heading towards?' then the simple answer is that there is no evidence I know of to suggest that it does have meaningful purpose and there is plenty of evidence to suggest it is simply a mechanism of selection, albeit a mechanism driven by forces of chance and physics that give rise to massive complexity. Richard Dawkin's book The Blind Watchmaker is devoted to explaining how this mechanism works.


It is perhaps paradoxical to observe that I have an evolved conciousness that allows me to reflect on the point that I exist because of a mechanism of selection that has acted blindly and has yielded me - but it is perfectly possible for this happen without any kind of 'guiding intention' just by millions of years of trial and error and the laws of thermodynamics. (And if that raises the question, why is the universe set-up like this then? Well, you can go several ways on that one, but none of them involve evidence or hold much hope of any becoming available any time soon). Further and perhaps even more ironic to me is the fact that I appear to have evolved with this operating system worse than Vista called Conciousness that comes with applications called 'intuition' and 'emotions' which are really buggy and tantalise me with all these tricks of seeing my life as a narrative or important in  some way, that could tempt me into thinking that evolution wasn't simply a mechanism chugging away with no greater purpose but to select and propagate life.

Ok, that may be too nihilistic for most people, but as has been noted by several psychologists, actually it's normal people who are deluded. Rose tinted glasses are a very necessary thing for mental well being. Depressed people tend to do better in tests where one is required to make objective judgements, thus suggesting seeing reality as it really is perhaps ain't such a great thing - which is a selective pressure in itself when it comes to the species. I think I've written before about how Daniel Gilbert noted that most of us exist in a state oscillating around the junction between reality and delusion - too much delusion and one goes dancing in traffic, too much reality and I can't get out of bed!

One more point on this - I think this realisation that evolution is simply a mechanism is a major reason why one should take the time to consider things from a moral point of view and think for oneself about everything one holds dear. At a single stroke it destroys the basis for practically every prejudice there is - race, sexuality, gender etc. - take away 'intention', 'purpose' or the idea of being 'chosen' or that we're inevitably going in a particular direction towards something - then one has to start getting real about what one believes when it comes to calibrating what is right and what is wrong.

Right, down off one soapbox and onto another. I'm a bit concerned about my next bit coming across like an advert for Microsoft, but credit where credit is due...

This week I was up in Cambridge for the Microsoft Summer School at their Research Centre there, aka MSR  - co-sponsors for my research alongside the Medical Research Council. I don't expect I'll ever be a millionaire, but this a little of what I imagine the life is like - having my every need attended to, meeting high flyers and people of power and influence and experiencing priviledge way outside my everyday life. To address the cynicism I myself have - there is of course a quid pro quo - MSR spend maybe a million pounds a year on their PhD students overall, but the return if one of us does come up with something cool  that feeds into their products could be many many times greater. And this money is such a tiny fraction of their income.

Amongst the researchers themselves at least, they do genuinely appear to want to be more than simply a big old hated monopoly - there does appear to be a social conscience at play and hence large investments in research that may be of social benefit without necessarily yielding economic return. That said, there is still a part of me that says, 'well it's easy to be magnanimous when one holds the reigns of power. It's giving away ones power that is really meaningful.'

However, I've been treated like a prince for a week, so I should emphasise the positives - amazing place, amazing people, don't think I spent any money in the entire week and there was such attention to detail in making sure everyone felt included, had there specific needs met and just generally in being welcomed and looked after, I was blown away. The full schedule is here but the highlights were: One, the go-karting on Monday. Way more fun than I expected and I can understand why people get into cars now. I didn't even notice that I'd bruised myself until the next day, such was the adrenaline rush from power sliding and opposite lock and getting into battles with my colleagues. Secondly was Jesus College itself. I feel quite conflicted about the privilege people in Cambridge receive. Maybe it does act an incentive for people that such places exist, but I would prefer that the money and power was spread more evenly across the globe, even if it meant I personally had less. But as it stands, I got to stay in this immaculately maintained ancient college (see the picture above) and was waited upon at a five course dinner while I sat next to one of the designers of the ZX81 (first computer I ever used) and the BBC Micro. Did I really do that? Yes, apparently I did.

Then there were the seminars themselves and the other students. I was feeling really quite intimidated the first couple of days - there are some seriously clever people there - but once I decided to stop worrying about what I'm not, it was just fun to talk to them and hear about their work. Some really excellent speakers among the presenters too and I got to play with some cool technology.

If you want to know more and see my poster - which is hopefully digestible for the non-expert - then follow the link above to the schedule and you can read about the various speakers and download things like my poster (it's near the bottom of the page) and power point files of some of the presentations. 

My favourite was Drew Purves, but I think his presentation may be unavailable due to content of a commercially or research sensitive nature. David Mackay was ace too (he's not part of MSR) and I'm going to see I can get either or both of them to visit Southampton to give their talks here.

So kudos to Microsoft for showing me another side of the behemoth - they are much more than just those idiots who make crashware!

Back to reality for me now. I've been mulling over whether I'm really cut out for the PhD. My week away has given me a bit of a boost, but I'm still not sure - and this is not false modesty - if I am clever enough to do this and whether it just makes me too unhappy grinding away at it like I have been. I've still got a couple of months to look at the options and make up my mind about whether to stick or quit, but I'm not 100% committed to the cause at the moment. Perhaps not the happiest note to end on, but that is how things are at the time of writing.

Please send all objections, corrections and anything else to the usual address or post it as a coment below ;-)

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Some things I was thinking about when I was running (other than how many flies I've eaten today and how it is that when I run through the posh areas of Southampton the people say hello to me, but when I run through the poorer areas people shout abuse at me - which I've decided is just an availability error)...

---------------------------------

I have to do my first seminar in 10 days time. It's only 25-30 minutes and to people in my department, but it'll be the first real time I have to account for my work in the last six months. I'm going to talk about modelling and simulation in the context of research into the immune system.

Science and Art have a lot of similarities (at least in my mind) in that they are both trying to express something about reality. Picasso famously said in 1923 that "Art is the lie that helps us realise the truth." And this concept of imperfect artificial constructions helping us to understand more deeply what is real is very much how my research - modelling of the immune system - is proceeding.

Science itself is often about hierarchies of organisation. At the most fundamental level is Physics, where scientists are trying to understand what exactly reality is made of, the particles that make atoms etc. One problem that often occurs down here is that things cannot often be observed directly. So something like the results of experiments to look for the fundamental particles of which the universe is made at the Large Hadron Collider is analogous to turning up at the scene of a burglary and trying to figure out who committed the crime from the mess they left behind.

On the next level up in the hierarchy, one may be trying to understand how these particles combine to form groups of particles and how these groupings are organised and interact as systems.

Then one might jump up to another level where these groups of particles are large enough to be considered entities in their own right and express patterns of behaviour that can be observed and predicted without worrying about what every individual particle is doing.

And so on and so forth, right up to people and societies and galaxies. One important point being (assuming one accepts this concept of a hierarchy) that the rules governing the lower levels place constraints upon what is possible at the higher levels.

I too am working at a level where it is difficult, if not impossible to observe things directly and that is where modelling/simulation comes in. We can observe cells under a microscope and see some components of cells even, but to go deeper is not possible with visible light as the molecules - proteins - are too small to be resolved this way. Technical note: resolution is defined as the ability to distinguish between two separate points. If you want to test yourself, draw two dots on a bit of white paper close together, lean it against something and walk back. You should reach a point where it starts to look like one dot. That's the resolution limit of your vision. For more fun, you can do this on your skin with a friend using two pencils. Close your eyes and they should start with the pencils far apart, say touching on your upper and lower arm and then gradually they put them at points closer and closer together. Again there will be a distance where it feels like you are being touched with just one pencil - the resolution limit for your sense of touch - it'll be different for different parts of your body.

But I digress. So I am trying to model entities - proteins - that exist in almost all our cells and have been observed as having a role in travelling to the cell surface and signalling to our immune systems whether the cell from which they come is diseased or not - and therefore whether it should be killed or not. Understanding this process - how and why some diseases are signalled and some not - would be very helpful in treating everything from Cancer to Swine Flu.

So as these proteins can't be observed in situ, one strategy is to make models based on what can be observed and perform simulations to figure out the things that can't be observed directly. So far I have modelled the static structure of two proteins and I am now modelling the dynamic interaction of these two proteins and eventually I hope to progress to whole systems of proteins. As with the hierarchy I described before, it is a case of start simple and progress to complexity once one is confident that the rules and assumptions are sound (enough) at each stage. Ultimately any model is only as useful as the real experiments that validate it, but the point of the model is to suggest and ideally predict which experiments to carry out. Hopefully by the end of the summer I will have enough information for my colleagues over at the Hospital to do some experiments and test my results and that will be quite exciting (in a small way) as I will feel like I've done some real Science, something new - the lies of my simulations hopefully giving insight into the truth of our immune systems.

------------------------------------------

That took most of the run and then I was thinking about things on the cultural front. I've enjoyed quite a lot in the past few months, I'm not going to say too much about them, just list them with a sentence or so each for anyone who wants to check 'em out:

Books

The Gum Thief by Douglas Coupland : His best is in some time. Funny and sad.

Speed of Dark by Elizabeth Moon : Such a great writer, her simple prose belies the power of her thinking. A near future book about autism, which as my brother said is better than The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night.

Thicker Than Water by Mike Carey : Not so great stuff about a freelance exorcist in London, but fun nonetheless. Fourth in the series.

Little Brother by Cory Doctorow : My favourite read of the year so far, I ripped through it in 36 hours. A great read about security, surveillance, human rights and teenage romance. The main character is like a one boy A-team.

Blood Meridian by Cormac MacCarthy : Amazing writing, but so unrelentingly grim that I'm still only half way through after 4 months! Set in mid-19th century USA.

Film and TV

Coraline in 3D : I was really impressed by the 3D and it's a charming story, funny, a bit scary and the animation is extraordinary in places.

Let the Right One In : the more I think about this film the less I like it and I was unimpressed to start with. Not sure why it got such good reviews.

Generation Kill : Another great HBO series. Quite disturbing, but it's good to see a show that conveys some of the (what I would assume are) the complexities of war and the people that join the armed forces.

Music (props to Neil)

Uproot by DJ Rupture : I really like this mix of reggae and electronic music. My current favourite.

Luminarium by Tape : kind of reminds of an instrumental Talk Talk with overtones of Mogwai.

Art

Alexandr Rodchenko and Liubov Popova at the Tate Modern. Only a few days left to catch this, but I was really impressed by how ahead of the curve they were and how many mediums they worked in.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For anyone crazy enough to want more, some bonus material follows below, a post I started and didn't know how to finish! Or if it even made sense...

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

April 19 2009

It's just past the six month mark for my PhD. Spring is here and I'm feeling tired and a bit more lost than usual. Here's a bit of science and philosophy as an attempt to figure things out.

I've been mulling as I often do on the nature of choices - the very fact of having them or not having them, the extent to which one has free will or not. Partly cos this is something I do a lot of anyway and partly cos this speaks directly to my research. I chose this path from the paths available to me and my actions previously interacted with the world such as to lead to this set of paths. Obviously one does not choose to be born or the circumstances that one is born into. Growing up is process of moving from a situation of having no power to make decisions to a situation where one becomes increasingly more able to make and be responsible for ones decisions. I'd probably use this phenomena to define what it means to be an adult - a person actively chooses and who takes responsibility for the consequences of their actions. (Likewise I'd define being English as: to be neurotic about food and obsessed with house prices).

Foresight is not perfect and hence many decisions one makes are bad and the consequences not good, but most of us learn to a lesser or greater extent through this process and the results are ultimately what we call experience and wisdom. This is fine when right and wrong are obvious and the decisions are simple choices, but personally I find that the vast majority of situations are complex and it is not a simple matter to know what to expect when one makes a choice. Even with hindsight it's often not obvious if one choice was superior to another. One of my favourite expressions is that the road to hell is paved with good intentions - certainly I've been down to hell a few times on the receiving end of other peoples good intentions and I've built a fair bit of the road too - so it always pull my up when I catch myself or someone else being a bit too certain about what they're doing.

Anyhow, before I start riffing on my low opinion of the human race, my point was really that it seems that we are all faced with the almost impossible situation that the world is very complex and yet one must constantly make decisions - doing nothing still being a choice of sorts. So troubled as I am about myself and other people, ultimately it's a wish for a bit more tolerance in the world.

And this is not to ignore the evidence that shows how our decisions can be made without recourse to concious thought i.e. that we don't always exercise free will - as I was discussing the other day, the hypothesis being that conciousness exists on a spectrum from unconscious to fully aware and much of our inherited survival abilities would have evolved prior to the kind of reflection and introspection I'm demonstrating (far too much of) here. So it's not surprising that many of our decisions are made without recourse to free will, we are evolved animals after all and choosing a mate or avoiding a predator is perhaps best done without running it past your fore brain first.

Right, that's part of the back story, here I am (in this universe, just to cover the parallel worlds scenario) wondering about my choices past and present and here's another assumption I operate under: The universe is governed by rules that are themselves based upon natural phenomena. That is to say there is nothing magical or supernatural that directs the universe we observe (which is not to exclude God if you're that way inclined, but if they exist, they are outside the system and not interacting with it.) This assumption is a lot deeper than it may first seem. A lot of people seem to think that it implies reduction of complexity and that this somehow leads to some kind of loss. To me this in no way implies that a squeezing of ones imagination or that disciplines like Art lose any value or Artists lose their ability to create or for one to have opinions about such things. What it does say to me is that - Hey! You there. Your actions have real consequences and there's no magical solutions to your problems or anyone else's, so stop acting like you can't think for yourself and stop oppressing other people cos you're too dumb to question the dogma you got fed as a child and your own animal inheritance. The assumption of rules governing the universe presents the possibility of testing and evidence and actually making decisions without them being founded in dogma, instinct and stupidity.

And as far as I can tell we are in no danger of running out of complex phenomena to understand and reducing the world to a simple set of equations and robbing anyone of their creativity and imagination. If anything we're pretty much at the beginning and the human race is more in danger of extinction than running out of things to think about and stuff to do.

If you accept my assumption about the universe and its underlying objective nature (and also perhaps  battling with ideas about our own nature and place within the universe) then one question raised is how to find these rules? Can it even be done? That is essentially what Science is - the attempt to find the rules and test the assumption - and my long preamble is an attempt to encapsulate the spirit guiding a wide range of approaches to this question which I would argue have been more successful than anything else we've come up with. This being perhaps why more traditional philosophical disciplines have been in decline - they don't produce many testable hypotheses, however interesting they may be to think about, and usefulness is significant in determining the fitness of ideas and ultimately survival in the same way as it is for living things.

Which finally brings me to my PhD. Here's another assumption or maybe a proposition might be better: Is nature stochastic? (Stochastic deriving from the Greek, "to guess" and means "random" or "chance") Does the universe operate according to probabilities and chance rather than outcomes determined with total certainty by the preceding set of circumstances?

Ok, that's really a trick question- cos it's not one that can be answered. It's one thing to assume nature has an objective reality, but like the existence of God, it's not something that ca n be proved one way or the other and hence one is always stuck with an assumption. A better proposition might be: Is it better to choose to model nature as stochastic or deterministic? Does one approach produce more reliable rules than another?

That is something we can test for usefulness. And the answer is: It depends.

In my PhD the approach to understanding the behaviour of molecules inside cells is to assume they are stochastic processes. In other words in modelling the behaviour of the molecules, we assume a set of possible outcomes may occur weighted according to probabilities inherent within the model system we create. By comparing this to what can be observed in the behaviour of real molecules, we hope to derive the properties of the molecules themselves and the properties of real living organisms. Ultimately this knowledge then would be used for developing medicines - my department being Cancer Sciences - but the knowledge being fundamentally immunology/biochemistry.

So why do it this way? This goes back to where we started - choices and complexity....

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: What no comments?! All I can say is 'stunning'. Philospophy and science all in one. From my own studies all I can say is that Kant had to make a simiar assumption: that nature appears to have a purpose (which we cannot know) so we must treat nature AS IF it had a purpose.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Getting back to my roots with a bit of Film Studies to start this post:

One way I judge the quality of a film is how much I find myself thinking about it afterwards. I saw L'Enfant on Wednesday and while I thought it good, it didn't touch me too greatly. But here I am on Sunday still mulling it over. To me that's a sign of a great film. It is easy to call it depressing - a film about the life in an industrial Belgium town of the kind people that in the UK most nice middle class people like me would cross the road to avoid - but it's so unusual to see a film about this strata of society, played out so dispassionately. I find it compelling and moving the more I think about it. Obviously I am a pretentious bleeding heart (goes without saying really) but it reminded me of Kieslowski's 10 commandments films and the ideas from Foucault about how we treat the lowest and most vulnerable members of our society tells us much about ourselves and how 'civilised' we are. What I've been mulling over are the pathways that lead to the kind of desperate and anti-social  and self-destructive behaviour of the characters in the film and those who I see on the street or I have known.

Essentially I've been thinking about how messed up the world is for about the billionth time and how complex the problems are to solve! There's a great line in the second Gwyneth Jones book about how the real problem is not making things simple but keeping them complicated. The implication being that simple thinking is the source of prejudice and fascism, where as vagueness and messiness are the reality and staying complex in ones thinking is key to treating others with humanity.

Bruno the principal protagonist is a true nihilist anti-hero of which there is nothing cool at all. He really is a large child living only in the moment for almost the entire film and that is really frightening to me.
Stylistically it has nods to Italian Neo-realism and one theme it follows that I'm always interested in is the subversion of modern technology to needs beyond those intended by the designers. As with the Wire this revolves around the use of mobile phones and vehicles for crime that intersects with more universal themes of the type that Dickens depicted.

By coincidence, the last film I saw prior to that was Breathless or A Bout de Souffle if you prefer. Another film with a nihilistic central character - but oh so cool. One of the coolest films ever made. Jump cuts, jazz, smoking, fast cars, guns, beautiful people and meditations on how tiresome modern life is. I'd forgotten what a truly great piece of Art it is. Someone taking the medium and really doing something new with it. And it's a document of it's time, 1960 in Paris. Jean-Paul Belmondo and Jean Seburg are the two most beautiful and terrible people in the world in that film.

So two films worth checking out if you have the time and inclination for those kind of things.

I saw Breathless on my afternoon off when I spent the week in Cambridge, a couple of weeks ago.

I was in Cambridge visiting Microsoft Research, where my supervisor Andrew is based, for a week of induction into the world of Microsoft and Computer Modelling. Here are some thoughts on Microsoft and Cambridge I wrote at the time and the picture at the top is of the Bridge at Queens College:

---------------------------------------------------

Imagine if you will, a brand new building all glass and steel and exposed concrete columns. Lots of space and natural light. It's high security, but once you're in then it's a world of calm and soft colours

My desk is situated in a large office space in a group of four in an open plan area with a kitchen and sofas surrounded on both sides by rows of offices for the big cheeses. The kitchen is stocked with fruit, biscuits and energy bars. There is a fancy tea and coffee machine that makes very nice lattes. Around the corner is a big glass fronted cooler with spring water, juice and fizzy drinks. One can help oneself to as
much as one wants. The desk is spacious and I have a comfy expensive Herman Miller Aero chair. 

Perhaps what's so amazing is the extravagance of space. The floor I'm on is maybe about half the size of a football pitch and there are maybe 15-20 people occupying the whole floor. One would never get claustrophobia working there. In fact, my only gripe is that it's a bit too quiet - no hijinks or larking about whatsoever. Everyone is super professional and focused.

The building is located in the science park and we have lunch with the physicists over in the Cavendish Laboratory canteen. (Sadly nerds, not the canteen that Maxwell or Watson and Crick would have eaten in. The Lab moved from it’s original location in 1974). Apparently the University wouldn't allow Microsoft to have their own catering and Microsoft even had to build the building, sell it to the University and now rent it back in order to occupy that spot!

I walk there under big open skies to the sound of birdsong and bicycles and back again under darkening horizons and the sounds of church bells. It is quite a contrast to the hectic rush of the Avenue and the sense of enclosure in Southampton.

My accommodation is pretty basic, even if the college itself is luxurious, like staying in Hogwarts. I have to share a shower and toilet which is a bit grotty, but I can't complain when everything else is on a level of privilege outside my usual experience. (Andrew did mention that a year ago I'd have been in a 4 star hotel, but such is the credit crunch).

What I've seen of Cambridge so far feels like what England is like in a Richard Curtis film - no oiks and everyone acts with that upper class sense of entitlement. It does make me a bit  uncomfortable but suppose new places take getting used to. I have an inverse snobbery prejudice, I can't deny it. I tend to find myself wanting to commit acts of violence on people who are more posh or more middle class than me just cos I assume they've had a nicer life than me and it's all so unfair and I want them to suffer a bit more - it's wrong and irrational I know and I can see beyond it, but the feelings are there! And it has been a good week so far on the learning front which is the real point of being here.

-----------------------------------------

I'm due to go and live in Cambridge for a couple of months next year, so I better show some adaptability and get over my issues. And I did meet some really interesting people and began making new contacts in the world of academia relating to Biology and Computer modelling. In fact it's off the back of one meeting that at the end of March I'm going for a week at the School of Mathematics at the University of Leeds for the impressively named Graduate School in Non linear and Stochastic Systems in Biology. (I only included that cos the fancy words sound really clever!) Once again, I'm wondering, "Where did it all go right?" and suspiciously looking around for the lurking disaster and my personal regression to the mean...(I want one of these)

Returning to Art for a moment, before I finish and go back to Science and my report writing: One of my favourite Computer writers Charles Petzold has reviewed The Art Instinct on his site. This ties in nicely with all the Darwin stuff on TV (and if you didn't catch the fine David Attenborough documentary recently there's this excellent 6 minute version on YouTube ) as it is a book that attempts to relate evolution and creativity. I'm adding it to my ever growing reading list, but if anyone likes the look of it and gets there first, let me know what you think.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's 4 weeks to my first deadline - that of my five month report - so I thought as a way of sorting out some thoughts I'd post a sort of primer on Cancer - or what I've learnt so far about that aspect of my studies.
What follows owes a lot to a seminar at Southampton General Hospital by Graham Packham and a paper from 2000 called The Hallmarks of Cancer by Douglas Hanahan and Robert A. Weinberg.

What is cancer, where does it come from & how common is it?

Cancer is a genetic disease that begins with the production of a single cell that has evaded the control systems that have evolved to regulate the processes of cell division, growth and repair. So when we say it is genetic, we mean that enough of the genes within the cell have mutated to spawn a cell that can overcome the controls. Mutations of our genes can happen by natural random chance, by environmental factors such as from the chemicals in cigarettes or overexposure to sunlight or by  bacterial or viral infection.

This rogue cell then goes on to multiply and grow more cells just like the original. The end result, if not treated, is ultimately death as either the vital organs fail to function or because the body is unable to produce sufficient red blood cells to provide the body with the oxygen it needs to function. There are over 100 different 'types' of cancer, occurring at different sites within the body, with different ages of onset, different courses of progression, different underlying causes and needing a variety of different treatments. Generally though, as it starts with one cell, it can often take years or decades before the cancer has grown enough cells for symptoms to become apparent.

From an individual point of view cancer is a common disease. The current harsh facts are that about 1 in 3 of us will suffer from cancer and 1 in 4 will die from cancer. However, from a cells point of view it is extremely rare to be a cancer cell. Humans are estimated to have 10 to the power 14 cells - that's 10 followed by 14 zeros - growing, dividing and dying throughout our lifetimes, so to be a cancer cell is to be a very very rare thing. Further to this the natural mutation rate of genes within cells is so slow that it is estimated that you'd need to live one hundred years to acquire enough mutations in one cell to get cancer. Hence the significance of environmental and pathogen mutations. In any event, to repeat it can take 20 years from the appearance of a cancer cell for it to replicate and grow to the size of a tumour.

The acquired capabilities of a cancer cell or 'what makes you so special, huh?'

I've reproduced a diagram here (D. Hanahan and A. Weinberg, 2000) that shows what have been identified as the 6 capabilities a cell must acquire to become cancerous (click on it to make it larger).

One thing to note is that these capabilities do not to be acquired by a cell in a particular order or at a particular rate - hence the circle - and some may occur simultaneously, but it must have all of them to become cancerous.

Bearing that in mind, the six capabilities are described in an arbitrary order, the "how?" and "why?" of these capabilities is obviously what researchers are trying to understand, so this is really just an outline of the "what?" part of the big question:

1. Self-sufficiency in growth signals: cells need to be told when to grow and are instructed by signals upstream that lead to cell growth downstream. Cancer cells appear to have developed mutations that allow them to turn on the downstream signals without recourse to these instructions and override the usual pathways.

For example the HER2 receptor has been identified as over expressed in 20-30%  of breast cancer tumours and this causes these cancer cells to be hyper responsive to normal growth factor conditions and proliferate in a way that normal cells would not as they would need greater stimulation. 

2. Insensitivity to growth inhibition : conversely to growth, cancer cells acquire the ability to ignore the usual anti-growth signals that act as a check on uncontrolled growth of cells.

An example of how this can occur is via the human papillomavirus that is has been identified as a major cause of cervical cancer. This has been shown to disrupt the function of pRb anti-growth inhibition pathway in cells. Hence the national vaccination programme that began in the UK against this virus for teenage girls in 2008 which will doubtless save many women's lives. (And doubtless will lead to the usual moral hand wringing and health scares around sex and vaccinations - dumb humans, but whatyagonnado?)

3. Evasion of Apoptosis : which is a fancy word for suicide. Or programmed cell death, if you prefer. Cell death is an everyday part of life (and hence part of the reason for eating is to make new cells). The cells themselves and the immune systems cells are constantly on the look out for signs of damage or dangerous mutations. And should a cell or an immune system cell notice something is wrong, the cell either decides to do the decent thing or is told to do so by the immune system and then offs itself. Once triggered it can take just 30 minutes for the cell to defragment and the corpse gets consumed within 24 hours - waste not, want not - consider that as a bioweapon - pretty scary, huh? Cancer cells turn off these internal mechanisms and thus can ignore these instructions.

The inactivation of the p53 tumour suppressing protein is thought to be a common example of such an evasion of apoptosis in cancer cells thought to occur in over 50% of all tumours. This can happen through mutations resulting by chance or exposure to environmental factors such as chemicals in cigarettes, radiation from the sun or pathogens such as viruses.

4. Limitless replicative potential : as well as the potential for suicide, normal cells have a limited ability to reproduce themselves. Each time a cell copies itself some genetic information is lost and eventually they cannot replicate any more (on average after 70 divisions and this doesn't apply to stem cells.) The very reason for this limit, it is proposed, is that it is a product of evolution that acts as a form of cancer prevention. Cancer cells turn on an enzyme that overcomes this built-in limitation in 85-90% of tumours. This may occur via the usual mutagenic or pathogenic pathways outlined in 3.

5. Sustained angiogenesis : a fancy word for describing the growth of red blood cells, which is how cells get oxygen. As anyone who's tried to breathe underwater knows, humans can't extract oxygen from water like fish can. But our cells can't survive without it and therefore neither can we. Hence we breathe air into our lungs and they extract oxygen and it is then redistributed to the rest of our bodies via our red blood cells. For a cell to access the oxygen they carry (and other nutrients) it must be within 100 micrometres of a capillary blood vessel or they will starve and die. That's in the range of the thickness of a human hair. The process of angiogenesis is tightly controlled, so cancers must overcome these controls for them to proliferate and grow into tumours. Trying to understand how cancer cells influence the angiogenesis triggers and inhibitors is an area of intense research and is not wel l understood. It is proposed that it is an early to mid-stage event in human cancers and is therefore a target for future treatments. Like putting out a fire, exclude oxygen and it will extinguish.

6. Tumour Invasion & Metastasis : sooner or later in most cancers development, if left unchecked, it will go from being a clump of cells in one place - a tumour - and spread itself around the body. This tumour invasion, the setting up of colony tumours is called metastasis. It's responsible for 90% of all deaths, but it is an ability that must also be acquired by the primary tumour. These processes are complex and not fully understood. But for example, the alteration of several proteins involved in tethering cells to their environments have been identified in tissues surrounding metastatic capable cells.

The final big factor in all this is, as already outlined, is the acceleration of mutation rates in genes due to pathogens, environmental exposures to mutagens such as UV radiation and thirdly due an existing inherited genetic mutation. To repeat, that is how the final obstacle of so many mutations occurring within one cell in less than 100 years is overcome that allows these six abilities to be acquired.

Treatments - Current and Pending

The most basic treatment is surgery to cut out the tumour. This obviously happens once a cancer tumour has been identified and goes alongside other treatments, as it is difficult if not impossible to know if surgery has removed all of the cells.

Most people have heard of chemotherapy & radiotherapy, which essentially the use of toxins or radiation to kill cancer cells. The principal downside being that the toxins and radiation kill cells other than the cancer cells. Interestingly it was suggested to me when I joined Cancer Sciences that the destructive effect on the immune system cells of chemotherapy may stimulate an immune response that also aids in the effectiveness of chemotherapy. Point being though, it's not well understood how it works and it's not what one might call a targeted treatment, but it has saved many lives so far.

Identification of pathogens and mutagens and prevention of exposure to them, such as banning smoking in pubs, wearing sunblock or vaccination against the human papillomavirus have already been mentioned, but this is a very important form of prevention that should not be overlooked.

The latest currently available treatments are Antibody based treatments. Drugs you may have heard of include Herceptin for some Breast Cancers or Rituxan for Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma.

If we return to section 1 above and the acquisition of self-sufficiency to growth signals of cancer cells: Herceptin is a molecule (an antibody) designed to bind to HER2 receptor, inhibiting them and thereby prevent these cells from growing more of themselves through this pathway in the 20-30% of breast cancers which have this feature. It is also thought to inhibit angiogenesis.

So the purpose of these treatments is to create antibody molecules that target aspects of cancer cells that inhibit aspects of the six hallmark features and arrest their progress, ideally ultimately causing them to die off. This type of treatment will also go hand in hand with surgery and other traditional treatments, but it is much more targeted to the individual type of cancer and thus less damaging and more successful.

Several antibody treatments for other cancers have been developed and will be available in the next year or two.

Future treatments include DNA fusion vaccination. This is a more active approach to immunotherapy and aims to activate the immune system to destroy cancers directly. This works by identifying the genes associated with a particular cancer and fusing it with another bit of DNA from a pathogen that is known to cause an immune response. This attempts to get over the problem of our immune systems seeing cancers as part of our own bodies and leaving them alone. A vaccine created from pathogen-cancer fused DNA is then injected to the patient and stimulates an immune response from the host immune system to kill all cells with that protein motif including the tumour cells. As well as being targeted this has the advantage of hopefully generating immunity against the cancer returning in the way that other vaccines do.

Trials of such a vaccine for prostate cancer in humans are now on going, so this type of treatment may be available in the next few years.

Lastly, to relate this back to my own work: I'm currently involved at the far end of the research and treatment development process. I'm trying to help figure out mechanisms inside cells that relate to how the immune system sees diseases. It's unclear (to me anyway) how, if these are fully understood, that they can be turned into treatments and it was mentioned recently that it may be more useful for HIV than Cancer, but such is research. Point being, it could be 20 years before anything I do now filters down into something available in the clinic, if it filters down at all.

So feel free to email me questions or to point out any errors etc. And I hope that was useful to someone other than me!

Something to bear in mind

One final point, the best thing for all of us is not to worry too much about getting ill - eat a decent amount of fresh fruit and vegetables, get some regular gentle exercise, don't unnecessarily expose yourself to anything nasty, take advantage of the vaccines available for common illnesses - and the odds for a long and healthy life are pretty good. (But I have no prescription for it being a happy life!)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Al, Thankyou for that. I did find this article of yours to be most interesting which surprised me! Would it be true to say (and pardon me if I am showing my ignorance by stating the obvious) that cancer is the biggest killer of the human species? If so it is somewhat a twist of nature that although mankind can find cures for many diseases and ailments it is so far unable to do so for the biggest killer of them all? Is this one of those endless quests that may never be solved, in which case should we not be re-focussing efforts and indeed money much more into prevention. I am of course thinking out loud and it would of course be daft to completely stop research but I do feel that people are still not educated enough into the quite sophisticated ways and means of cancer. To have a globally co-ordinated information campaign may indeed make people think again about how to go about life in order to lead a fuller life? It is true that cancer (as far as my limited knowledge will allow) does not discriminate. An example being a close friend of mine who live a clean and healthy lifestyle. He kept fit and did not drink or smoke, contracted cancer of the tongue. When at the doctor after having investigated the family history which was pretty clean of cancer the doctor then turned to my friend and said "I am sorry but it looks like you have been dealt a bad hand in life!" I am glad to say that after a couple of surgeries including the removal of half his tongue he is now in remission. This sort of takes me back to my point about whether a cure will ever be found. Many people in India would say that my friend must have done something bad in a past life and therefore carries bad Karma with him in this life! I personally do not believe this but it cannot be discounted as we truely do not know why this has happened to him. Sorry to ramble on a bit but I am kind of thinking out loud to help me to understand ..... WHY ? Bestest..... and keep up the good work. Sanjiv

Woah...big questions! I don't have concrete simple answers, but what I can say is that my understanding generally is that overall the biggest top 4 killers worldwide are ranked as cardiovascular diseases (heart attacks etc.), infectious/parasitical diseases (covering a wide range from measles to malaria) then third are cancers and then strokes. Secondly and importantly - it will very much depend on where you live - if you are born in parts of Africa then HIV/AIDS or Malaria are much more likely to kill you and thus you won't live long enough to get cancer or heart disease. And if you went back to the 1950s, then you and your family would be very much at risk from diseases now eradicated/controlled by vaccinations such as smallpox or measles. So the times one lives in are also a factor. Go back further and death by cholera in the UK was very prevalent and has been eradicated by social policies that brought about the construction of modern sewage systems. So it's not just medical research, it's good governance and good science that solve these problems. As far as evolution is concerned all that matters is that we live long enough to reproduce - harsh, but there it is - so things like cancer are a consequence of the evolutionary pressure to ensure survival at the expense of what are in evolutionary terms - lesser problems, such as living disease free and for a long time. The 'why?' question is not really something that science can address - at least not philosophically - but there is good progress being made into the 'how' and 'what' aspects of cancer and many other diseases. And just as we reap the benefits of the work and sacrifices of our ancestors, so our descendants will reap that of the work that is done today. Which is cold comfort for your friend who needed it now, but that is the way it is unfortunately and luck cannot be eliminated, but the odds can be tipped our way through what is available medically as treatment or prevention and through our behaviour as prevention. The basic message about lifestyle remains the same, regardless of what the medicine can do, in that respect.

I feel your comments about evolution are a little harsh. Surely it can't be just a matter of numbers and survival otherwise, surely, we'd all still be cavemen?! It must be that evolution is about change and adaptability and that's where hope lies, in being able to learn. We have evolved this far and can solve far more complex problems than we could before and cancer is on the list. Your own closing paragraph appears to point to this when you say 'we reap the benefits of the work and sacrifices of our ancestors'.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
A friend I know who started her PhD a year ago was always reluctant to talk about it whenever I asked what she was doing or what it was about. Now I'm into my third month of mine, I understand what a difficult question that is. I had conversation with one of my supervisors right at the start of my studies about how life was often a question of how much uncertainty one could live with. My opinion being that uncertainty leads to feelings of not being in control which leads to feelings of powerlessness. And feelings of powerlessness leads to feelings of anger or depression. Hence the illusion of certainty and being in control of ones destiny is very necessary for sanity even if it is a great big fat lie. So to be asked about my PhD frequently triggers that lovely chain of emotions in me as I find it difficult to frame my thoughts about what I'm doing in any coherent way much of the time.

So I've been trying to write this for about three weeks now in the hope it linearises my thoughts and makes them just a bit more manageable.

The quantity of jargon involved is one thing that makes it tough to talk/write about and therefore it is quite a mission to explain things in plain English. I'll do my best to explain as I go, but it inevitably ends up quite lengthy as a consequence.

John the laconic man from North Carolina who has the desk next to me and is both my colleague and unwitting mentor in my blind stagger into academia has two catchphrases: "Here's the deal..." and (usually directed to me) "I'll leave that as an exercise for the Reader..."

So here's the deal: My supervisor Tim, a Professor in Immunology has spent much of the last 10 years trying to understand the mechanisms by which cells present signals to our immune systems to indicate whether they are healthy or not. This is in order to better understand how our bodies observe (or not) cancer cells with a view to improving these processes and preventing cancers. My last post gives some more background and detail to all that.

At present I'm involved a sort of mini-project to improve the understanding of these mechanisms inside the cells of chickens by modelling the structures of unknown immune system proteins with a known similar protein. This approach is to compare proteins and trace their evolutionary heritage in order to identify the changes that have taken place. DNA is the molecule that encodes all the biological information that describes life.

I still find it a mind blowing concept to think that all life - you, me, dogs, trees, bacteria - everything, are all related. Or to put it another way - Unifying Biochemistry underlies the diversity of Biological Life. And don't take my word for it, that is what the evidence tell us, have a read and check it out.

So one can imagine that if one can look around today and make comparisons it's possible to trace the changes through time, this is called phylogenetics - I believe a guy called Darwin had a similar idea and though he didn't have access to DNA to and modern statistical methods support his ideas he still made a compelling case that is still the cause of controversy for people who aren't big fans of evidence.

DNA essentially is a code - like these words - it can be read and used to do something as well as having a physical form (in the case of DNA the form of an acid and in the case of these words in the form of electricity and/or light). The code is written as genes (about 25,000 in humans) and what DNA does a lot of the time is to provide codes for building proteins.

I'm building models of Chicken Immune system protein complexes called the major histocompatibility complex. The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is a protein complex (i.e. it contains several proteins) that exists in all jawed mammals inside cells. It's role is to present to the immune system cells (that are roaming around between the other cells) protein fragments called peptides that tell the body whether there is disease present inside that cell. Each human carries around 6 different types of them (different types of the same thing are called alleles) as a consequence of evolution, while their are thought to be more than 20 different alleles in total in humans. Different alleles recognise and present different diseases.

The hope is that it's possible to identify the important bits of these Chicken alleles - the bits that determine what diseases are presented by cells to the immune system - by looking at what has changed and what has not changed between the structures. Below is a representation of the known protein from a Chickens Immune system on the left and one of my final models on the right in blue. We're not interested in the yellow part, hence I've not modelled it.

   

If you've got this far, you're probably wondering what the Chicken has to with fighting Cancer in Humans. A question I often ask myself.It's not a very simple answer:

The reasons for using Chicken MHC molecules is the suggestion that unlike in humans there has been co-evolution between the interacting genes involved in this part of their immune system. This possibility means it should be easier to identify significant co-evolved mutations in Chickens and thus sites that are important to how these protein complexes present information regarding the health of the cells they correspond to. Identification of these sites in Chicken MHC would then assist in the identification of the corresponding sites in Human MHC Class I molecules and thus may shed light on how diseases are presented to the human immune system.

Essentially then it's a strategy for working backwards to cross reference the biochemical unity by analysing one species proteins in which we think the relevant genes that code them are close together in the genome and using the results to find the relevant genes in another - Us - that are not sitting side by side on our genome (25,000 genes remember). And if you know where the code is - you can start messing about with it - wreaking terrible havoc or curing diseases!

The next step  for me is to model the structure of another associated protein and then hopefully to do some dynamic modelling to see how these two proteins interact.

That's probably more than enough about that, but suffice to say it's really difficult and complicated and hence my opening paragraphs. If you really want to learn more about how it's all done then as an exercise for the Reader have a look here.

I'm due to go to Microsoft sometime in January and start a whole other side of things. Here's a quote from my supervisor Andrew:

"We are developing programming languages and tools for simulating and analysing complex models of biological systems. One of our aims is to develop a language in which large models of biological systems can be programmed from simple components in a modular fashion. The ultimate goal is to be able to program and test a biological system on a computer, before implementing the final design inside a living organism."

Programming Biology, Microsoft Research, 2008

--------------------------------------------------------

Changing tack: on the cultural front I've been to see several great films in the last few months - Gomorra and Waltz with Bashir stand out. Not exactly reassuring about humanity in general, but excellent nonetheless.

TV has been a dead zone as usual, with the exception of the IT Crowd. I'm making my way through the final series of Battlestar Galactica on DVD, but my heart isn't really in it. Like many series, it's gone on too long and just got stupid.

I went to see the Francis Bacon exhibition and I liked that a lot, especially the 1950's blue paintings themed around apprehension (yeah, what a surprise!) but it was very crowded.

Books I've recently read and rated:

James Sallis's Cripple Creek was fantastic. I wish I could write like him.

Justina Robson's Selling Out is maybe my favourite book of the year. Her cyborg protagonist Lila Black is my favourite character for some time. You need to read Keeping It Real first really.

I finished Bold As Love and I'm onto the next one, Gwyneth Jones is also a brilliant writer.

New music I've been enjoying:

Amadou & Mariam, Welcome to Mali. My French isn't good enough to know what they're singing about, but the music is upbeat and the whole fusion sound is really fresh.

Kings of Leon, Only by the Night. I have to be in the right mood to tolerate their style, but I guess I have been recently.
