Randy Newman, Harps & Angels. I don't normally go in for this kind of thing either - storytelling/social commentary songs - but he made me laugh several times (A few words in defence of our country, especially) and Feels Like Home and Potholes are just great songs.

Don't You Evah by Spoon is probably my favourite song of 2008.

That's it for this year then. Thanks for reading and the feedback. Always appreciated.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: "And if you know where the code is - you can start messing about with it - wreaking terrible havoc or curing diseases!" Coincidence or destiny that the above phrase ended up right next to a recommendation to read 'I Am Legend'...

More science please: I was just getting into your explanations and you stopped! Seems to me you're on the sharp end of all this; if your computer models work then they'll try it out on someone! Bagsy not me! Hey the html ...sort of works. Isn't this meant to be underlined? Is 'ul' underline? But I don't know why '...sort of works' (or this) is on a different line. It's not a Mac/PC thing is it?

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
This is going to be lengthy and hard going, but I'll try to make it as understandable and relevant to you the reader as possible.(And if anyone reading this wishes to ask for clarifications or give me feedback on what is not clear or just plain incorrect, that would be quite useful for me.)

I'm now over a month into my PhD and I thought I'd write something of what I'm doing, how I'm doing it and ultimately what it's all for. Which would be easier if I had some idea of it myself...ok here we go...the keyword here is partition. I several different partitions in my head, yet they are all connected: Immunology, Biochemistry, Cancer Sciences and Computing.

The human immune system is a remarkable thing and can, in theory, see off any pathogen it encounters. A pathogen being any disease inducing micro organism e.g. a virus like the common cold, bacteria like salmonella, a parasite like roundworms or a 'self' pathogen such as cancer.

However the immune system is a product of evolution and as most people know evolution is simply a selection mechanism for ensuring the survival of a population of organisms long enough so that it can reproduce a new generation. Hence it is often 'good enough' in its solutions to ensure survival of a species and as a consequence 'improvements' often get conserved and passed along. But it is not a system for designing the best solution to a problem in the way an engineer would.

This is an explanation for why we get cancers, allergies, diabetes etc. perhaps even mental illnesses. These are all the imperfections that affect us as individuals (often terribly) but affect the entire population in such a way as to give us a shot at sticking around long enough to have children.

Most of us are also familiar with vaccinations. This is where a 'safe' version of a microbe is introduced to the immune system to stimulate it to produce the necessary weapons in preparation for a real attack. This was the first real success medical science had in manipulating the immune system to work more effectively.

Vaccines essentially work as what is called an antibody mediating approach to immunity. That is to say that antibodies (target finders if you wish) tell the body what a foreigner looks like and then to kill it. The body can deal with some foreigners relatively easily when evolution has had lots of experience selecting for them and they are not too dangerous - like a dodgy bacteria infested kebab or a cold virus stuck in your nose. But a lot of things we’ve either never seen before or are less easy to deal with and more dangerous such as a polio or measles virus, which is why we need vaccines to pick up where evolution left off by priming us to have antibodies that can recognise these pathogens.

However our bodies are made of cells and viruses and cancers exist inside the cells and pretend they are part of us. The immune system needs a way to be able to distinguish between 'self' and 'non-self' when selecting what to kill. This is called cellular immunity which is what my work is really all about.

Essentially, all our cells have internal mechanisms for sampling the chemicals inside each cell and sending them to the surface so that the immune system cells can roam around the body surveying the surface of the cells for anything untoward. If it finds something it shouldn't i.e. a cell with a chemical on the surface indicating a virus inside it then sends it a message to commit suicide and the cell dies.

Cancer cells are our own cells - they are 'self' except they are 'self' gone wrong. They are cells that multiply grow out of control either killing us by causing our vital organs not to function any more or from lack of red blood cells that provide oxygen to our organs if it is leukaemia.

The immune system has evolved to distinguish between 'self' and 'non-self' to prevent it attacking our own bodies, attacking ourselves is called auto-immunity. However in the case of cancer it would obviously be desirable if the immune system did attack these cells and to some extent it does do this. In fact doctors are always interested in those apocryphal people who've "smoked 40 a day for 60 years and never did me any harm" because they may have something special about their immune system and that is why it never did them any harm.

If you've made it this far - that's some of the background - here's where I get to talk about what I'm doing:

Returning to the idea that our cells have internal mechanisms for selecting peptide fragments for presentation on the surface - that is to say molecules called proteins made from carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, oxygen, sulphur and phosphorus. What's truly remarkable is that these six elements can combine to produce a very very large number of different proteins (millions and millions). So the body has to have a way of selecting which ones are important and therefore to present. There is not enough time or energy for an effective immune response without some selection. It appears that the peptides presenting cancer are generally not strongly presented and therefore these cells often go unnoticed.

This mechanism is the heart of the problem and understanding it could ultimately lead to vaccines for cancer. In other words, in the same way that the immune system is prompted to produce the weapons needed to fight measles by the introduction of a deactivated measles virus to the body, a chemical that aids the presentation of the peptides that say 'I'm a cancer cell' would act as a vaccine by prompting the immune system to destroy it before it could do any real damage.

Understanding the mechanism is very difficult though. These molecules are made of many atoms and their function is determined through their shape as well as their composition. The process itself is dynamic and yet much of the information can only be gathered by means which are the equivalent of taking a few still pictures and trying to make a film out of them.

What I’ve been doing in this last two weeks then is trying to understand how to model the 3D structure of a molecular complex that is involved in this presentation process from its chemical sequence. This is done by comparison to known molecules and using the laws of physics to try and determine the shape it will take.The pictures at the top are my first attempts to do this. It really is working down at the atomic level and wasn’t what I expected I’d being doing at this point, but it’s all part of the overall problem. Welcome to my world of bioinformatics and biochemistry. The three images here are from my first bit of modelling (click on them to see them full size): They show a template molecule for which a structure is known on the left, while the other two are the same modelled molecule displayed in two ways – one as a ‘ribbon’ cartoon to show various functional components of the molecule and one as a ‘space-filling’ cartoon which indicates something of how it might really look if you could see it. It’s so small I can't think of an analogy to compare it to. Those lines coming off the model mean I still need to refine this model for it to be approaching a real molecule.

The point of this is that by understanding the structures one can start to understand the dynamic process. As I say, shape is conveying information as much as what it’s made of – think ‘thumbs up’ versus ‘the middle finger’ - they mean quite different things. Fundamentally it is all an information problem to my mind.

I’m now based over in Biochemistry having left the Hospital for a few months to do this, which is like some kind of old Nuclear Power Station, grey concrete with a maze of corridors. It does have an amazing view though. I can see the Isle of Wight from the window on a clear day.

A digression for the nerds – although I’m part sponsored by Microsoft and will be writing the Pi Calculus code under their guidance, the Biochemists are all on Unix, while some of the Cancer Sciences people run their analysis systems on Macs! It’s a good thing I regard computers just as machines like spoons or anything else – but another set of is partitions needed. I will say that I have been enjoying getting back to Linux, there is something really satisfying about the feeling of control one has when running things from the command line inside a shell and writing little scripts to tweak things just the way I need. It’s what I don’t like about the proprietorial systems, however beautiful their interface may be, I’m doing what they want which isn’t necessarily what I want. Though in the interests of full disclosure, I did have to spend half a day reinstalling Linux to get the laptop I’m borrowing running with Fedora, while the Vista partition booted no problem, so there’s no perfect answer. And unlike Mac or Windows things rarely 'just work'. And for the uber-nerds I’m writing Python scripts at the moment to do this modelling.

This probably sounds like it’s all going swimmingly, but on the emotional front this has all been exhausting and I’ve been arriving home depressed most nights for two weeks at just how out of my depth I am and how little I’ve achieved each day (plus ca change, eh?). And I’m in an office now, a proper office. If there’s one thing I’d hoped to avoid in my life it was an office job. Basically, I’m sat there with a laptop, a pile of textbooks and the realisation that there is not enough coffee in the world to make my brain work fast enough. ‘What have I done?’ followed by ‘Your choice idiot and you’re incredibly lucky, so suck it up and show some adaptability.’ is the usual conversation I have with myself each night...

If and when I get to grips with the Biochemistry, I then have to cross partitions to modelling at a higher level (the realm of cells rather than atoms) and potentially I’ll do some wet work too. I’ll save those details for another time. Who knows? Years down the line it may all ultimately feed into drug trials and improved cancer treatments.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I read the whole post. Do I qualify for some kind of award? Bodge, you are doing stirling work that may unltimately be of use to our pitiful species. Infinitely more worthwhile than anything us idiots in TV land are doing! Except for Jeremy Clarkson.
Cheers Mr. Cooper - your prize is a pint next time I see you. All you have to do to collect is get those Telecine people together in a pub - now that's a real challenge!

Hi Al, bit late on this - your warning of '1500 words' was warning enough to put me off reading the post until I had plenty of good time. Anyway, very concise and informative as usual; you really are very good at explaining complex things in an 'everyday' manner. (To be nitpicky/nerdy, watch your syntax; little words missed out make sentences difficult to read, e.g. 'They are cells that multiply AND grow out of control ---> killing us EITHER by causing our vital organs not to function any more or from lack of red blood cells that provide oxygen to our organs if it is leukaemia.' Sorry, twiddly, I know but your clarity is exemplary otherwise. And I know I'm far from prefect. Great pictures: the molecule looks like lots of men clustered together wearing very tight underpants.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
As a matter of staying sane, I try to not think about what people may be saying about me behind my back. In fact, I'm a bit like a small child in that I pretend that if I'm not there I don't exist for anyone else and I'm usually surprised if someone I meet says they've heard something about me - but today's revelation was a whole new level of weirdness:

I went into the Cancer Sciences Division building after lunch today and one of my new colleagues came up to me and said, 'There's a rumour going around the department that you used to work for MI5. Is this true?'

Of course the only appropriate response was to say that I could neither confirm or deny any involvement I may or may not have had in the past or the present with the Secret Services...

A bit later I met someone else I'd never met before, who took one look at me and said, 'Are you the Engineer?' Now that's a bit more like it. Thought my cover was slipping for a moment.

So anyway, I'm definitely not in Kansas any more. My induction goes on until Friday and I'm starting to think PowerPoint should be a Health and Safety issue, if it's not an actual abuse of my human rights. I've lost count of how many hours I've sat through and I really don't want to slag the process off, but I think they need to rethink the whole induction thing a bit. For me personally it's mostly serving to scare me as to how much I don't know and everyone else is pretty bored. There is something very passive about sitting through a PowerPoint presentation which unless it's really good (which is the exception) it's not a particularly good way to engage a group of people in my opinion. And I get the impression that most people presenting don't seem to get that unless a speaker is really gifted, most people switch off after a couple of minutes. Much like me typing this, if it's dull you won't have read this far!

Something I didn't explain last time, the Faculty of Life Sciences took in about 100 post-graduate students who I saw on the first morning. The School of Medicine took on about 35 of these, with whom I spent a week and as of last Thursday we're down the 6 of us in Cancer Sciences Division and from Monday, I'll be on my own doing my PhD.

The best thing I learnt on my induction so far (and props to my colleague Lyndsey for this) was that if one is falling asleep in a presentation/meeting, lift both feet off the floor. It forces one to contract all one's core muscles so one has to concentrate. 

I've been sitting through presentations on a whole range of stuff to do with Medical Research which I don't understand enough about to write about, but I really liked the one on Imaging where the guy showed us lots of cool pictures and told us how our brains interpret images and can be fooled, while explaining the different machines we can use. We had to wear 3D glasses for some of the images.

I'll be glad when it's done, but it doesn't detract from what I said last time about knowing how lucky I am. I'm looking forward to being a bit more active (once I get rid of this Freshers Flu).

Which segue ways nicely into mentioning the picture above of the running vest I wore for my first cross country race in four years. We look like the Southampton Football team out for a run. It was a beautiful autumn day up near Winchester and I came in 143rd out of 269 runners in 37m42s over the 9km. I'm very happy with that as a start and hope to move up the field as the season progresses. I'm not a particularly competitive person, but it's good to have training goals.

On the reading and watching front I've been getting into my Women's Science Fiction again. I'm about a third of the way into The Female Man by Joanna Russ and while I can see what a great book it is, it's such hard work because of the non-linear narrative style and trick of changing storyteller perspective mid-way through a paragraph,I doubt I'm gonna finish it.

Much easier reading and therefore more enjoyable for my tired brain is Bold as Love by Gwyneth Jones. If it finishes as strongly as it's started it may well be one of my favourites of the year. All about a young woman musician during a future dissolution of the United Kingdom. Funny and moving so far.

I've got another Justina Robson book waiting for me too.

And last night I went to see I've Loved You So Long. Which I thought was great. A proper old school Art Film. I'm sure my former lecturer would say there was too much talking and not enough story telling through pictures, but it was a little in the traditon of Eric Rohmer (to which it refers) and was a really powerful story about two sisters. And family. And love. The standard stuff of life. No car chases or special effects.

Right, better go clean my Walther PPK before bed, I don't want to get in trouble with Director Womack...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: ... as a member of MI5, you should be aware that MI6 are currently using powerpoint presentations as a torture device - so simple yet so violent.
Great blog Al. (And an even better comment from 'jen'. (Not the Jen I live with, I know, I checked.) Good luck with the secret mission. Make good use of the 3D glasses!

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
This is really a post for myself (well they all are, but this more so) to try and make some sense of the chaos in my head after the last week.
I woke up this morning primed to get up and run the 12 miles on my training schedule and clear my head and while I don't mind the rain, it's too heavy and windy to consider yet. And so I've ended up wasting my morning stressing about things I can't control like I know I shouldn't. Maybe I can run later, this will do in the meantime.

Anyway, I've had a week of induction for my PhD and I still have two weeks to go. I was exhausted come Friday and not a little overwhelmed by the experience, as well as daunted by what is still to come.

First of all, despite feeling pretty grumpy after about 10 Power point presentations on Monday, when I was walking to the hospital on day two on Wednesday I did find myself considering just how privileged I am. People are paying me to learn stuff, that's got to make me one of the luckiest people alive and I wonder how many of my colleagues feel the same? Having done some pretty rubbish jobs and had some pretty awful experiences in my time, I am one lucky person, no doubt. However it feels.

Induction is like peeling an onion. Day One started with the all of the Life Sciences Faculty new Post-Graduates first thing at the Boldrewood Campus. So that was people from Medicine, Nursing, Bio-Sciences, Psychology, Biology etc. I was pleasantly surprised to see Liz there, who started on Civil Eng with me, so it wasn't an entire room of strangers. And I'd gone in with the hope meeting one person I could get along with, so I'd achieved that goal straight away.

After a couple of hours of Power Point, we got sent off to our respective Schools within the Faculty. I've been assigned to Medicine, even though I'm really as much a part of Biochemistry and Computer Science in what I'll be doing. So that's the next layer of the onion.

Over at the General Hospital is where the School of Medicine is based. The next sessions (of Power Point, did I mention they use Power Point a lot yet?) were then consisting of people doing Medical Research: Nutritionists, Medical Doctors, Cancer Scientists etc. We started with the usual Health and Safety stuff and overview of the School (which is huge) then had a tour and that was it for the day. And I met another nice person.

Tuesday was International Student Day, so I didn't have to attend and took the opportunity to do other chores.

Wednesday was the start of the School Induction proper. Lots more presentations/lectures about what research is all about, how to develop a hypothesis. Most interesting that day was the session on the Ethics of Human Research.

This gave me a chance to hear from my new colleagues how they think a bit. It made me think (not for the first time) that everyone should have the opportunity to experience working/mixing with people in fields outside their own. That again speaks to my feeling of privilege. I've attended Art school and mixed with people from that background, I've worked and studies with Engineers/Physicists and Mathematicians and now I'm mixing with people from the Medical world. It really opens my mind each time I hear how different people experience and understand the world. 

In this instance we had to look at and discuss an AIDs prevention study in South Africa. In the discussion what struck me most was that while my instincts are more technical - how do we make sure it's worthwhile and done properly/safely? - much of what other people were saying was more immediately human - concerns about dignity of the participants for example. Aiming for the same things, but coming at them from a different perspective.

The next day we had an Animal Ethics lecture, which was to me the most sobering and interesting session of the first week. Following on from the more generalised discussion about human ethics, to use an American expression this one really went to where the rubber meets the road. I found it quite moving in some respects as the speaker talked about the dilemmas of killing animals to save humans. It certainly left me in no doubt, whatever your views on animal experimentation, it is something that is thought about in great detail by those involved and not taken lightly in any aspect. She talked about pain alleviation, sentience of the animals involved, licensing, differing cultural attitudes towards animals and how decisions are made as to proceeding with any proposed experiments. I was surprised to discover that all medication in this country has to be tested on animals prior to licensing - some to think about when you next have a cold or headache - some creature died to make sure that you don't when you pop that pill. And unlike modern human research, they didn't get to chose to participate.

For me personally, I'll be building a tool that one day, if successful, may be used to design drugs. So it's given me a lot to think about in terms of the possible consequences of my actions following this path. As an engineer, one is always made to consider the consequences of messing up and designing for that. This is different.

Many of the rest of the sessions this week have been about dealing with Administration involved in doing research and techniques of searching literature and developing skills related to written work in research such as avoiding plagiarism. To be fair, dull as it often has been listening to that stuff, it does demonstrate the great efforts they make to help us get started.

Next week, I have three more days introducing me to a whole bunch of stuff actually about medicine and biology such as an overview of stem cell research. That's where I'm getting daunted. I have a to repeat, 'Don't Panic' in my head several times a day when I remember how much I don't know and need to learn. So many known unknowns, let alone all the unknown unknowns.

Then on Thursday, I reach the third layer of the onion and head off to my Division within the School within the Faculty within the University for more induction. Confused yet? I know I am. 

My Division is Cancer Sciences and I can see I've got more Health and Safety and a whole load of lab induction stuff for example - fusion protein tools - whatever that is. Still trying to get my head around the definition of a protein.

That takes me through to the 17th of October and if I haven't leapt from the Itchen Bridge in despair by that point I might actually start doing some work on my PhD itself.

It's taken me hour to write that and it's stopped raining, so I can finally go out and run. Yay! And actually it does make a bit more sense now I've typed it up.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
This picture is more or less how I remember the summer of 2008. Grey. Still, at least I had a proper holiday this year. A week camping in France.

I've just about finished moving home for the first time in four years - which was a lot more hassle than I thought, but on the whole an improvement so far - and on Monday I begin my induction to the School of Medicine. It still has an air of unreality about it when I write that and I'd completely forgotten I'd even got a degree until someone at work asked me a few days ago if I'd finished it yet.

Medicine - it's one of the last areas I'd have expected to end up working four years ago or even 20 years ago.

But, for better or worse I start a PhD on Monday and I'm getting pretty nervous about it. I was advised to get two textbooks to start with on Molecular Biology (each over 1000 pages) and so far I'm about 100 pages into one of them. I'm not sure how soon I need to be up to speed  with that stuff, but I've also got to start learning the programming language too. Definite feeling that I'm unprepared, standing at the bottom of a mountain and trying to convince myself that it's just a bunch of small steps repeated to get to the top!

The weirdest thing has been visiting the hospital a couple of times and realising that this is to be a place of work for me soon. I'm hoping I become desensitised to going there as I felt really uncomfortable both times I've been so far.

There's quite a lot of lectures too - introductions to electron microscopy, modules on statistics in medicine, that sort of thing. Which I'm looking forward to doing. New stuff is usually fun.

I have had a fair bit of time for reading over the summer and I've read a general introductory book on Immunology which has been really interesting so I expect to find the subject enjoyable on that level - lots of facts like how mothers kissing babies helps their children's immune system that I've been boring anyone who'll listen with - but it is mind blowing in it's complexity. Which is kind of the point of the PhD - getting a handle on the complexity so it is manageable and understandable and can be put to use.

Not a lot else to say really. Did a calculation a few weeks back where I estimated I spent 85-90% of the time in an average week over the summer on my own, which was slightly surprising even to me. Not read any really great books (except I am Legend which is so good I read it in a day), just a bunch of average ones and likewise with films. See the side bar for links.

I'm intending to join a running club for the cross country season and that's my only new plan at the moment. I've missed doing that in the last few years, but I've often been working on Saturdays.

Actually, I only got the confirmation of funding through last Friday and so I'm not officially doing a PhD until I sign and return the offer form, so I've still got time to change my mind...

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
The above picture is of a street sign in Southampton that I saw last week and had to take a picture of. I thought I was so jaded that nothing could surprise me, but this managed to make me laugh. I didn't realise that this society had become quite so insane that we need calorie counts on our street signs, but I was obviously wrong. Definitely a sign of the times if you'll excuse the awful pun.

There's a sentence in The Left Hand of Darkness that goes something along the lines of that while it's good to have a destination, it's the journey itself that is most important. And so it has been with the last four years and so I find it difficult to sum up my feelings about this period on arrival at this point in any simple way as they are somewhat conflicted. But for my own record I should say something. It has been really hard work, most days I've questioned what the hell am I doing and I'm so used to things going badly it's kind of disorientating to succeed. I didn't really realise how much it mattered to me to get a first until I was walking down to pick up my results and I started to feel like I wanted to puke and once I saw the bit of paper it was mostly relief that I felt. In terms of overall lessons learned then I'd return to two of my favourite mantras of recent years, Louis Pasteur's, "Fortune favours the prepared mind" and my paraphrasing of running writer Arthur Newtons advice, "You are only fit for for what you do". This is because in my experience hard work and determination combined with a willingness to reflect, learn and adapt when faced with one's mistakes/faults will make up for a lack of talent in many situations. Although this usually gets distilled down to the words 'Suck it up!'  playing on a loop in my mind when things get tough and I have the urge to give in.

Another benefit I find of doing a science based subject is that it regularly serves to remind me of my own insignificance in the scheme of things either numerically or in terms of the relative nature of the problems that I face in my daily life. I'm far too self-indulgent as it is and so it's useful for me to have a counter balance. Speaking of self-indulgence, time keeps on moving forward whether I like it or not and so to the future...

Last Tuesday after I got my results I went for an interview for a PhD over in the Biological Sciences department and I've since accepted the offer to do a PhD with them starting in October. This probably sounds quite bizarre after all this time spent in Engineering and in some respects it is I suppose, but it seemed like such an unusual opportunity (arising from a discussion in the pub) that I thought I'd regret it if I turned it down. I'll try to explain it as best I can, but even the supervisors are not sure what I'm exactly likely to end up with a PhD in!

I know next to nothing about immunology, but from the little background reading I've done since this PhD was proposed to me what I understand is that our body has cells that can act as police going around killing (among others) cells that are infected with cancer. However for these killer cells (Cytotoxic T-cells) to kill cancer cells they need to be able to recognise the cancer cells and they can only do this when they present in certain ways. Researchers have been trying to develop ways to force cancer cells present themselves to our bodies immune system so that our own bodies can kill the cancer with these killer T-cells by influencing the way the cancer cells develop - essentially interfering in the process with drugs - but in order to do this they need to understand the process by which cells are encoded to present themselves either as infected or not infected to the T-cells, which is still mostly a mystery. Still with me?! It's time to change disciplines.

Over in Computer Science, researchers have been trying to develop languages to describe and model systems which act as networks. I guess everyone has some concept of what a network is these days, whether it's a railway network, the internet or a group of people. More concisely though it can be described a system of concurrent processes.

The immune system is also a kind of network and therefore in theory it should be possible to model it using a language developed for other things like a mobile phone network. At present the Biological Science researchers have begun to develop a model of how infected cancer cells present and gathered some data based on in vivo lab experiments. While separately the computer science researchers have developed the language and begun developing a corresponding model in the computer. What they both need is someone to train up and work full time across both disciplines in order to take this work forward and develop both the lab and computer experiments. And that's the role I'll be taking on and why it's such an unusual and interesting opportunity. I'll be inducted to work in three locations, the Southampton General Hospital in the laboratory doing biological experiments and at the Southampton University Campus and up at a Computer Research Centre in Cambridge doing computer modelling.

The aim of the game then is to develop a model in which what is observed in the lab with real cells can be simulated in the computer like for like and then ultimately to start developing some kind of predictive model for guiding the development, in a speedier and more systematic way, of drugs that will help T-cells find the infected cancer cells and destroy them. Should be a piece of cake!

At which point I'll move onto Equality for Everyone, World Peace and then Time Travel of course, before tackling the really tough problems like making sure people don't drift into my path as if drawn to me magnetically when I'm trying to walk around them on the pavement...

Actually, it's pretty daunting just looking at the Introduction to Immunology textbook I bought today, but like I say I thought I'd regret if I didn't at least have a go, even if it's a disaster. The main selling points for me are that it is inter-disciplinary and as it is joint funded by the Medical Research Council and Microsoft, the money is confirmed and is a fair bit better than the Civil Engineering option. And all three of the supervisors seemed like really good people to work for/with which clinched the deal at the interview from my side. Hopefully it'll equip me with skills and knowledge that mean I'll be able to either get a job or carry on with more research at the end of the three or so years this will take. At the moment it's only a verbal confirmation and I suppose I shouldn't make too many plans until the paperwork is signed, but hopefully it'll all go through ok now.

So I've got a couple of months now to do some background reading, earn a bit of money, find somewhere new to live and I've got a stack of novels to read. Rather annoyingly now I have time to go to the cinema there is nothing on, so I guess I'll track down some things on DVD.

item.title: The Journey Begins
item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Thanks for joining me!
Good company in a journey makes the way seem shorter. — Izaak Walton

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It’s been so long since I wrote this as I find that when it comes to feelings very little changes. In fact, it’s kind of remarkable how little difference I feel as I grow older. It’s like I’ve felt the same for as long as I can remember. I know I must have changed and be changing, but internally I don’t notice. It’s pretty disappointing – to paraphrase Tokyo Story.

So I thought I’d make an effort to write about what I’ve been doing instead. I’ve got ten months left of my three year research post in Southampton investigating the immune system. This project is unusual in that I’ve involved in all parts of it: the design of the experiments, performing the experiments and analysing and presenting the data. What’s nice about this (but challenging) is that I have intimate knowledge of the whole thing and all the problems. Most of the project has been about developing the methodology to actually do the project, both in terms of experiments and analysis, and while there will be some new immunological knowledge at the end, the real benefit will be felt by those that use these tools to build on this work. A larger project involving both Oxford and Southampton using patient cancer tumour samples has been funded by Cancer Research UK partly as a consequence of this project. I don’t get any personal benefit from that, just the warm glow of knowing that I’ve made my tiny indirect contribution to knowledge that may increase some peoples chances of surviving cancer in the future.

In thinking about my own future I’ve been working through the materials provided by 80,000 hours. This is a number representing the length of the average career. It speaks to question I’ve been mulling since I was still in my 20s about what does it mean to make a meaningful contribution and “do some good”? One of the ironies of following their career guide was that biomedical researcher – my current job – was one that it suggested I pursue! For reasons I won’t go into, this may no longer be a viable option for me. But I have found 80,000 hours very helpful in thinking about this question, and the various ways that one can contribute beyond more obvious directions such as helping people by being a medical doctor or teacher.

One option it’s had me revisit is the “earning to give”, and taking the pledge to donate 10% of my income to charity. This is the idea that one is likely do more good in the world by earning at a sufficiently high income that giving 10% away would save more lives than training to be a doctor would. This assumes one doesn’t become an arms trader or some such choice! I find it a really difficult concept, as it’s so abstract to think that giving thousands of pounds away for things like malaria nets, or just directly giving money to the poorest people (as I did last year) is the most helpful thing one could do. But the science suggests is that it is one of the best ways to actually help. And despite meaning less holidays or material goods in my life, I’d still be in the top 5% richest people in the world having given away 10% of my earnings. I still haven’t made the pledge, but I am seriously considering it. Over 20 years I could expect to have saved around 80 lives. As I’ll never see or know these 80 people it’s very intangible and doesn’t stroke my ego the way that experiencing the results of my actions would do.

I should clarify that there are big problems other than global health and poverty and therefore making a high impact contribution could, for example, mean pursing a career in policy or advocacy to promote equal rights, or a reduction in factory farming, or the challenges of climate change etc. etc. But giving away money is possibly the simplest thing that people like me can do that the evidence suggests will actually have an impact. I'd also mention that the 80,000 hours site is excellent for all sorts of evidence based information about many aspects of work, such as how to develop better social skills or cold emailing prospective contacts. All things I could definitely improve upon.

Something else I’ve done in the last year, both for the selfish reasons described and less selfish, that helps people directly, is train to be a Data Carpentry/Software Carpentry Instructor. Since 2013 I’ve become a keen user of the statistical programming language R. And I’ve also become aware that many many people have data they are trying to make sense of, but don’t know how best to do it. These people can be anyone in any field. I’ve helped train Archaeologists and Physicists. Biologists and Social Scientists. And it’s really rewarding, learning and teaching other people. I've always been much better at helping other people solve their problems than solving my own. Must be something to do with perspective.

Recently, I finally joined a social media network. Twitter. This was motivated partly by low level harassments at my intransigence around social media, and partly after attending a science conference in Dublin in September. There was a scientist from the US there called Atul Butte, calls himself a data parasite, and he gave an inspiring talk that pushed a few buttons in me. One was the criticism about how scientists do science to publish papers and not solve problems. But the main thrust was that scientists generate tons of data that never gets used to solve problems, but could be. He gave a couple of great examples about using publicly available date to identify how existing drugs could be re-targeted to use cancer, and how existing data could be used to identify markers of disease to which new drugs could be made. He also talked about twitter as a tool of the job, which is kind of a complicated subject in itself, but I figured I could try it out. Don’t expect too much action, but you can reach me here: @alistair604.

And maybe I’ll have a stab at using some of that publicly available data too. For example, I was thinking about seeing whether new anti-parasitic targets could be identified from the all the data on worms that’s out there. If only there was more time and I had more energy. If anyone has any fun ideas for data analysis drop me a line.

I think at the moment my ideal job would be something along the lines of a job where I could still do research some of the time, and one where I could work with people, especially people who don't identify as using code, or are from backgrounds that don't traditionally think of computing as being for them (and yet probably use all sorts of devices and software all day long) to help them to develop the skills they need for the problems they are trying to solve. Possibly Research Software Engineering, but I'm not sure academia is the path for me. I do think that data/coding skills are an equality issue, and if we're ever going to beat the idiots we need to give as many, and as diverse a range of people as possible the skills to gather and examine the data and figure out what the most important problems are and how we solve them.

Or I could just stay home with the Bibi cat. My neighbours cats Bibi and her sister Belle have decided they live here at least 50% of the time. After sticking her murder mittens into my neck she's snoozing, but it can only be a matter of time before she wakes up and creates havoc. (I'm on a break in my experiment and don't have to be back at work until 7.30pm).

For those that are interested, one of the things I learnt  whilst in Dublin about what’s hot in the area of science I work in is the drive for personalised medicine. This is really problematic as it involves gathering data about individuals in terms of genes, blood, stool samples, and real time data such as heart rate from wearable devices. This is potentially incredibly powerful in saving lives – it would be fantastic to spot symptoms of cancer or a stroke long before they happen, and to know which specific drug or intervention is best likely to work for you. However, it’s another step towards total surveillance and zero privacy. He’s an example about a geneticist I know. Her parents chose to have DNA genotyping for fun. And what they found out was that they both carried the same gene associated with dementia. This means she also has the gene because we get our copy from one of our parents. Therefore if they both have it, she’s guaranteed to have it. Point being, she’s been diagnosed with a risk of dementia without her consent because of data someone else (her parents) chose to gather. And that’s just a simple example of what can go wrong. Who’s storing this data? And what might they do with it? There are lots of risks as well as benefits to gathering all this information. Challenging times ahead.

Oh, and I bought a car a couple of weeks ago. 44 years old and my first car. Is that unusual in the UK? Not sure. I used it to go up to Beacon Hill near Winchester on Saturday from where I took the picture at the top.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Murder mittens. Lol! What car? Make and model, and colour please. As ever, your blog is very interesting but what are you going to do/aim for in 10 months? Despite your early remarks, you come across as very confident and sure about what you like and like to do. Good luck in assimilating them into your life.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
There's two bits from the book 2312 that I regularly think about: one is the comment that no useful thoughts occur between midnight and 5 am, and the other is pseudoiteration. This second concept is best illustrated in the following (edited) quote from the book about the character Wahram's relationship with habits and the pseudoiterative:

Habits begin to form at the very first repetition. After that there is a tropism toward repetition, for the patterns involved are defenses, bulwarks against time and despair...Wahram was very aware of this, having lived the process many times; so he paid attention to what he did when he traveled, on the lookout for those first repetitions that would create the pattern of that particular moment in his life...Too often in his past, meaninglessness had gnawed at the edges of things. He needed order, and a project; he needed habits...habits were not truly iterative but pseudoiterative. The pattern of the day might be the same, in other words, but the individual events fulfilling the pattern were always a little bit different. Thus there was both pattern and surprise, and this was Wahram’s desired state: to live in a pseudoiterative. But then also to live in a good pseudoiterative, an interesting one, the pattern constructed as a little work of art. No matter the brevity of the trip, the dullness of the terrarium or the people in it, it was important to invent a pattern and a project and pursue it with all his will and imagination.

2312
Kim Stanley Robinson

The psuedoiterative came to mind again following lunchtime discussion about the fact I hadn't posted a blog in nearly a year, and my response that my life is repetitive in ways that are are indeed a defence against the world, but probably not very interesting to read about again and again. But then again, on reflection I do also seek out both pattern and surprise, so here's a round of the things that are new in my psuedoiterative world in the last year:

Social media

I finally signed up for Spotify as my only real foray into the world of social media, and have been amazed at just how good it is. One of my hobby's is to study, and I've been doing Coursera Data Science and Machine Learning Courses in the last 12 months so know a little bit about how Spotify works, but it really is excellent at finding music I like. And I make no comment on whether Spotify is good or bad for the music industry, but as a product that delivers music I want to hear it's really impressed me. If anyone wants to share music with me or listen to what I'm listening to, drop me a line and I'll tell you how to find me. I'm afraid I still have no real desire to join Facebook or Twitter, these aren't communities I feel I would be an active part of at the moment, and I'm also concerned they'd make connections that probably aren't good for me, and create itches that I'd struggle to resist scratching.

Books

One book I'm currently reading is Why It Does Not Have To Be In Focus which examines 100 photos, largely from the last 20 years. It's perfect for me, as I can dip in and out rather than worry about reading from start to finish. Anyhow, I was drawn to it because my life largely Art-free these days, and I recalled how much I used to love photography (along with Films and TV). It's really reignited my love of the form and the process, and after discussion with a colleague who amazed me by revealing she's nearly at the end of 5 years of taking a photo a day, has recommended the Fuji fixed lens cameras to me as the closest digital cameras to analogue that are portable. They are quite pricey, but I might splash out and get back to taking some shots.

One of my favourite photo's of which I have a postcard version from many years ago is Nan Goldin's Anthony by the sea shot in Brighton in 1979. I like this photo partly due to narcissism (I imagine it could be me in the picture and the ambivalence of the pose), partly because it captures Brighton the way I think of it, and partly because it reminds of Edward Hopper and his obsession with light, particularly Sun in an empty room and Rooms by the sea which is something I share, particularly at this time of year.

On the fiction front, my favourite read so far this year is Uprooted by Naomi Novik. It's a sort of fairy tale, and one of those rare books that manages to work on many levels in terms of being fun, moving and making me think. I've also really enjoyed Luna by Ian MacDonald, The Masked City by Genevieve Cogman and the latest Christopher Brookmyre, Joe Abercrombie, James S.A. Corey books.

Films and TV

I've not been to the cinema this year! And I've not watched many at home, of those I've only seen a one films that I really liked as a piece of cinema which was Girlhood. Going back to the way I was taught to look at film, this fitted the definition of cinema in that so much is conveyed without words, in both the joy of friendship and the sadness of her situation. I highly recommend it. I also enjoyed Sicario,which while not in the same league as Girlhood was a pretty intense thriller/Western, albeit ridiculous, morally and politically dubious as these things usually are. What we do in the shadows is a particularly fine spin on the mockumentary genre if you need a laugh.

We've signed up for Netflix too, and there's nothing new on there that I'd say is particularly amazing - mostly cos I'm old and have seen it all before - but I did enjoy the retro-fest of Stranger Things. And there's lots of old stuff like Alan Partridge, Breaking Bad and classic films that makes it good value for money

Holidays

I've been very lucky on the holiday front this year and had four short trips away: Wales twice, New York, and Scotland. South Wales in early spring was beautiful, we had a flat in an incredibly ugly block looking over the sea meaning both the view, sound and smell were fantastic. I took this one at sunset, the dog licked me:

Then I went back with Steve and family for a short, but excellent camping trip just along the coast in August. There's something about swimming in the sea that is just one of the best things a person can do, especially when it was me, Grace, Pearl and Steve with body boards too. There's an e.e cummings poem that sums it up nicely. Here's a picture of the aftermath, with Stan chilling with Huey:

And Huey could not get enough of the tennis ball:

New York was May, which wasn't the most relaxing of trips, but it's a great place to explore. And excellent vegan food too. I don't have any pictures that aren't anything like you can't Google.

Glasgow and Moray was September. We did a walking tour in Glasgow run by the School of Art, which was excellent and again took me back to Art school days and that great feeling when someone makes you see something you never noticed before or in a new way. Then we went up to Culbin near Inverness in Moray. The drive through the Highlands itself was impressive, but Culbin Edge was near perfect. If you're looking for a peaceful place with all modern life's conveniences then I can recommend it. We were really lucky and saw the Northern Lights and the Milky Way. Here's the view from the cabin (check out the website if you want to see the cabin itself):

Science

I'm exactly a year into my three year project. It's really hard work, but it's going pretty well. I'm moaned a lot previously about the downs of academic life in the last couple of posts. None of that really changes. Neither does the fact of me being really extremely lucky to be doing what I'm doing. I don't know if this will be my last job in science, but if it is I feel like we might actually do some solid work this time around. Maybe I can write more about what it is I'm doing another time if anyone is interested?

And finally

I'm still using the sleep tracking, it mostly shows how badly I sleep! Nightmares, restlessness etc. I bought a Pebble to use with it, which has turned out to be really useful for other things. I never miss a phone call, text message or appointment (or can switch it to silent if I want to be left alone) or mislay my phone. I use it for timings too. I was so impressed I helped fund the next generation on Kickstarter so I'll be getting a new one that can also monitor fitness and can dictate text message responses. If you like modern technology as much as me, or have hearing difficulties, then I recommend them. Very handy for living the pseudoiterative.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I love the poem!

For most people the pseudoiterative is routine(!) And yes, every day is different within a routine, always. What is the object out of focus on the horizon of the first camping picture? Haven't seen you for a long time Al, good to read another blog from you :-) Disappointed you're not joining Facebook but I will check out your Spotify listens if you'll send me the link. I'm always curious as to what you're listening to. Maybe we can get it together over Xmas having failed to contact you again during the summer. Great to read that you've had several holidays. Email me your Spotify link. (I don't do Spotify very often except to check out a CD (or vinyl!) before I buy it. That's if I remember after I've heard something I like.) Mostly buying very obscure stuff these days. Looking forward to hearing from you and we must get something together soon!!

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
An update from last time, as things have moved forward. The paper containing work from my PhD that began in 2011 was finally published on October 20th. It's open access, so should you be so inclined, you can read/download it here: http://www.nature.com/articles/srep14928

As intimated last time, it was something of a death march, so I just feel a bit numb now that it's all over. Maybe with time I'll look back on it as an achievement, but at the moment I don't feel much about it.

More importantly, the contract for the proteomics project finally also got signed on the 1st of October - not this has prevented the ever efficient University HR department sending me a redundancy notice this week! But once that's sorted, I now have a contract for three years, and hopefully we'll do some interesting science. It's a nice change to be back in lab, learning new things, and being science immediately I've run into lots of problems we hadn't anticipated. But I guess that's the fun of it really. If one doesn't like problem solving, then it's not the right job. I'll try and put some photos together cos I think labs look quite fun and exciting if you're unfamiliar with them. And the techniques can seem quite magical (not necessarily in a good way).

Other things I've been up to are my data science learning, which I've really enjoyed, and this month I made my first web app. Again this might only be useful if you do a job which requires measuring things out and making up solutions, and apps exist that do this already, but it was fun to figure out how to create one. You can play with it here: https://ab604.shinyapps.io/biochem_calculator and if you want to play with the code, the repo is here: https://github.com/ab604/biochem_calculator

As you may or may not know – I hate getting up! Especially now the clocks have gone back. So to make life easier I’ve investigated a couple of things. Here are my finding and suggestions for what it’s worth.

Health Warning: This may all be placebo!

That said, the idea is that we wake naturally from the ‘light sleep’ part of the sleep cycle – supposedly the dawn has light at blue frequencies that trigger a cascade of hormones and neurotransmitters that move us to the part of the cycle that wake us up. Consequently, if one wakes suddenly from a deep sleep or REM sleep we get ‘sleep inertia’ as our hormones readjust.

  1. Dawn Simulator – I’ve used this in winter for about three years, and I think it helps. It gradually comes on over 30 minutes before my alarm goes off. I think the light should be more blue, but it seems to work to an extent. It’s gentle.
  2. Sleep Cycle App – this uses an accelerometer in your phone or wristband to assess which sleep phase you are in due the amount of movement you are making. You set an alarm time and it tries to waking you in a 30 minute window around that time by assessing when you are in light sleep.

One a practical note, I’d say the dawn simulator is best, as it will always come on and alarm at the same time (which is important if you have to leave for work at a specific time), and the point of the light is to wake me gently rather than spot when I’m in the correct phase.

But the sleep app is really good for analysing your sleep, for naps and you can set it to tell you when you need to go to bed. The other advantage of the sleep app is that if you share a bed with someone who gets up at a different time, you’re less likely to wake them, as you can set a vibrating alarm.

We have this Dawn Simulator: Bodyclock

Sleep Apps:

Sleep as Android £2.99 (14 day free trial, Android only. I use this one)  

Sleep Cylce £0.99 (iOS and Android)

Finally, a few recommendations:

In the music world I finally signed up for Spotify and have been pleasantly surprised with how good it is. Both in terms of catalogue and in recommending me things I might like. On heaviest rotation since September has been Jason Isbell Something more than free, but then I've long had a soft spot for country music.

 Book-wise, I've absolutely loved Aurora by Kim Stanley Robinson. All about interstellar space travel, what it means to be human and entropy. It introduced me to a fantastic, but sad poem called The City by C.P. Cavafy (I like the Lawrence Durrell translation). I'm now reading The Traitor which, so far, is also a fantastic book about the use of economic power and belief to control people, told through the eyes of one woman. Other recent reads are on the side bar, but those are my top reads of 2015 so far alongside The best of all possible worlds by Karen Lord.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Looking forward to photos of yourself and your assistant, Beaker. :-)

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
There are few things I consider a sin, but self-pity is one of them. Which along with the general sense of ennui that I have makes me want to delete everything I write most days. However, Chris you gave me permission to moan, so here goes:

As an exercise for myself and something I thought my potentially be of interest to other people, I've created a graphic of my life in science since 2008 (If it's hard to read, you can download it here). It's certainly not capturing all the nuances, such as the differences in scale and scope between my PhD project and Fellowship project, but hopefully it does provide some sense of my experience of life in the world of science and academia. Both the mundane reality that it's the minority of my time that's spent doing what probably most of us imagine scientists to be doing i.e. experiments, and the privilege that I get paid to learn and have a great deal of autonomy.

One thing I wanted to show, and I'd expect this is true for many walks of life, is how scientists are always having to look ahead to when the money runs out, spending considerable time in the present securing funding for the future. I can see how this is good for preventing complacency, but it is a big distraction from the job in hand, and a regular source of anxiety.

Drawing this time line also got me thinking about what science is, and why the hell me or anyone would do it. In terms of a definition I found myself in agreement with this recent paper that describes science as: "Specifically, it is an approach that strives to better approximate the state of nature by reducing errors in inferences." Which to me is a more precise version of Feynmans: science is the best way we have of not fooling ourselves.

However, these definitions are very terse and needs unpacking, which is done excellently in a paper from 1996 called The Myths of Science, but that's sadly behind a pay-wall. What it addresses is the notions that most of us have that there is a single method of doing science, that science follows a linear path from prediction to experiment and validation. The notion that science is about procedures (e.g. experiments) rather than creativity, the notion that scientists are any better than anyone else at being objective, the notion that all questions can be addressed by science, and that the process is honest.

I'll just pick up on two of these:

As someone who has an opinion on most things, I'm acutely aware that these are just opinions, and would be horrified if someone considered them authoritative statements. And yet, I get the impression that many people think that scientists are somehow more objective and smarter than average! Including many scientists themselves. There are two good reasons to suppose this may well be false: One is that all humans have biases and prejudices of one sort or another, doing science doesn't make you immune to being an idiot (see Tim Hunt). Second, is that each scientist only really has a narrow area of expertise, making them pretty much ignorant about everything else, just like everyone else. Beware any scientist holding forth on subjects they don't actively study, there's often no reason to suppose they know any more than you do.

The second myth is the linear path to scientific discovery. What I'd pick up here, which is related to scientific objectivity, is the role of luck. This seems true in general, but success is often as much a matter of luck as judgement. And yet, as has been documented (Tavris & Aronson) when things go well we congratulate ourselves on our amazing foresight and genius, but when they go badly it was just bad luck, or more likely, someone else's fault. Funny isn't it? I certainly think that it's possible to increase one's chances of things going well under specific circumstances, but so many things are beyond one's control that we can't ignore the importance of serendipity or even untangle what was luck and what was judgement much of the time. For example, I came to a scientific paper the other day by Google that seems to have a method that would be useful to me. I read it, tried the method out, got stuck, emailed the lab in Germany who'd developed the method, got it working with their help, and now await some results. If it goes well is that luck or am I clever? Or a bit of both? Perhaps if I'd kept looking I'd have found something better? Perhaps if the guy had been on holiday when I emailed, I'd have given up and tried something else? It's certainly not the linear: hypothesis, experiment, conclusions model everyone learns at school. More like: what's the next most obvious question? how the hell do I test it? Google the literature, pick something promising, give it a whirl, if that's no good, try something else. Repeat until I get an unambiguous answer or give up! Doing science is more a case of collecting and developing a set of tools, or a library of experiences to apply, and sometimes it's just a case of looking at things and making observations and connections, more akin to a creative process that a formal method of clear steps. 

So I ask myself, why do I do science? Three things I enjoy in life: Physical activity and problem solving (you can take the ape out of Africa, but you can't take the ape out of me), and Visual/Written Media (exposure to ideas in the form of TV, films, Art and books). As with the other two, spending my time figuring things out keeps me from worrying about my impending doom, and I seem to have some adeptness at problem solving which itself is a form of positive feedback and coping mechanism. I figure we all gravitate towards things we have some intrinsic abilities in. And the more I do it, the more comfortable I am with having my ideas challenged and shown to be incorrect. I'm not a masochist, but making mistakes and getting it wrong is a fundamental part of the process. And as I am someone who is easily fooled and doesn't consider ignorance bliss, if science is the best way we have of not fooling ourselves, then it's nice to have tools for being slightly less duped if possible. 

The reality of doing science in my personal experience is that it is much more about failure than success. Sure you can see the number of rejections for our paper, but I'm really talking about the fact that most ideas are wrong and therefore most of my work goes in the bin of bad ideas. This is a good thing! It hopefully means that what is left is what is worth keeping. Too much failure though and not enough success means that the funding will dry up and I'll be out of a job (true in most professions I imagine). I don't have ambitions beyond getting paid to find out interesting things, but I have to play the game and act like I care about "a career". And I have never been in my comfort zone since I started doing science either, it's an ocean of uncertainty. So, if you asked me today what are the job requirements for being a scientist I'd say 50% of it comprises of these four things:

  1. Resilience to failure.
  2. At ease with uncertainty.
  3. Good organisation.
  4. Good communication.

The other 50% is luck.

For myself, after nearly 8 years I can't really point to any scientific output of mine that make any real contribution to the sum total of human understanding, and that's a bit grinding, but I'd be surprised if that's uncommon. I've probably got until about the end of 2018 to make my mark before I'll struggle to get further funding. And I'm not really sure how to gauge whether I'm spending my life wisely or not. The road to hell is definitely paved with good intentions, so I know that intentions aren't necessarily what matters.

That said, I went to a conference a few weeks back and there was an inspiring Professor from the USA who reminded me of the all the potential for making the world a better place that the area of science I work in has. She had a really nice way of posing the problem - our genes tell us about our ancestry, but our proteome also tell us about our present and our future. Our proteome are the proteins that our genes express that make us, us. (If genes are the recipe, proteins are the cake.) The important point here is that we are born with our genes, but much of what happens in terms of whether they are expressed i.e. make they protein encode is due to the environment e.g. what we eat, how much sun we get. Or it is to do with our age, whether we're a child, young adult or old adult. Hence our proteomes change over time and in response to the environment, telling us about who we are now and what the our future health might be. My proteome might mean for example, that at one time in my life a drug is effective, but not at another, due to the expression level of the protein that the drug targets changing with age. Understanding our proteomes would be really useful for many many things, and we're still only figuring out how to observe them, let alone understand them. The bit that made it extra inspiring was that she described some of the steps she and her lab was working on to take the science from the laboratory to the clinic, to actually make the knowledge useful. This is something that is rarely discussed in my current circles and always troubles me.

I'm not sure I ever trust my own self-justifications for why I do what I do. Am I lost in the sunk costs fallacy? Is it because I don't know what else to do, and it's inertia that stops me from changing? Or do I really think the potential future benefits win over the costs of dealing with the present obstacles? All I can say is that I don't think I'd be too gutted if I had to stop tomorrow and do something else. I'm sure there are other problem solving jobs in the world that I could do.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Science is much like making up space stories or cobbling together a magazine, then - a mix of perseverance, sheer bloody-mindedness, and blind luck. Beats cleaning toilets. Keep up the good work, Al. Coops

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Something of a mixed salad to end the year:

Looking back at my #63 post from the start of 2014 I can see that still neither objective 1 (B44 paper) or objective 3 (H2-Db paper) have been completed. Objective 1 is about to enter its third year.

My job situation is still unresolved - each month my contract has been extended by a further month since my funding ran out in the spring, at the expense of my bosses. This situation can't continue indefinitely and either the legal people will resolve their issues or it will be abandoned. The project is a good one and it would be a shame for it to unravel. Since I have very little control in this situation, I just have to hang on for now (or choose to leave).

On the upside, I feel that in late November I reached an endpoint to the research question I started with my PhD in 2008. Unfortunately, as it's all unpublished, I can't write about it. I've been experiencing this weird mix of satisfaction that comes with completion (after all this time) whilst totally frustrated that it remains unshared with the world. In the scheme of human knowledge and endeavour, it's tiny. A speck. But learning new and interesting things and then being able to share them is the WHOLE point. Not just a minor point, it is the point as far as I'm concerned. Sharing knowledge, experiences and learning from each other is the mechanism by which we make things better. And it's driving me slightly mad that this is so difficult in the system within which I work. Hopefully I'll be able to publish it in 2015, but if anyone ever asks me what is the most important skill one needs to develop in order to work in academia, I'd say it's the ability to tolerate/manage uncertainty. With a willingness to fail (in order to learn how to do better) as a close second.

Right, now that I've got my moaning out of the way, I'll return to the subject of people with more significant problems and my foray into effective giving. I had a slightly deeper look into micro finance projects, and what work has been done to assess the effectiveness of charities. I should point out here that one may have many reasons for choosing a charity e.g. a personal connection, and one immediately runs into the question of criteria - what is an effective charity? For the purposes of what I was trying to understand, I wanted to know which charities save most lives per pound donated in aiming to eliminate poverty and increase equality. But the organisations that have looked into this sort of thing have more extensive criteria.

Part of what has always troubled me about working somewhere that is partly funded by charity is that we're scientists, yet is the charity itself evidence based? It sucks up a lot of public money, but is this the best use of that money? Are all these glossy advertising campaigns good value? I can't answer those questions, but what I have been able to learn about is the organisations which seek to assess the quality of giving in a similar way to the Cochrane Collaboration does for health treatments.

Three related sites are: Oxford University's Centre for effective altruism and their related site Giving what we can , and in the USA Give Well. I'll leave it to readers to investigate these if they are of interest to you, but it led me to understand that the evidence for the benefits of micro credits was lacking at present, so I've decided not to pursue that avenue. I have recently donated a small sum to the Schistosomiasis Control Initiative run by Imperial College London. My other small donations this year have been ad-hoc ones to the DEC for their Syria, Ebola, Gaza and Philippines appeals. In total somewhere between 1 and 2% of my gross income (and before Gift Aid). Hopefully when my own financial/work situation is more resolved I'll come up with a more rational and proportional giving strategy based on the evidence (and my beliefs). I also keep saying I'll do some voluntary work, but that's another story...

Another thing I recently began is doing some on-line learning. I've been a statistics/coding/reproducible science hobbyist for a while now and some nice people at John Hopkins University have created a set of courses just for people like me. It's free (although you can pay if you want to be certified) and they run most courses each month. I can highly recommend it so far. See here for the Data Science pathway I'm doing and Coursera for all the courses (other sites are available).

In pizza news, I've refined my recipe from #68 to use 200g 00 flour, 100g of white bread flour and 5g of salt. That's a third less salt, but still quite a lot. I've also started making the dough 24 hours in advance. The results are not bad, better than shop bought pizza, but not as good as something done in a proper wood burning oven. They are still a bit doughy sometimes, which may be my bad technique rather than the method!

Finally, it's not been a great year culturally - either that or I've reached an age where I've seen it before and so it doesn't have the impact of first contact - so I'm struggling to think of anything I've seen, read or listened to that amazed me. What I have discovered recently is Hearts of Space, the ambient music station based in San Francisco. It's what you might expect - quite hippy - but I find it pretty good background for working or trying to get to sleep. You can try their on-line radio station for free, or get various subscriptions which you can stream to your phone, computer or whatever device you might have e.g. a Sonos system. If you need something relaxing to listen to at this time of year, then you might like to give it a go.

That's enough reflection for now. Time to do.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Been a little while since I read blog #69. I checked out the websites of the organisations that you suggested were worth checking. Particularly Give Well as they seem to be the barometer by which charities are measured. Curious things these charities: in all cases, in Give Well's own reports, their results are often unverifiable! I'd have thought that the one thing you would do as a charity would be a) to shout about the good you do. And b) at the very least, have the figures to back that up. Accusations about funds not reaching those they are intended for are more than rife since Band Aid first tried to do some good so I was very surprised that even Give Well's top charities are incredibly vague and inaccurate about their own figures. It seems there's nothing clear cut in the world of charity giving. Even with SCI, who win, for the 4th year running, GiveWell's top charity award, there are uncertainties about the efficacy of their methods. There are uncertainties about their results due to poor records or even missing results that are then made up to fill the gaps in their records. How did they win?! And how did they keep, their top award? And just how bad are the rest?!! I found myself doubting how wisely money was spent by one of the charities (I can't remember which one it was now) as I read about their annual 'Colloquium' to be held in one of Vienna's most 'exclusive' buildings, situated centrally right next to the Stadtpark. The get-your-tickets-now call was followed by lots of seemingly air-headed enthusiasm for the must-be-seen-at event. Surely some people are getting off on this for the wrong reasons. Somebody must be paying for this 'exclusive' building and the insinuation is that it's not cheap. Surely the money could be better used. Using GiveWell's site I thought I'd better check out the charities that I give to: MSF, WaterAid and Oxfam. As you know I don't agree with charity because I don't believe people should have to beg for what are essential needs. We pay our taxes and these should guarantee that nobody needs to beg. That should be a good enough argument for this country but there's also overseas aid. The rich nations continue to exploit the Southern Hemisphere and I don't see my taxes ending here: we should be supporting other people wherever needed and I'm glad to see Cameron has defended our Aid package to other countries and I hope that '1st world' countries will continue to help 'developing' nations but I want them to stop exploiting them too! But I'm soft and, like you, I felt the need to make a contribution despite this. I chose those charities because they seem to transcend political boundaries and provide much needed help without prejudice: life saving medicine should importantly be non-partisan; water is a basic need that should be guaranteed by by all of us for each other in the world; and Oxfam just seem to be always there, wherever they're needed. GiveWell don't include WaterAid as they don't meet GiveWell's strict criteria for recommendation. Oxfam are, in GiveWell's words, simply everywhere and too big and complicated to be comprehensively and meaningfully measured. MSF don't make GiveWell's top charities either but GiveWell gave them the accolade of recommending them, in the case of the Haiti earthquake (as well as in one other case, which I've lost track of), as the charity to give donations to rather than any of the other disaster charities as there was no more that the disaster charities could do. Thanks for coming back on this issue Al - I know your research is always impeccable! And very interesting, a well thought out approach; mine was ad hoc and relied on instinct rather than research. Sorry I took so long to comment but I was doing my research (using your organisations, ta) on the train, on my phone and only when I had enough energy. (Lucky no charity is depending on me!)

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
It's over ten years since I moved to Southampton and began writing this blog. I felt pretty old then and I feel ancient now. Back in December 2004, I estimated I had 2100 weeks to live so I must be down to 1580 weeks now. Have I used those last 520 weeks wisely? No, of course not! Does anyone? I'm as clueless now as I was then...

Anyhow, I've been putting off writing for about two months as I didn't want to just moan, but every time I sat down to write I find my thoughts dominated by negative thoughts and all the things that are getting on my nerves. Then today I realised I could just channel that and write about pizza...

One of the things I dislike about living in Southampton is the impossibility of getting (what I consider) good pizza. Pretty much every city I've ever visited other than Southampton has at least one place where one can get a decent pizza. (And let's not discuss the state of Southampton's coffee...Actually, I will digress into the world of coffee and say, buy a Chemex and never drink coffee anywhere other than home again. IMHO it makes as good as coffee as I've had, providing you can get decent coffee to use with it. Of course, there are other reasons for drinking coffee out and about, but for quality, the coffee produced by a Chemex will do for me.)

Back to the pizza. So short of opening a pizza place of my own (currently under discussion), I've been playing with Frying Pan Pizza the last couple of weeks. See here, here, here, and here for where I took my initial ideas.

The results of my latest attempt are in the pictures below, but if you fancy trying it yourself here's the recipe I used this time, it makes two pizzas:

Ingredients for the dough:

150g 00 flour (for example)

150g Waitrose Strong Canadian White Bread Flour (my preferred bread flour)

About 200g of cold water (doing things by weight is easiest for me!)

8g salt (more about this below)

4g Olive oil

2g of dried yeast (for example)

Ingredients for the ragu and topping:

230g tin of chopped tomatoes (for example)

1 teaspoon dried oregano

1 clove of garlic

150g Ball of mozzarella (for example)

Method:

  1. Mix all the dough ingredients in a bowl, and then knead on the side for a few minutes, adding extra flour or water if the dough is too dry or wet, until you have smooth, but not too sticky dough.
  2. Rest it for about 15 minutes (not sure if this is really necessary) and then divide it to two equal parts. I use the scales for that.
