At this point, the recommendation is to put the dough in the fridge for 24 hours. I've not tried this part yet and just covered the dough balls up and let them sit on the side for an hour.
  3. In the meantime, put the tomatoes in a colander and let some of the liquid drain off for 5 minutes. This seems like a waste, but does seem to stop you getting a soggy pizza.
  4. Put the garlic, oregano and tomatoes in a blender and whiz it up until you have smooth ragu.
  5. Drain the mozzarella, and use a kitchen towel to soak up any excess moisture, for the same reason as in 3. Then slice it as thinly as you can.
  6. Next, you need a metal frying pan like this one and some oven gloves:

  7. Put your grill on the highest setting and adjust the rack so you can get the frying pan nice and close to the heat.
  8. Now heat the pan on the hob as hot as you dare, and mind your smoke alarm.
  9. Whilst the pan is heating up and the grill is heating up, roll a dough ball out on the side to the right size and shape for your pan. You'll probably need a bit of flour for this to stop it sticking to the side.
  10. Put it in the hot pan - remember to put your oven gloves on.
  11. It's important to shake the pan whilst it's starting to cook, else it will stick, like my first effort did. It should start to bubble up and you can peek underneath and depending on your preference either burn it or stop when it's going brown. A few minutes.
  12. Turn off the hob and spoon over half the ragu, spread it thinly, leaving as much crust as you like. Then add the cheese.
  13. Now pop it under the grill - remember the oven gloves or you will be sorry - and cook it until it's done to your satisfaction. A few minutes again.

That's it, and now you can either make the other one, or save the dough, ragu and cheese until the next day. Here's the two that I made last night:



Comments:

So you can see on the left, the first one I went for a more burnt wood-fired style! It tasted better than the second one on the right, but unfortunately I stuck it to the pan as I forgot to keep shaking the pan when I first put it in, hence it's bit broken. The second one was more doughy, but still good. (I ate the doughy one last night, and the burnt one today).

My only really concern is that each pizza has 4g of salt in it (not including what's in the cheese) - which when you consider the daily recommended salt intake is 6g is a lot. I'm going to try halving the salt and seeing if the flavour is still ok, and that the dough texture is right. I didn't take photos of the internal structure, but this recipe gave a bubbly structure that I liked where it was thin enough, but too doughy where I'd left it thick. I may also try just using 00 flour and see if that gives a better texture.

The only other downside is that you can only do one pizza at a time, so if you are eating with someone or a group, it takes about 5-10 minutes between pizzas.

That said, it's by far the best pizza I've had in Southampton - but the bar is very low. And as anyone who's eaten pizza with me knows, I essentially only consider a Margarita to be pizza! Occasionally I might dabble with the four cheeses, but really the purity of the cheese and tomato combination is what I consider proper pizza. (My blog, my rules.)

I'll be interested to know if anyone tries this and has any more suggestions. I'll shall try this again soon, having made the dough the day before.

Postscript

Following your comment Phil, I've been looking more into the whole charity thing I wrote about previously, and it turns out that it's a bit unclear whether micro-finance schemes are effective, so I'm thinking about charities/schemes for which the evidence of effectiveness is strongest. I'll write more about that next time, along with some of the usual maudlin introspection for which I use this blog... :-)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I love all the asides that don't usually appear in cookbooks, such as, remember you're oven gloves or you will be sorry, and, mind your fire alarm. Funniest blog you've written so far. :-D More maudlin ones please! ;-) Looking forward to what you find out about the charity schemes.
dust your base with polenta my friend. no more sticky bottoms and protects it from scorching! Nasty:D

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
As was kindly pointed out to me earlier this year - a man has got to have a code, a creed to live by. :-)

And I've been awake since 4 am again, so I figured I'd write down my ruminations in a little self-help posting to myself.

I have a simple view of life as comprising of:

1. Problems that can be solved.

2. Problems that can't be solved, but have to be managed.

And finally:

3. Death. No more problems (Hurrah!).

To address point 1, the strategy I find that works best is to be well organised. Having a plan is pretty much the only way I know to get anything done. And a simple plan for me, starts with one of life's most fundamental questions:

What am I trying to achieve?

and must also address this question:

How will I know when I have achieved it?

There are many ways to do planning and be organised, whether it's analogue or electronic, and it is largely a matter of practice and review to get better at it. It's not an intrinsic ability, it's learnt.

I tend to fall back on the old SMART acronym (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Revisable, Time-based) as a sanity check of my plans and often apply my tried and tested, all-purpose algorithm in enacting them:

  1. Take a small step in what I think is the correct direction, or if in doubt, any direction.
  2. If the small step has made the situation worse, repeat step 1 in a different direction.
  3. If the small step has made the situation better, take another step in that direction.
  4. Repeat steps 1 to 3 until I reach my destination.

So that deals well with the solvable problems. Then there are the problems that can't be fixed and have to be managed. After much trial and error and general reading around the subject, my current strategy for managing those problems is based on the hypothesis that "feelings follow actions".

This is the hypothesis which explains why punching a bag generally makes people feel more angry rather than calmer. Which seems obvious when you think about it, but it took me a long time to figure that out.

People obviously have a wide variety of temperaments, as characterised by the Big 5 personality traits, but this perhaps is misleading as most people seem capable of experiencing the same wide dynamic range of emotions from misery to elation, whatever their baseline temperament. And if you accept that latter point, then combined with the "feelings follow actions" hypothesis, it gives me hope that I might be able to manage the problems that can't be solved.

For example, if I am furious about something that I cannot control at work and go for a run, or talk to someone else who distracts me with tales of their life, I will most likely through those actions feel a bit better. I have not solved the problem, but I have acted against my emotions and manipulated my feelings (in hopefully a positive way!)

One of the most difficult aspects of the "feelings follow actions" hypothesis is that the necessary actions are often the hardest ones to take, precisely because of ones feelings prior to acting against them, and there is almost a faith element required that acting will work. In running, we talk of stimulus control through practice - this is the process by which one learns to manage discomfort and performance anxiety etc. through routine and ritual, that has always struck me as analogous to religious practices. So when I read about the rising popularity of mindfulness it occurs to me that this an example of stimulus control following the "feelings follow actions" hypothesis. The point I'm making here is again about practice and learning, as my belief is that people are more similar than they are different, so I don't really accept it when people claim they can't do something. They are confusing can't with don't. Which is not to say I think learning anything is easy. It's not - or at least it's not for me. But it is possible to learn new things, and get better at something through repeated effort.

The slight contradiction for me is that I also believe that problems have to be discussed and acknowledged if there is any hope of coming up with a plan and working towards solutions. The trickiest part for me is being able to distinguish between category 1 and 2 problems, and therefore knowing which route to take. In fact, I know these are false divisions and often problems are a mixture of solvable and unsolvable, and untangling that is also often part of the process. This point has come at the end, when in a sense it should be at the start. The implication of the tangled nature of problems is that it is important to invest in problem definition at the start of the process. Where I usually go wrong is that I set out to solve one problem and discover that the thing I'm working on is not the actual problem that needs addressing (which is one reason for my little algorithm). The other trap I usually fall into (and another reason for my algorithm) is that of repeating a failed strategy and expecting it to work. Punching that bag and still feeling angry? I wonder why? Is that wall going to break? Or will it be my head?

Writing this is a thought ordering process, which while it hasn't helped me get anymore sleep, has demonstrated to me that it's all heuristics in the end. Right answers are for mathematicians and suckers. The rest of us are just muddling through, however neatly I can write my code, and so I finish by reminding myself of another favourite question of mine: How wrong can I be and still have a useful answer?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Heard of this guy, Prof. Steve Peters: The Chimp Paradox: The Mind Management Programme to Help You Achieve Success, Confidence and Happiness He's got some interesting ideas, which evidently worked for British Cycling but not for the England Football team!
An inspiring read. Thank you

Hey Steve. Yes, I heard him interviewed a while back. It raised a couple of questions in my mind: one was whether sports people are more prone to strange beliefs than the average person? I wondered this because of the unlikelihood of ever achieving success at the top of a sporting profession, and therefore the belief system required to keep trying against almost impossible odds. The second question it raised in my mind was whether sports people would benefit from his help more than the average person due to the work ethic that any professional sports person would have? I guess someone may have looked into those question already, and it does sound a bit like Behavioural Activation minus the jargon!

Hey Jen. Glad you enjoyed it - a bit more of a ramble than usual that one. Looking at the date I wrote it, it was another 24 hours before I cracked the problem that was driving me crazy on this particular occasion. Which despite my neurotic outpouring, was actually a maths problem that I'd been trying to solve every day for a week, rather anything else, and all came down to a typo that I just couldn't see. It's hard to describe the sense of relief at having solved what was in fact quite a trivial problem after such a long period of frustration! Bizarrely, I still woke up again at 4am for the next two nights. I'm putting that down to not being able to finish a paper we started writing back in 2012 due to my interpersonal working relationship difficulties. That's definitely a problem that has to be managed, rather than solved. Ho-hum. Anyhow, I'd be interested to hear what you are up to these days if you fancy dropping me a line.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Nearly July already and still no contract...but before I go there, here's an aside:

Being as I am I got myself a subscription to Significance Magazine this year, and the first edition I received was all about poverty and development. My favourite statistic was contained in this article that you can download as a pdf and read for free: Is aid a waste of money? It makes this point:

"If you add up all the aid that all OECD
countries have given since they started
counting it in 1960, and then assume that
the only thing that this aid has achieved
was the eradication of smallpox, then the
whole thing would still be a bargain, costing
less than half what the UK National
Health Service spends on average to save
a life."

I think that's pretty striking, and along with a couple of other conversations about charity that I'd had recently, it got me thinking I should probably give a bit more of my income away. And following the principle of public declaration making it more likely I will act, and on the off chance it encourages anyone else to do likewise, the decision I've come to is to make a monthly donation and lend a further amount equal to my annual donation. A combined total of about 2% of my net income.

I looked into the charities that are allied to the DEC and I decided that I like the look of Care International in what they do and that they offer both the choice of a monthly subscription and/or a Microfinance Scheme in which you can directly loan someone money in a developing country.

Anyhow, there are plenty of other ways to give and charities to give to, both here and abroad, and I'm obviously not going to make much of a dent in solving global inequality! But I'm reasonably convinced that inequality is an important factor in most problems facing humanity, and what's that line Tesco's use?

I had the opportunity to hear Françoise Barré-Sinoussi speak last week (you can read her fascinating story here) and to me she exemplified the scientist as citizen. By this I mean she was not only concerned with finding things out, but is equally concerned with the wider impact. In the context of her work, this means not only discovering HIV, but fighting for the rights of people living with HIV around the world, including getting access to medicines to help them manage the infection and eliminating stigma. Her talk was as much sociology as biology, and the other thing that I really liked was her use of "we" rather than "me" or "I". The cult of the genius is a real problem for science, and while there are occasional geniuses, most of science is just like anything else, the result of the collective efforts of many ordinary people. I mean, she did strike me as fairly extraordinary, but at the same time she left me feeling that everyone could make a meaningful difference with just a little bit of effort, whether in science or any other walk of life. Which was pretty inspiring.

Telling my story backwards, I was lucky enough to be funded by my boss to be in the USA the week before that at the 8th International Workshop on Antigen Processing and Presentation in Philadelphia. For those of you that don't speak jargon, that's my little niche of science. It was the first time I'd been out of Europe since 2001, and my first international conference. To give you a sense of the size of the niche, there were 142 attendees, representing a good proportion of the overall global community. For me anyway it was a really interesting meeting. I felt like I learnt more about my field in 24 hours than I had in the last 2 years.  And I got to put faces to many of the people who's work I'd read, and made some new connections in my little world. I got to spend a few days in New York on the way, and there's a picture of the Hudson River round the corner from where I was staying at the top.

Before that I was at the Cheltenham Science Festival doing a bit of public engagement for Cancer Research UK, who fund our lab. It was kinda fun, but exhausting.

And a week before that I went to Cambridge and gave my first external talk to the group I'm a member of in the British Society of Immunolgy. In fact, I gave two talks. Just like buses, nothing for five years and then...

So, although actually doing the science is incredibly challenging, I've had plenty of reasons to reflect that as I enter my tenth year in Southampton, I'm leading a very privileged existence these days. There is a fair degree of cognitive dissonance, as pretty much everyone I know who works at the University seems to feel incredibly stressed, undervalued and demoralised. Even within my own team, I often find myself in the bizarre position of being Pollyanna. Which you may find hard to imagine! Certainly, I've had plenty of moments since Christmas when I've thought, "I hope it all unravels and I'm forced to do something else." It's a funny business I'm in, and it can be hard to keep going.

To return to the beginning, I still don't have a contract and every few weeks since my Fellowship money ran out in April I have to ask my boss for some more. Currently, I have money until the end of August, by which time I'd really hope I know one way or another if the new project is going ahead.

In the meantime, the struggle to get the science published that we completed in 2012 goes on...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Al! 2 things: I'm very surprised that you want to give away your income when you don't have a contract. I agree her talk sounds very inspiring but make sure you've got it before you give it. And second, I'm surprised that loans are a good idea. Loans have to be repaid. Surely that's compounding the problem. I give. I don't want my aid repaid. On the other hand the acronym for the International Worshop on Antigen Processing and Presentation is I-WAPP. Pretty good for something fighting cancer!! (That's 3 things. I know, I can't count, just as well I'm not a scientist.)
PS (4th thing! Crap, eh?) Great picture!

Thanks Phil. Well, I'm cautiously optimistic that I'll have a job soon, and even so I can afford to give a little. I've always been a bit wary of charity generally, on the basis that it facilitates us not doing things through governments and more accountable means. That said, I live in this world and not the one I wish I did, and this is one way to make a direct impact, albeit small. And actually, that's why I was struck by the statistic, government foreign aid, NGO's and charities really do add up to a large meaningful impact DESPITE all the problems associated with foreign aid. As for micro-finance, yes there are problems with it too, Wikipedia has a good article: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microfinance . However, another downside of charity is that it is patronizing. Many people would like to help themselves if they had access to the resources to do so, such as a reasonable source of credit - one major criticism of micro-finance is that they lack a decent place to save money too. I'd hope that the scheme administered by Care International: http://www.careinternational.org.uk/what-we-do/microfinance goes some way to addressing the credit problem that arises because banks won't lend small amounts to high risk individuals. If the person who I lend to defaults, it is in effect charity, and if they pay me back, then I can re-loan the money to someone else. Creating safe and reliable sources of credit is itself addressing one source of inequality.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0089657

Above is the link to my first publication, a significant landmark for me. It's open access, so anyone can read it and download all the material, although it is really only of interest to a specialist audience.

It complements the work by my colleague Andy, which you can only access via subscription via the following link, but I'm including it for completeness: http://www.jbc.org/content/288/45/32797.short

To provide some context, if you do take a peek, this work is examining molecules of the Chicken immune system. This obviously sounds a bit odd when you consider I'm part of a group predominantly funded by Cancer Research UK (you can see my boss Tim if you watch the video following the link, and my hands!).

However there a several reasons why we would choose to study this, some of which I go into in the paper.

Firstly, and not directly relevant to my work, there are good commercial reasons for researching the chicken immune system. I don't eat meat, but many people do, and I do eat eggs along with many other people, so protecting this important food source means understanding how to keep chickens healthy, and that means understanding their immune system. Secondly, and also not directly relevant to this work, chickens (and their close relatives) are a possible vector of human disease - you've heard of bird flu, right?

More relevant to what I do is the fact that chickens diverged in evolutionary history from humans a long time ago. This has led to chickens having smaller, simpler much more compact group of genes that have the same function as a much larger, more complicated set of genes in mammals (including us.) When you are trying to untangle a problem as complicated as how cancers go unseen by the immune system, it's helpful to have a simpler system to work with. Any information we can glean from the simpler system may inform us about the the more complicated one.

Hence the usefulness of studying Chickens.

In Biology the simple Francis Crick dogma is DNA makes RNA makes proteins which have function i.e. Genes are a code and their information is transcribed into another intermediate code, which is then translated into stuff, proteins. From proteins, bones, brains and muscles are made and information passed around, such as whether a cell has cancer. It's a lot more complicated than that, but that's the gist.

The complexity of Biology does mean that subtle differences can have big consequences, a good example is sickle cell anaemia. A mutation in the gene for the hemoglobin protein leads to swapping one "residue" in the protein, amounting to just a few atoms, and causes the hemoglobin proteins forming red blood cells to become stiff, such that they clog blood vessels or easily rupture leading to various health problems.

In my work I was trying to understand the functional effects of subtle differences in two versions of a protein which informs the immune system as to the health status of chicken cells.

The hypothesis under examination is that proteins are plastic like playdough - and that relative differences in plasticity between proteins are of functional relevance. The testable prediction arising from the findings in my paper is that I've identified parts of the protein that could be mutated experimentally to see if we can alter plasticity and function in a directed fashion. (Back to you Andy).

I've put a picture here showing how one of these proteins might move. This is a porcupine plot and the size and colour of the spikes represent the direction and magnitude of the motion of each atom illustrated.

Bringing this back to cancer (and other diseases), if protein plasticity is relevant for function in the same way in humans, then we might think about how to modulate protein plasticity. How? I'm not sure we know, but we can learn from situations where drugs cause problems and examine if this is down to their binding to these proteins, modulating plasticity and thus function, in a negative fashion. This is something we might then reverse engineer to our advantage by designing molecules that would modulate the plasticity of these proteins and alter their function to make cancers more visible.

The proteins under examination are highly variable, so your particular proteins might have different plasticity to mine, for example. Hence a generalised and protein specific understanding of this process is the holy grail for exploring this possible route to using our own immune systems to manage cancer. And it might be a dead end. In fact I'd say it's probably a dead end, as most ideas in Science are. But pessimistic as that sounds, it's actually how we make progress, by ruling things out, so that's what left is the solid, reliable stuff, and so that fancy new drug the doctor offers doesn't kill you when you take it.

To be ruled out, it needs to be tested, and for that it needs to be in the public domain, so that others can see it, test the ideas and report back whether they're worthwhile, need revising or simply abandoning. And that's why I'm so glad it's published, cos it does no-one any good sitting on my hard drive unchallenged.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Congratulations on your first paper. Seeing your name in print like that is awesome. Well done.
Congratulations indeed! Not just your hands, your whole head, out of focus, is in one shot of the video!

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Click on the map above and the obligatory pictures of me looking silly if you want to see them bigger.


In the 2014 Meon Valley Plod I was 58th of 266 participant in a time of 3:26:37. It was a bit of surprise as I'd got up that morning expecting conditions to be as bad, if not worse than last year. It was pretty chilly in the wind at the start, but as you can see in the photo of me going up the first big hill at mile 3, I'd taken my hat and gloves off pretty early on.

And long before I got to Butser Hill at mile 17, I was actually hot and took my jacket off. The second photo of me is on the approach to summit of Buster and the other small photo is the view looking down from Butser over the landscape approaching it. As it shows, it was actually quite a nice day.

What was really confusing was the lack of mud, given the weather of the last few months. It obviously runs off the Downs and floods everywhere else. I did get caught out again at about mile 14 where what looked like a puddle turned out to be over my knee and freezing cold. There were a few more of those before Butser too.

I was about 15 minutes faster than last year, which I put down to the conditions as much as anything. I don't really remember a great deal of the run, it was one of those runs where I just got into a trance and ran and ran until mile 19 where I caught up with a guy called Rajiv from the Guildford and Godalming club with whom I chatted the last couple of miles. My favourite things about this year were that there were two fields of llamas (or alpacas, not sure which) and a greyhound that did the whole race too in 5 hours 12 minutes.

So not a terribly exciting race to report on this time around. But it is still a fairly challenging event, even in good conditions, if you like running. And at £16 entry, value for money.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: good running, very impressed with the map on this post too :)

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
I submitted my report for my MRC Fellowship today, which officially ended on January 14th, but because I'd been frugal with my funds I had enough money leftover to extend my contract until April 22nd 2014.

Here's the compact version:

Aim 1: Continue development of research into MHC Class I antigen processing:

  • Objective 1 is on-going (Publish B44 paper)
  • Objective 2 is complete (Publish BF2 paper)
  • Objective 3 is on-going (Publish H2-Db paper)

Aim 2: Establish a new industrial and interdisciplinary collaboration:

  • New industrial collaborators have agreed in principle to fund a new 3 year project with me as post-doctoral researcher, but the contracts remain to be agreed and signed. Next meeting to discuss this project in early February 2014.

The three papers for Aim 1 and the new project I'm still stuck in negotiations over for Aim 2 are those I referred to last time. On the whole it's good news, but it is a good thing I'd kept some money back to pay myself some wages for a few extra months otherwise I'd be out of a job at the moment.

The best thing that has happened is that I got my first publication (Objective 2) accepted yesterday by PLoS One. It'll be published in late February and as it's an open access journal, anyone who cares to have look, is welcome to. Not that it'll mean much to anyone without a specialist interest. There is a certain irony that this paper is something I started after I had submitted my PhD dissertation and the work actually contained in my thesis dissertation remains unpublished. But I did use many of the methods and protocols that I had developed in the previous four years.

As someone who is not a trained biologist or computer scientist and general sufferer of Imposter Syndrome, the following feedback from one of the anonymous reviewers was a particular relief, "This is a solid piece of work..."

It's a bit of a landmark moment for me, if somewhat bittersweet due to the massive friction created with one of my colleagues during the production of the work. The test now will be whether other researchers read and use my findings in their own work, and most importantly discover whether the findings can be replicated or refuted. But it's out there, even if it immediately disappears into obscurity. So I'll take the opportunity to be a big myself up and say that becoming a published scientist was not something I'd ever imagined or aspired to when I was younger or when I quit TV, so however small an achievement it is in the scheme of things, it feels real, and that I've actually made a small contribution to the sum total of human knowledge. Which is probably as close to immortality as I can expect!

I'm still not sure academia is for me in the long term, for reasons I also detailed last time, but it's nice to have a bit of success.

At the top is a picture of a 3D printed model of one of the molecules that appears in the paper. I had it printed for the BSI Congress that I went to before Christmas and it turned out to be a real crowd pleaser - I've since produced models for academics in Oxford and Cambridge who wanted their molecules printed too. I may have to change my profession again...

In other news, I read 2312 by Kim Stanley Robinson over Christmas, and I've since been forcing it on other people. It's a long book, without much plot, but it is probably my favourite read of the last 12 months. It's a book of enormous breadth: themes of love, the consequences of human behaviour on the environment, the scientist as citizen, the transcendent power of art, the consequences of longevity and prosperity on human form and behaviour, to name a few. But what I particularly like about his work is how human everyone is and how humanely he considers even the bad guys. That and the surprising nature of love reminded me of one of my favourite books, The Dispossessed by Ursula Le Guin. 2312 is not a perfect book, some bits drag or seem a bit ridiculous, but if you need an uplifting read, give it a go.

And if you need an antidote for that, check out the Sandman Slim series by Richard Kadrey.

It's just over a week to year's Meon Valley Plod - Yes I'm doing it again. It's going to be muddy. I'll post a race report after that, but here's the links to last years reports here and here if you need reminding and wish to join me next time.

Maybe I'll be a bit closer to securing a job by then...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: '<i>...solid piece of work.<i>' Of course! Brilliant news! (Glad to see you were aiming for immortality! ;-) 'Fraid I dropped out of your invite for the mud run ;-)
<i>... and I can't remember how to turn off the italics!<i>

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
A bit of a diary update as I head towards the end of the year.

So there is the map and then there is the territory, the plan and what actually happens. These things have been very divergent.

The plan for life after submitting my PhD thesis dissertation back in December 2012 was pretty ambitious and as described last time in #61, much of the original plan has failed and had to be abandoned. As I mostly still self-identify as an engineer, I've resorted to a combination of back-up plans and on-the-spot problem solving following the tried and tested methods that I've learnt over the years to deal with the set-backs. It's a tough being Pollyanna when I can't seem to catch a break and feel trapped by circumstances beyond my control, and when there is such a high degree of uncertainty in my life, but the alternative is to just give up and I'm not there yet. One counter-measure is to switch on the news and realise I'm probably suffering from the focusing illusion much of the time.

The aims for 2013 were to publish three papers based on work from my PhD, two of which I would be the lead author on. This would facilitate another aim, securing funding to remain working in academia.

At the time of writing none of the three papers have been published. The most important one has now been rejected three times. The second one is out for review, but has caused a great deal of trouble along the way. The third one is yet to be finished and submitted. The knock-on effect was that I've not been able to apply for any funding from a research council, as publications are a important part of their criteria for awarding funding.

Some of the difficulties arise from the age old problem of working in teams and teams where different members have different priorities and are driven by different incentives. Or to put it simply, those with permanent contracts and established positions aren't quite as concerned about losing their job as I am and therefore aren't in such a hurry to get the work done.

However, I'm not one to sit around and watch the big boulder heading down the road to crush me, so I did think about worst case scenarios and my colleagues priorities back in January, and have been working with the things I can control to find a solution. This really amounts to keeping on trying, to being open to new opportunities and alternative outcomes, and to keeping on talking to different people. So much of life is about luck, good and bad, it's easy to delude myself that when things go well it's something I've done just as much as when things go bad. However, if I can place enough bets and be smart enough to recognise a win when I see one, then hopefully success will arrive before I run out of time and money. I think the recognising it part (not fixing my expectations) and the willingness to engage with lots of different people that are the hardest bits for me. It's exhausting for one, and requires overcoming the great temptation to withdraw and adopt some fatalistic stance that amounts to just not bothering.

So although I'm presently 7 weeks away from unemployment with no academic CV to speak of, I have one big bet still in play. That's the collaboration with industry that I initiated back in the summer arising from a chance conversation. This is work (mentioned in #61) is aimed at developing ways test whether a chemical is going to cause an allergic response without using animal testing. It's really nice because not only does it address both the problem of what causes allergies and reducing animal testing, but the information should also be useful for the kind of cancer research I've been involved with. I should know if that's going to happen by Christmas and I'm hopeful that if it goes ahead I'll find life in 2014 much more bearable. I recently spoke to a couple of other academics outside of my current circle and there are a couple of other opportunities with them I could also follow up on if this one doesn't come off.

That said, the last two years of academia has been such a death march that I've made a decision that even if the new project goes ahead, if I'm still feeling the way I do now by the summer of 2014, then it's time to do something else. I'm not a masochist and as I've said before, process is at least as important to me as the goals. This current process of dealing with a high degree of uncertainty in an environment where I don't feel supported to the degree I feel I should be, is not worth the effort. People don't do science for the money, so if it's not fun they go and do something that either is fun or pays well. Or at the very least, is less demoralising. Simple as.

The sad thing is, and I know this is not uncommon as other colleagues have said similar things to me, I don't feel proud of my PhD or the work we're attempting to publish. It's feels like something I survived as if it were a war or natural disaster. Which is not to trash the whole thing and say it wasn't worth doing and that this research is pointless, but it does often give me pause to reflect on whether the costs outweigh the benefits. Compared to other jobs I've had, I have more day to day freedom than any other job and occasionally it does feel like it has purpose. But a lot of the time it feels like a game of egos and sleight of hand just to continue playing the game, and the whole aim of discovering knowledge has been lost to the goals of obtaining funding and prestige. We could and should have done more, and done it better in the time I had and with the resources that were available.

Putting all that to one side and in an attempt to develop my gratitude attitude, here's a short list of things I am thankful about from 2013:

  • It's been a great year for running. We've done quite a few amazing runs on the South Downs in all four seasons and weather conditions, ranging from 8 miles to 24 miles. It's beautiful countryside at all times of year. The Meon Valley Plod was pretty special too. Nature put me in my place that day. And as long as it doesn't clash with my Uncle's 70th, I intend to do it again in 2014. We've also run in Yorkshire, Manchester and Amsterdam. Plus a few Park Runs.

  • I managed to fit in more time off this year. Particular memories are walking the North coast of Cornwall to St. Ives in April. Gin and tonic and BBQs on the beach in Brighton throughout the summer. Midsummer in Harrogate. Cycling in the New Forest and on the Isle of Wight in August and September. Meeting friends and relatives in Manchester in February and October. (I like Manchester a lot, if it wasn't for their weather and being so far from the sea, I'd like to live there.)

  • I've read a load of great books. They're listed over in the side bar.

  • I went to see some live music for the first time in years. I'd forgotten how magical that can be.

  • And cheesey though it is, it probably bears saying that I'm grateful for all the support of my friends, colleagues and loved ones throughout the year. You know who you are. And whether I've physically seen you every day, less often or not at all, it's all those small acts of kindness and words of support that keep me going.

I'm off to Liverpool next week for my first proper academic conference, the meeting of the British Society for Immunology. Somehow it seems to have taken me 5 years to get around to attending one. I'm a little trepidatious as I'm not a great traveller, and it's not the most glamorous location, but it's a really good line up of scientists from my field and an opportunity to meet them and hear about their work (and tell them about mine). Another chance to roll the dice. If you happen to be in Liverpool, drop by and see my poster :-)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That is also a frighteningly accurate description of my workplace experience... Whatever you do, don't consider a career in the NHS!

Hi Al, That's all some pretty heavy food for thought. A great shame that none of it worked out as I would have expected or, as your account states, it should have. Working in a university, as I am as a technician, I'd have said that although things move slowly they generally work out in the end to the benefit of all but things here are (slowly) changing for the worse and it's depressing to hear the same is happening to you. You seem to have been hard done by. That you're thinking of changing is a great shame as university research is the perfect place for you. They need to treat you better and realise they should value you more rather than letting you go. However, Elina is right, even the most ideal, altruistic employment is ruined when office politics and petty empire building get in the way (taking the place of the profit motive in business) and coping with overblown egos is as much of a problem as anywhere else. Hope your aims work out and I hope you made some useful contacts in Liverpool. You have a lot to offer Al, don't ever forget that.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
I've given up waiting for the right moment to post an update. I wanted to wait until certain things had been resolved, but things have continued in the messy fashion I described last time. I've been reading about Zombies and I feel like I inhabit a world of (trivial) Zombie problems that every time I think I've killed them off, they rise up again...

And I apologise if I've neglected to answer anyone's emails in recent months. I've not been keeping up with them very well.

So my main news is that I passed my viva in May and hence have more or less completed my PhD. I say more or less as I have some minor corrections to my thesis dissertation which I hope to have done by the end of this week and with luck, it'll get signed off and I can print it and I'll be truly finished being a student by the end of July.

To cut a long story long, I should have had my viva in March, but my examiner was ill and it got delayed until May. In the event it was a largely undramatic affair. More like a friendly interrogation for two hours and then I walked to the supermarket. No-one can say I don't know how to celebrate four and half years of hard work ;-)

I might attempt a post to explain my thesis more at some point, if anyone suffers from insomnia, but not tonight. See post #56 for an overview.

The real outstanding issue is getting my work published. This is important for two reasons:

  • One, I won't feel like I've really done any science worth it's name until it has passed the scrutiny of external peer review.
  • Secondly, I'm unable to apply for further funding from any research councils without having published my work and hence I could be unemployed in January 2014 when my current funding ends.

It took five months to prepare our first submission and we were rejected from Nature within a week. No surprise there, but my boss wanted aim high. It was a similar story with Science last week. So I am now about to begin writing iteration three of the Zombie paper. A colleague from Cambridge took two years and 10 journal attempts to get published, and Emma in my lab is on journal 5 and 18 months in her attempt, so it's early days for me.

This has become slightly less worrying - in science the money often runs out before the success arrives - after one of those chance conversations that has led to an opportunity to meet with some people from industry in a few weeks who might fund me directly for three years.

As you may or may not know, the EU have banned all animal testing on cosmetics which means that anyone developing cosmetics needs to find ways to ensure they are safe to use that doesn't involve animals. The problem is how to prevent allergic reactions, and allergic reactions are due to our immune systems, and my current work is about another part of our immune system that parallels the part that can cause allergic responses to things like shower gels, and my methods don't involve animals.

So this becomes interesting to me for three reasons:

  • One I might be able to obtain funding directly for three years without the pressure of having to publish first. I won't be particularly well paid, but a job is a job and they are getting harder to come by. And hopefully this is the right kind of job for me.
  • Two, it's the chance to apply the knowledge and modelling techniques I've been part of developing to a different yet similar system to see if it works. I'll be able to continue working with my team, albeit on my own new project most of the time.
  • Thirdly, it's a more tangible problem than 'this might be useful for cancer', that has been my PhD. It offers the possibility of yielding information relevant to many health problems beyond allergic responses shower gels and perfumes, such as reducing side effects in medicines as discussed in post #56. It also might help in the development of techniques to reduce animal use more generally.

For industry, it's a relatively cheap way to investigate a possible avenue of innovation and the University retains the intellectual property rights, so whatever I might turn up remains in the public domain.

So I'm mildly optimistic that it will work out, but won't be surprised if I end up posting how it all came to nothing in a few weeks time.

Plan B is to continue investigating the possibility of becoming a primary school teacher.

Fun fact: In 2009 the Times Educational Supplement stated that there are 17,000 primary schools with 193,000 teachers in England. In 2010 the Royal Society reported that only 5,989 (3%) had a background in science and 3,903 had a degree in Maths.

I'm a breathing example of how a person can learn new things that aren't in their background, but surely can't be a good thing to have so few teachers with a background in science amongst the entire population? Hence it's a problem I could potentially contribute to resolving by becoming a teacher myself. I don't know enough about it to know whether I want to do it, but I'm looking into it.

I've managed three short holidays this year, as well as lots of walking on the South Downs. A weekend in Cornwall, a week in Yorkshire and a weekend in Amsterdam. All lovely places I'd not been to before. I stuck a picture from our walk in Nidderdale in Yorkshire at the top.

I've read a bunch of books in the past few months, which you can see in the side bar. All good fun, nothing too heavy if you like Zombies or Space Opera.The Rapture of the Nerds is a truly mind bending take on Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy.

That'll do for now. Looking at what I wrote last time as compared with this time I'm obviously feeling a bit calmer and a bit more certain. Or at least my sense of absurdity is better intact.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
When I wrote my weblog at Christmas it was with the sense and expectation that things were concluding and changing such that when I next wrote it would be to describe how things resolved themselves and my plans for what happens next. In the actuality, things have been messy, drawn out and often inconclusive thus far.

The year started with my new work contract and PhD thesis submission and house sale all being problematic. These have been resolved and replaced by viva examination delays, paper submission delays, interpersonal communication issues with one of my colleagues, holiday cancellations and grant writing delays.

So I guess this is a post about how that makes me feel and how I'm dealing with it...

I've just finished reading the second Dagmar Shaw novel by Walter Jon Williams. Early on in the book he describes, "a low twelve volt anxiety now hummed in Dagmar's nerves, sixteen cycles per second of uncertainty and unease."

Now, my life is thankfully not that dramatic and individually each problem in my life is quite trivial. But the idea of an oscillating sense of uncertainty and unease resonated with me as a description of my present experience of modern life and dealing with multiple small problems. For every thing that becomes certain another source of uncertainty manifests and often the certainties are themselves sources of anxiety. Relaxation is almost impossible and yet paradoxically absolutely crucial to successful problem solving.

I wrote last time about the importance of the illusion of control and focusing on process (rather than the target) as coping mechanisms for me. So it was nice to have my prejudices reinforced when I went to the Brighton Science Festival a couple of weeks after I wrote that. I discovered from one of the talks I went to that what I call 'illusion of control' is essentially what the psychologists call 'internal locus of control'. The sense in which one internally feels that one can effect changes and control your destiny, rather than ones life being shaped by external forces beyond your control. Secondly, I learnt that indeed focusing on the process is considered a more effective strategy for visualisation i.e. if you want to get a degree, visualise studying and attending lectures not standing on a stage receiving a piece of paper at the end. (In fact the suggestion is that the latter is more likely to be detrimental to actually succeeding.) Attending to process is also part of being mindful as a coping mechanism, as the Buddhists would have it.

That said, as I've also said before, I'm someone who needs to have clearly defined goals and endpoints. Things that drag on indefinitely with no clear denouement are horrible for me.

And yet life in reality, as now, is often chaotic and without clarity (except for the obvious endpoint for everyone) :-)

In dealing with these feelings of unease and uncertainty, I guess that's why I make and refine my list of heuristics, to condense all the experiences and lessons learnt (and biases and prejudices) into a handy guide I can refer to for finding my way.

I confess I also I do a lot of self-talk. I'm not even sure when the internal dialogue started, but it has a life of it's own now. Whenever I catch myself doing something I disapprove of e.g. being narcissistic or self-pitying or judgemental and bigoted or not letting things go or procrastinating; there is usually a internal discussion about my sense of perspective, my motivations and the relationship of my cognition to my emotions that frequently ends up with things being said out-loud. It's what I call 'having a word with myself'. Usually it's positive, if a bit heated. I'm not someone who believes in blame and punishments as useful strategies. But I'll end up doing it on a bus one day and it'll look like I'm having a full psychotic episode. My current internal refrain is: How do I get from here to there?

And obviously (as well as what I've written in previous posts) another way I deal with it is to write it down. Writing helps me as a sorting process. Even when it's inconclusive like this. It's another lesson I've learnt: I don't always need a solution, sometimes I just need an outlet for what I'm feeling and thinking.The solution will present itself eventually and even if it doesn't it may not matter. Maybe what I thought was the problem wasn't really the problem after all. What matters is dealing constructively with the emotions that might be an obstacle to getting from here to there.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I can vouch for focusing on the process: I was once told that if I carried on as I was, I could get a First. From then on I wanted that First. I blew it. I should have carried on focussing on what interested me. It's still easy to get lost. But for yourself it's a much more honest pursuit. (On another matter: Really enjoyed our evening together last Saturday.)
PS Addendum to no. 19 on your Heuristics list: 'A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.' (Lao-tsu http://www.quotationspage.com/quote/24004.html) I thought it was Chairman Mao!

It's helpful to be reminded about focusing on the process & plus evidence/personal examples of where it has been effective. It certainly links with the practice of mindfulness which seems popular. It is also relevant to some sport - keep one's eye on the ball (rather than where you are aiming) - something like that. Hopefully the viva date has been set - best wishes.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
This is a postscript to my previous post and in response to correspondence I've received about running in general and specifically doing something as idiotic as running 21 miles in the freezing cold and wet:

Firstly I'm someone who believes that the only meaning in life is that which we choose to ascribe it. So running appeals to my sense of the absurdity. I can honestly say while I was in some discomfort during the Meon Valley Plod and there was a short period of actual pain, I was never sad or miserable. In fact I was laughing and smiling quite a lot, precisely because it's something I'd chosen to do and the absurd nature of running as an activity. It's a completely unnecessary thing to do in theses days of bicycles, cars and trains etc. Furthermore, running is a tangible connection to my physical self. I experience it directly, which is stark contrast to rest of my life which is an almost entirely intangible world of thoughts and ideas.

Secondly, running can be many things to me. On my own it's often meditative and my thoughts wander, order themselves and I relax and get perspective of my own tiny place in the Universe. Actions create feelings.I often used to visualise I was dropping my troubles like litter as I ran along.

Running with other people is a social thing and a chance to have a conversation without any intrusion. The phrase I read yesterday to describe the consequences of mobile communications devices - fatally connected. It's nice to be only connected to one or two people once in a while.

Or it can be with training with the club or a race or an event such the Meon Valley Plod and one gets the sense of well being that always comes from being part of an in-group.

Thirdly there is the illusion of control. We have so little control over the world we inhabit, yet for me anyway I need some veneer of control over the chaos to be able to cope. Putting one foot in front of another is very much something I can choose to do and create that necessary illusion. Even when everything else has gone to hell.

I don't think any of this is exclusive to running or that there is anything special about running. It's just what works for me. It could just as easily be making Art, part of having a family or something else. Different strokes and all that.

For me it's as much about the process as completion. I do relatively few events (or races if you prefer) compared to most of my club colleagues. There are occasions when I want to see how well I can do and I will take it seriously to train for that, but ultimately if I wasn't into the process of the training I wouldn't bother with the race. It's the same way I feel about Science or anything else, the journey is as important as the destination. I get equal satisfaction from completing something as I do from doing something well. Completion provides the quantitative sense of satisfaction and doing something well provides the qualitative reward. A bad run for me is one where I ran stressed and angry, which is fortunately rare.

I should also point out that I only went waist deep on one side. The bit where is was like a lake was mostly only knee deep, but it was impossible to tell looking at it where it was deep and where it was shallow. And the guy behind me did stop and check I was ok.

So I might do it again or I might not. I'm easily bored and like to try new things.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Tenacity comes to mind amongst other words. I just cannot imagine tolerating the discomfort of running in wet & muddy shoes.So well done many times over for having finished.
I'll scratch ordering the armchair + Wii for your birthday then. ;-)

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
In what was officially the worst conditions since 1997 I ran my second Meon Valley Plod on Sunday. The map here is the old route. I’ve not been able to find a copy of the current one, but they’re pretty similar.

I’d kitted myself out with three base layers overlaid with a waterproof jacket with a hood on top. Leggings, glove, hat and off-road shoes. As we huddled in the Scout Hut with the 300 or so other runners, Kevin and Owen asked me if I was going to be too hot. I can safely say that overheating wasn’t a problem.

The race starts and finishes on the road, with a couple of miles of road during the course, but other than that it’s entirely tracks and fields. Within five minutes of running we were in ankle deep mud and that was just the start. Waterproof shoes were completely redundant and it was as much effort pulling my feet out of the mud and water and finding stable footing as going up and down the hills. My ankles, calves and knees are stiff today.

As my core was warm I was coping with the cold and wet ok for the first half of the race and I’d learnt from last year by going off easy and eating something every 20 minutes. Who’d have thought wet cake could taste so good? By the time we got near East Meon we were running through the equivalent of a World War I trench, the mud was knee deep and my biggest worry was getting skittled over by people going face down in the mud all around me.

So we had two types of conditions to deal with: Up on the ridge the rain was horizontal, stinging and the wind biting cold, but it was a bit less muddy. In the woods there was no cold wind and a bit less rain, but the deep puddles and ditches were full of mud and freezing water. At one point it was like running down a waterfall.

But as I say, I was just about coping with the cold, although I didn’t have much feeling in my feet. Until around mile 14. I got to this bit in the woods where all I could see in front of me was a lake of water stretching for about 300 metres where the path was supposed to be. The nearest person to me was too far ahead to see how they had traversed the water, so I started wading through the shin deep edge and got about 100 metres through. Then I took a step and went waist deep into icy water. I didn’t really get warm again after that.

Between miles 17 and 18 coming off Butser Hill I really was starting to be concerned I was getting hypothermic, with my body shutting down and I felt like I was running on stumps. At which point I walked half a mile and started to get some sensation back into my toes, which was incredibly painful, but I found I could start running again. So I decided to make the most of it and charged for home taking about 4 or 5 other runners in the last two miles.

I think the look on everyone’s faces when I arrived back at the Scout Hut after three and three quarter hours told me how I must of looked and how they were all feeling. I sat there for quite a long time before I had enough feeling and strength to move again, even to clean my feet.

I can confirm I was 69th out of 252 finishers of the 350 registered to run.

My time was 3 hrs 39 min, nearly a whole hour behind the winner. The last runner was round in just under 6 hours.

When I got home I got in the shower with my clothes on and the mud just flowed and flowed from my clothes. There were even bits of straw in my socks from somewhere. Then I ate a cookie. That always helps.

Biggest respect has to go to the Marshalls though. I don’t know how they managed to stay out there in those conditions and keep everyone safe, but I’m sure glad they did.

Here are some horrible pictures of me – I’m even smiling on Butser Hill, though I’d lost a glove by then. And I look misleadingly unmuddy. I’m already thinking about doing it again next year after everyone’s nice emails

Some comments by other runners from the Race Organiser’s Website:

“I have never seen so many people drop out of a race, the conditions were horrendous. Well done marshalls for braving the elements and making sure everyone stayed safe. I  have never quit a race before but at mile 11 (when I couldnt feel my toes or hands) I just simply couldnt take any more. I am a seasoned cross country marathon runner so I am used to this sort of terrain, but when I started to shake I had to call it quits !! Well done to everyone that finished they truly deserved their medals, this was my favourite race last year, this years memories not so good.”

“I'd echo everyone for their thanks to the marshalls.  It was hell out there, I was frozen but I was running to keep warm so it must have been worse for the marshalls.  Every single one, of which there were many, were friendly, attentive and helpful despite the conditions.  A lasting memory of a forgetful day!  Thank you again.”

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
I didn't set out to write a three part post about my end of PhD thoughts, but that's what I seem to have ended up doing.

At the risk of turning this into some kind of self-help manual, this final part is the result of conversations arising from the first two posts and similar ones I've had many times over the years about generally coping in a hard and often arbitrary universe, where luck plays a significant role in outcomes and it all ends badly for everyone!

Firstly here's a condensed version of my current evidence based philosophy for well-being that I've learnt over the last twenty years or so. There are no guarantees of course, but this strategy seems to be most successful:

  1. Be kind.
  2. Seek out enjoyable experiences - and importantly - when you find some, repeat them and keep on repeating them.
  3. Mix with people that reinforce your sense of well-being.

Secondly and following on from this here are my thoughts on how I've learnt to cope with working in three disciplines in which I am still essentially a novice and do not have time to become a fully rounded expert. (Or as XKCD has the situation.)

Hypothesis: actions cause feelings. (Props to Richard Wiseman for bringing to my attention the idea of the flow of cause and effect in that direction, rather than the other way around.)

Here's some examples of how I've tested this hypothesis in my everyday life and I generally find I can't refute it:

Action: Looking at how much there is to know that I don’t know. Feeling: Overwhelmed and anxious.

Action: Comparing myself to someone with much greater experience or ability than me. Feeling: Stupid and inadequate.

Action: Asking for specific feedback, guidance and reassurance. Feeling: Sense of normality, greater perspective and less anxious.

Action: Making a plan along the lines of a SMART* goal based on the actual time available to me and what is sufficient to complete the task, rather than the amount of time that I would wish to have and aiming for perfection. Making decisions about where to compromise breath for depth and vice versa. ( *SMART: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Reversible and Time-based.)

Feeling: Greater sense of control.

Action: Executing a sensible plan. Feeling: Satisfaction at having achieved my goal.

Action: Doing something nice for myself or someone else, showing gratitude to someone for their help etc. Feeling: The sense that most people are fundamentally decent that counteracts the disproportionate effects from those that aren’t.

What can I say! Science is all about looking for underlying patterns and trying to extract over-arching rules. It's also all about testing the ideas that one comes up with from this process and generally speaking those ideas will turn out to be wrong or flawed. It's self-evident that if our ideas were mostly correct we'd have cured cancer, sorted out global warning and stopped fighting over resources a long time ago.

So I'm well aware that neat little acronyms and lists of rules are trite and limited in their ability to accurately guide anyone, but the question for me is how wrong do they have to be to stop being useful? Hence I decided to write this down anyway in the hope that while these thoughts may well be wrong and definitely provisional, it may be of interest or use to someone. As someone said to me a few years back, ideas are literally useless if they are not shared.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: While the micro level science is a bit lost on me, its good (reassuring?) to see that your personal evidence based philosophy is consistent with the actual evidence: http://www.neweconomics.org/projects/five-ways-well-being Weirdly, the area they identify that you haven't mentioned is exercise: maybe that's just taken as read for you!

Yeah, exercise is taken as read for me. Although I thought this idea was also a point of some academic debate these days? It's not just personal evidence though - I can send you the references to illustrate my ideas are at least consistent with some data. Which is not to say there isn't other evidence I'm unaware of that would refute my position! :-)

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Having reflected on my last post and the comments I received I thought I'd be a bit more positive and post a follow-on focused on what I have learnt and where it fits into the scheme of things.

Above is a cartoon I drew to give an overview of the process I've been researching (click on it to enlarge it). This is the process by which our immune system understands whether most of our trillions of cells are healthy or not. Thousands of the yellow molecules in the cartoon are constantly travelling to the surfaces of our cells to act as billboards displaying information about the internal health of our cells. The information the molecule carries is shown here as the red circle.

Most of the time these billboards say all is well and everything carries on as usual. But if the message is that the cell is infected or cancerous, then our T-cells will instruct the unhealthy cell to die.

When we get a cold, this is exactly how we get rid of it. Conversely, the failure to identify unhealthy cells is one reason we die of cancer. And misidentification can cause an auto-immune response such as multiple sclerosis.

In the cartoon this molecule looks like a solid yellow object, but actually these things are probably dynamic like us. They move and the bit holding the red circle may be more like a hand that opens and closes to select the information it displays to the immune system from a large selection of possible messages.

The focus of my research has been to investigate this hypothesis - Are these yellow molecules dynamic? And if so what does this mean for the information they select and any subsequent immune response?

To get a better idea of why this might be a useful thing to know I refer to a recent paper from Nature:

IIlling PT, et al. (2012) Immune self-reactivity triggered by drug-modified HLA-peptide repertoire. Nature 486(7404):554-558.

(You won't be able to read in this full unless you subscribe to Nature)

This paper is all about HIV medication called Abacavir. Although this is an effective medication in the treatment of HIV, this drug sometimes has a side-effect called a hypersensitivity reaction. This is a form of auto-immune response of which Asthma or Rheumatoid arthritis are other examples and in the worst case a hypersensitivity reaction can lead to death from anaphylaxis such as can happen with a peanut allergy.

What the researchers in this paper show is that Abacavir molecule can bind to the yellow molecule in my cartoon in some people just below where the red circle sits. The consequence of this is to change the shape of the "hand" that picks the circle. It's proposed then that this changes the information selected, perhaps it picks the square instead. This changes the information displayed at the cell surface potentially leading to misidentification of a healthy cell as an unhealthy one and an auto-immune response.

This becomes interesting for me when I compare this to my research as I'm looking at how the yellow molecule moves and therefore how the shape of the hand changes in respect to how it selects information. My expectation being that what they observe in Abacavir paper is a consequence of the Abacavir molecule utlimately effecting the motion of the yellow molecule.

So here we see an example of how a medication might cause a problem by doing something we don't want it to do. Abacavir is not designed to bind to the yellow molecule, it's supposed to interfere with HIV replication elsewhere.

But we could reverse that situation and think about how, for example, we might design and use a small molecule to deliberately bind to the yellow molecule and interfere with it to make it move in a way to select the infromation that makes a cancer cell more visible.

To be clear, we don't know how to do that and it could be a complete dead end! But we'd need to understand how these yellow molecules move and the effects of their motions on selection of the information they present if we wanted to attempt such a thing.

Hopefully this example gives some sense of the motivation behind what I've been doing, what we call 'Basic Science' and how it connects to real life. To make really effective cancer drugs (and tackle other diseases) we need to understand in a detailed way how things work at a molecular level if we're ever to move away from what one of my colleagues refers to as our current regieme of 'carve, poison and burn'.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Fascinating, and clearly a great thing to be dedicating research towards. MND is another terrible auto-immune disease that looks to be in your sights as well. Keep up the good work.

item.dc:creator: ab604soton
item.content:encoded:
Just a short post before I finish being a student after eight years. Which is kind of an extraordinary thought.

I'm under two weeks away from submitting my PhD thesis dissertation which I have been writing up since the beginning of October. I was told to allow 12 weeks and I really could do with at least 8 more, but it's a hard deadline and I have to meet it.

I won't have my defence until sometime in 2013, but it'll be a big relief to get the writing bit out of the way. The defence is otherwise known as the viva voce, which in the UK means I get examined by an external and an internal reviewer of my disseration.

I'm afraid I didn't cure cancer and all in all it feels like a pretty mediocre piece of work. I won't really feel like I've done some proper science until I get something published, which I hope will happen when I write it up for publication next year. With luck.

The good news is that I managed to win a successful grant application from the Medical Research Council and Microsoft Research to continue for another 12 months. Which in the current job climate is also a massive relief. The next step will be to try and apply for further grants to try and get some money for several years.

It's really hard to reflect on things with any perspective at the moment as I'm pretty tired and although the stress is not acute - it is just science and one of the most priviledged lifestyles on the planet after all - it has been stress for a prolonged period. Pretty much 12 months of it. So I'll have to have a proper think about how to proceed and whether Academia is for me when the New Year comes. Hopefully my house will be sold too which has been another source of stress and then my mind should be a bit clearer.

I wanted to capture a few photos of what Science looks like from my point of view at this time. The above montage shows both my places of work in Southampton. The Life Sciences Building on the left and the Cancer Science Building on the right. Below is my bench and tools of the trade for my experiments. The rest of my work is computational, so there isn't much to photograph!

Anyhow, thanks to everyone who's provided much needed advice and moral support over the last eight years (and all the paid employment Jon!). It's been a rollercoaster, but hopefully I'm a better person as a result of all this learning.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: well done Al! .. curing cancer single handed was probably a little ambitious anyway.
you have my greatest admiration for what you have achieved & I look forward to more news about whatever you do. It is inspirational. Another year in academia makes sense.
